descriptions.name: "Terrazza delle Stelle" observatory
descriptions.description: Located on Monte Bondone near Trento, Italy at 1,557 meters elevation, this observatory has operated since 2001 with an 80cm computer-controlled reflector telescope and unique steel dome. Recently recognized as a UNESCO World Astronomical Heritage Site, it provides clear skies free from light pollution for observing galaxies, planets, and stars.

descriptions.name: A.C. Barnes Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1903 at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York, this observatory featured a distinctive brick building with three domes and housed a 5-inch equatorial telescope alongside transit instruments. Named after aviation pioneer Patrick Young Alexander who donated funds for its construction, it served as an important facility for astronomical and geodetic research.

descriptions.name: Abbadia Castle
descriptions.description: This 19th-century Neo-Gothic castle and observatory built from 1864-1879 on the Basque coast near Hendaye, France was designed by architect Eugène Viollet-le-Duc. Featuring a unique meridian telescope and hosting high-level international astronomy from 1879-1975, it published 14 stellar catalogs documenting nearly 50,000 stars before being bequeathed to the French Academy of Sciences.

descriptions.name: Abu Rayhan al-Biruni Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at Shiraz University in Iran, this observatory honors Abu al-Rayhan Muhammad ibn Ahmad al-Biruni (973-1048), the renowned Islamic Golden Age scholar who was the first to calculate Earth's radius and contemplated heliocentricity. Named after this polymath who authored approximately 145 works on astronomy and mathematics, it continues the legacy of groundbreaking medieval scientific inquiry.

descriptions.name: Admiral Vasile Urseanu House, Bucharest
descriptions.description: Constructed between 1908-1910 in Bucharest for Admiral Vasile Urseanu, this observatory features a distinctive ship-shaped architecture symbolizing the bond between maritime and celestial interests. Equipped with a 150mm Zeiss telescope, the third largest in Romania at its time, it remains the only observatory open to the public in Bucharest and was restored in 1990 as a historic monument.

descriptions.name: AEMet Izaña
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in 1916 on the island of Tenerife at 2,373 meters altitude, this atmospheric observatory became a WMO Centennial Station after over a century of continuous meteorological and climatological observations. Connected to the nearby Teide Observatory, it serves as a critical facility for greenhouse gas research and atmospheric transparency studies in one of Europe's best observational locations.

descriptions.name: Ager observatory
descriptions.description: Located in the Montsec Mountains near Ager in Lleida, Catalonia, this facility combines a public observation center with the research-grade Observatori del Montsec at 1,570 meters elevation. Recognized with the international Starlight award, it features excellent seeing conditions, low light pollution, and offers guided observations and planetarium visits to the public.

descriptions.name: Ager observatory, Lleida
descriptions.description: This same facility in Ager, Lleida, combines a public center (Centre d'Observació de l'Univers) with a dedicated research observatory in the Montsec mountains recognized as one of Europe's best observational sites. The research-grade Observatori del Montsec and public Parc Astronòmic del Montsec offer excellent conditions for both scientific discovery and public astronomy education.

descriptions.name: Air Force Maui Optical and Supercomputing observatory
descriptions.description: Located on Haleakala volcano in Maui, Hawaii, this U.S. Space Force facility operates the Advanced Electro-Optical System (AEOS), a 3.67-meter telescope serving as the largest optical tracking telescope in the United States. Designed for satellite and ballistic missile tracking with exceptional accuracy, it also houses the Maui High Performance Computing Center for advanced research operations.

descriptions.name: Airdrie Public Observatory
descriptions.description: Operating since 1896 in Airdrie, North Lanarkshire, Scotland, this is the second-oldest and smallest of only four public observatories in the UK. Housing a historic 6-inch Victorian refracting telescope with clockwork drive, it has hosted visiting Apollo astronauts and underwent major restoration in 2013, remaining accessible to the public through the Airdrie Library.

descriptions.name: Al-Khawarizmi Astronomy Complex
descriptions.description: Located in Melaka, Malaysia, this complex established in 2002-2008 emphasizes astronomy's role in Islamic worship through its observatory, planetarium, and training center. Equipped with a 5-meter motorized dome and a 24-inch Ritchey-Chrétien robotic telescope, it serves as an important facility for Islamic astronomical heritage and education.

descriptions.name: Aldershot Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1906 in Aldershot, England as a gift to the British Army, this observatory houses a telescope ordered from the renowned Dublin-based Grubb company in 1891. Notable for the 1933 discovery of a 'great white spot' on Saturn, it underwent major restoration beginning in 2000 and is now maintained by the Farnham Astronomical Society.

descriptions.name: Alexander-Frantz-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Built in 1922 in Dresden, Germany by amateur astronomer Alexander Frantz, this privately-operated observatory served the local astronomy community. Located on the site of Frantz's heating systems factory, it remains a notable astronomy facility in Dresden with restricted public access requiring special permission.

descriptions.name: Algonquin Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1959 in Algonquin Provincial Park, Ontario, this observatory was established to provide a radio-quiet location for Canadian radio astronomy research. Housing the 46-meter radio telescope since 1962, it conducted the first successful long-distance interferometry experiment in 1968 and remains active in VLBI and geodesy research operations.

descriptions.name: Allegheny Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1859 and formally opened in 1867, this is one of America's earliest astronomical institutions, located in Pittsburgh and now part of the University of Pittsburgh. Housing the historic 13-inch Fitz-Clark and 30-inch Thaw refractors, it pioneered the Allegheny Time System and continues to serve educational and research functions.

descriptions.name: Alte Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Built in 1968 as part of the University of Münster's expansion, this observatory served astronomy education until light pollution from nearby student dormitories built in 1972-1974 made observations difficult. Operations ceased in the early 1980s, and the building was converted into an international guest house for visiting scientists in the early 1990s.

descriptions.name: Alte Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Founded in 1845 by astronomer Friedrich Wilhelm August Argelander, this classicist observatory designed by Peter Josef Leydel produced the famous Bonner Durchmusterung catalog of over 324,000 stars. Listed as an IAU Outstanding Astronomical Heritage site, the main building and 1899 refractor dome are architectural monuments, with the Volkssternwarte Bonn using the facility for public astronomy since 1975.

descriptions.name: Altitude SEE Test European Platform
descriptions.description: Established in 2004 on the Plateau de Bure in the French Alps at 2,552 meters elevation, this permanent research platform is dedicated to studying Single Event Effects in microelectronics caused by natural radiation. Operational since 2006, it hosts neutron and muon monitoring equipment for semiconductor vulnerability testing.

descriptions.name: Amphi Ashdod Observatory
descriptions.description: Amphi Ashdod is a large open-air amphitheater venue in Ashdod, Israel with capacity for 6,400 spectators, not a traditional astronomical observatory. Located in Ashdod-Yam Park near the Mediterranean coast, it hosts summer concerts and the international Méditerranée arts festival.

descriptions.name: Amundsen–Scott South Pole Station
descriptions.description: Located at Earth's South Pole, this U.S. research station is a critical center for Antarctic astronomy benefiting from high elevation, extreme dryness, and low temperature conditions. Hosting instruments like the South Pole Telescope and the IceCube neutrino detector with 80 sensor strings reaching 2,450 meters deep, it enables unique observations of the cosmic microwave background and neutrinos from space.

descriptions.name: ancien observatoire astronomique de la Marine de Nantes
descriptions.description: Built in 1826 and inaugurated in 1827 in Nantes, France, this 27-meter-high tower observatory was part of a hydrography school serving maritime navigation. Housing a cabinet of marine chronometer regulation facilities, it operated until 1887 and was rediscovered in the late 20th century, becoming a protected historical monument since 2013.

descriptions.name: Andrushivka Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 2001 in Andrushivka, Zhytomyr Oblast, Ukraine by founder Yuri Ivashchenko, this private observatory features a 60cm Zeiss-600 Cassegrain reflector. Highly productive in minor planet discovery with over a hundred asteroids found, it discovered 133293 Andrushivka and contributed to Wikipedia discovery (274301 Wikipedia) in 2013.

descriptions.name: Angell Hall Observatory
descriptions.description: Located atop Angell Hall at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor since 1927, this observatory contains a computer-controlled 0.4-meter Cassegrain telescope and serves educational and public outreach functions. Complemented by a planetarium with 25-seat capacity, it hosts free public open houses through the Student Astronomical Society.

descriptions.name: Aniane astronomical observatory
descriptions.description: Created in 1976 by amateur astronomer Pierre Bourge near Montpellier, France, this astronomical observatory is the largest amateur observatory in France. Now operating as Astronarium since 2014, it offers unique bubble and dome accommodations alongside telescope observations of the Sun, planets, and stars for public and group events.

descriptions.name: Ankara University Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1959 south of Ankara at 1,256 meters elevation by Dutch astronomer Egbert Kreiken, this observatory was officially inaugurated in 1963. Equipped with multiple telescopes including 35cm and 40cm instruments, it benefits from approximately 300 clear observing nights per year and hosts monthly public astronomy events.

descriptions.name: Antares Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: This observatory complex may refer to either the ANTARES neutrino detector 2.5 kilometers beneath the Mediterranean Sea off Toulon, France (operated 2006-2022), or the Antares Astronomical Observatory museum facility in Feira de Santana, Brazil. The ANTARES neutrino telescope made significant contributions to astroparticle physics research.

descriptions.name: Antonín Bečvář observatory
descriptions.description: Named after Czech astronomer Antonín Bečvář and established in 1970 in Most, Czech Republic, this observatory honors the astronomer who founded Skalnaté Pleso Observatory and discovered comet C/1947 F2. Bečvář created influential star atlases that remain respected in modern astronomy.

descriptions.name: Apache Point Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in the Sacramento Mountains of Sunspot, New Mexico at 9,200 feet elevation, this observatory operated by New Mexico State University houses four research telescopes including the 3.5-meter ARC and 2.5-meter SDSS instruments. Key projects include the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and the APOLLO lunar laser-ranging program with millimeter-level Earth-Moon accuracy.

descriptions.name: Arcetri Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1869 on the hills of Arcetri near Florence, Italy, this observatory was officially inaugurated in 1872 and located near Galileo Galilei's residence. Now part of the National Institute of Astrophysics with over 100 staff, it conducts frontier astrophysics research and maintains the historic Amici Telescope for public observations.

descriptions.name: Archenhold Observatory
descriptions.description: Operating since 1896 in Berlin's Treptower Park, this is Germany's largest and oldest public observatory featuring the Great Refractor with 68cm aperture and 21-meter focal length. The historic Einstein Hall hosts lectures on modern astronomy, while the museum, planetarium, and Celestial Cannon telescope remain major attractions for public education.

descriptions.name: Arecibo Observatory
descriptions.description: Completed in 1963, the Arecibo Observatory in Puerto Rico housed the world's largest single-unit radio telescope at 305 meters until FAST became operational in 2016. Scientists using Arecibo discovered the first extrasolar planets and pulsars, earning Nobel Prize recognition; the iconic telescope collapsed in 2020 but an educational facility was established on the site.

descriptions.name: Argentine Association of Amateur Astronomers
descriptions.description: The Asociación Argentina Amigos de la Astronomía (AAAA) is an amateur astronomy civil association based in Buenos Aires, founded to spread astronomy knowledge. A 1950 asteroid discovery by La Plata Observatory was named 4756 Asaramas in recognition of the association's role in introducing professional astronomers to astronomical science.

descriptions.name: Argentine Institute of Radio Astronomy
descriptions.description: Established in 1962 through an agreement between Argentine scientific agencies and universities, this radio astronomy institute operates two 30-meter single-dish antennas at Pereyra Iraola Park. Officially opened in 1966, it focuses on studying pulsars, radio transients, and blazars in the southern hemisphere at 1.4 GHz frequency.

descriptions.name: Argentine National Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1883 in La Plata, Argentina, this observatory resulted from an 1872 establishment of the National Meteorological Bureau and hosted the first school of astronomy in 1935. Its Gautier equatorial refractor telescope and museum, created in 1997, preserve original instrumentation including the Zeiss blink comparator and Repsold meridian circle.

descriptions.name: Armagh Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1789 by Lord Archbishop Richard Robinson, this is the oldest scientific institution in Northern Ireland and only years younger than Dunsink Observatory. With 224 years of unbroken weather records recognized by the World Meteorological Organisation and the famous NGC catalogue compiled by John Louis Emil Dreyer, it was added to the World Heritage Tentative List in 2025.

descriptions.name: Asahikawa observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Asahikawa, Hokkaido, Japan, this observatory features a 65cm reflector telescope as the third-largest in the region with continued sunspot observations. Integrated into the Asahikawa Science Center, it operates within a comprehensive facility with a large planetarium, laboratory, and exhibition zones.

descriptions.name: Asahikawa Science Center "Sci-Pal"
descriptions.description: The Asahikawa Science Center SCI-PAL is a science museum in Hokkaido featuring permanent exhibitions, a planetarium with 18-meter dome, laboratory, and observation facilities. Divided into Space, Earth, and Northern Country corners with hands-on experiments, it combines education with astronomical observation opportunities.

descriptions.name: Ashton Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Ashton-Wildwood County Park near Baxter, Iowa, this public observatory operated by the Des Moines Astronomical Society features 16-inch and 14-inch computerized telescopes. Operating Saturday nights from April through October with educational lectures, it includes a phosphorescent mural depicting the southern night sky and accommodates groups of up to 50 people.

descriptions.name: Asiago Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1942 and located on the Asiago Plateau 90 kilometers northwest of Padua at 1,045 meters elevation, this University of Padua observatory houses the 1.22-meter Galilei telescope. The nearby Cima Ekar station contains the 182cm Copernicus and 67/92cm Schmidt telescopes, participating in the Asiago-DLR Asteroid Survey and hosting public observations.

descriptions.name: Asiago-DLR Asteroid Survey
descriptions.description: Conducted in the early 2000s using a 67/92cm Schmidt telescope on Mount Ekar, this joint program between Padova Observatory and DLR Berlin discovered over 200 minor planets. Operating with a 2K×2K CCD camera and 0.67-square-degree field, it focused on near-Earth objects and comets using advanced photometry techniques.

descriptions.name: Asociación Entrerriana de Astronomía
descriptions.description: Founded on April 10, 1976 in Entre Ríos, Argentina, this civil astronomy association operates the Oro Verde Observatory, the only public observatory in the province. Established in 1986 with telescopes and a geodesic projection dome, it houses meteorite samples and Soviet space station debris in its Space Museum.

descriptions.name: Assy-Turgen Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 2,750 meters elevation 85 kilometers east of Almaty, Kazakhstan, this observatory operated by the Fesenkov Astrophysical Institute began observations in 1981. Construction started in 1975 but was frozen during Soviet Union collapse, resuming in 2014; it features excellent astroclimatic conditions with sub-2-arcsecond seeing and houses multiple research telescopes.

descriptions.name: Astroblème Charlevoix observatory
descriptions.description: Located in La Malbaie, Quebec, this is the only interpretation center combining meteorite impact education with astronomical observation. Housed in a former golf clubhouse, it offers scientific guides, meteorite samples from Charlevoix, and evening astronomy sessions using modern astrophotography equipment from mid-June through early September.

descriptions.name: Astrodomi Observatory
descriptions.description: This astronomical observatory is located in Tigre, Buenos Aires Province, Argentina. The facility serves amateur and professional astronomical research purposes in the region.

descriptions.name: Astronaut Memorial Planetarium and Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Cocoa, Florida, this planetarium and observatory facility featured a 210-seat theater with 70-foot hemisphere dome and a 24-inch rooftop Ritchey-Chrétien telescope. Operated by Eastern Florida State College, it was damaged by Hurricane Irma in 2017 and demolished in 2022 after fundraising efforts to restore it failed.

descriptions.name: Astronomic Observatory in Włocławek
descriptions.description: This observatory in Włocławek, Poland operates as both an amateur and professional facility registered with the U.S. Naval Observatory. Offering regular theoretical and practical classes, sky shows every clear Friday, and educational programs for regional schools, it serves as an important astronomy popularization center.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Calculation Institute
descriptions.description: While historically named the Astronomical Calculation Institute, modern Polish astronomy is primarily represented by the Nicolaus Copernicus Astronomical Center of the Polish Academy of Sciences in Warsaw. Founded in 1978 with A+ scientific ranking, it conducts advanced research in astronomy, astrophysics, and astroparticle physics.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Center Rijeka
descriptions.description: Opened in 2009 on Sveti Križ hill in a former World War II fortress, this is Croatia's only astronomy center featuring both an observatory and digital planetarium. Equipped with a mobile dome telescope and planetarium hosting 52 visitors to view 118,000 stars, it includes lecture halls and offers panoramic views of Kvarner Bay.

descriptions.name: Rome Observatory - Monte Porzio Catone
descriptions.description: Founded in 1938 on Monte Mario in Rome and relocated to Monte Porzio Catone in 1948, this observatory is now part of the National Institute of Astrophysics with diverse research interests. The facility includes the AstroLAB interactive laboratory, Monteporzio Telescope, and serves students and the public in studying everything from the Solar System to distant galaxies.

descriptions.name: University of Illinois Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1896 in Urbana, Illinois as a National Historic Landmark, this University of Illinois facility revolutionized astronomical photometry through Joel Stebbins' pioneering work with photoelectric cells from 1907-1922. Now used primarily for undergraduate classes and hosting free monthly public open houses, it preserves a 12-inch Brashear refractor as a testament to historic astronomical instrumentation.

descriptions.name: Prešov Observatory and Planetarium
descriptions.description: The Prešov Observatory and Planetarium in Slovakia was founded in 1984 and is equipped with a ZKP-2 planetarium and 150mm refractor-Coude telescope. This cultural-educational institution serves to popularize astronomy, particularly among school students and the general public in Eastern Slovakia.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory and Planetarium "Nicolaus Copernicus"
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory and Planetarium 'Nicolaus Copernicus' in Varna, Bulgaria, was the first astronomical complex in Bulgaria, opened on May 22, 1968. It comprises an astronomical observatory, a planetarium, and a tower with Foucault's pendulum, making it the largest and most modern planetarium in the Balkans.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory Dietrich Schiel
descriptions.description: The Observatório Dietrich Schiel is part of the Center for Scientific and Cultural Dissemination (CDCC) of USP at the São Carlos campus in Brazil, founded on April 10, 1986. It serves as an important center for astronomy education and research in São Paulo state.

descriptions.name: Astronomical observatory Gabrovo
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory and Planetarium Gabrovo was established in 1984 in Bulgaria with the goal of maintaining educational, observational, and cultural functions. It features an American Celestron 14 telescope and a planetarium equipped with 80 seats that presents programs in multiple languages including Bulgarian, English, German, and Russian.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory in Belgrade
descriptions.description: Founded in 1887, the Belgrade Astronomical Observatory is one of the oldest scientific institutions in Serbia, with its current complex built between 1929-1932. The observatory conducts research across all areas of astronomy and astrophysics, and operates the Astronomical Station Vidojevica with a robotic 1.4-meter telescope named after Milutin Milanković.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory in Tradate
descriptions.description: The Tradate Observatory in Italy is part of the Fondazione Osservatorio Astronomico Messier 13 (FOAM13) and is notable for having a Moon Tree (a cutting grown from a tree carried to the moon) planted at its park in 2011. The facility supports active astronomical observation and research in the Lombardy region.

descriptions.name: astronomical observatory Manfred von Ardenne
descriptions.description: The Sternwarte Manfred von Ardenne in Dresden, Germany, was built in 1956 and reopened to the public in 2007 after a 10-year renovation marking the 100th birthday of company founder Manfred von Ardenne. The observatory features a refractor telescope with a focal ratio of 1:15 for public observations.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Abruzzo
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory of Abruzzo encompasses the historic Collurania-Teramo Observatory founded in 1890 and the high-altitude Campo Imperatore station at 2,150 meters in the Gran Sasso mountains. It is the highest professional astronomical observatory in Italy and conducts research on supernovae, stellar variability, and active galactic nuclei.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Capodimonte
descriptions.description: Founded in 1807 by Joseph Bonaparte and relocated to its current Capodimonte location in 1819, the Astronomical Observatory of Capodimonte is part of Italy's National Institute for Astrophysics. The observatory features a 40cm main telescope and houses the MuSA museum with historic astronomical instruments from the 16th-19th centuries.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Garraf
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory of Garraf in Spain is housed in an old agricultural storehouse in the Parc Natural del Garraf with minimal light pollution, making it the closest observatory to populated areas with excellent dark skies. The facility operates a digital planetarium and hosts educational and observational activities throughout the year.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Kyiv University
descriptions.description: The Kyiv Astronomical Observatory was founded in 1845 and is one of the oldest astronomical institutions, with its original building now serving as a museum with a rich collection of scientific instruments. The observatory operates two main facilities at Lisnyky and Pylypovychi and conducts research on solar activity, satellite tracking, and celestial body mapping.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Lisbon
descriptions.description: The Lisbon Astronomical Observatory was formally established in 1878 after construction began in 1861, with the building designed in the style of the Russian Pulkova Observatory. The observatory made significant contributions to positional astronomy since the 19th century and became part of the University of Lisbon in 1992.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Mount Deva
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory of Mount Deva is located in Romania and is part of the country's astronomical research infrastructure, positioned on Kaldiniai hill in a rural setting conducive to observations.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Padova
descriptions.description: La Specola in Padua, Italy, was converted from a 14th-century tower into an astronomical observatory in 1767 and was one of the finest observatories in eighteenth-century Europe. The facility operated until 1942 when it moved to Asiago, but the tower now serves as an astronomical museum while maintaining active research.

descriptions.name: Astronomical observatory of Palermo
descriptions.description: Founded in 1790 by Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies under the direction of Giuseppe Piazzi, who discovered the dwarf planet Ceres in 1801, the Palermo Observatory is housed in the Palazzo dei Normanni. The Museo della Specola houses a valuable collection of over 100 scientific instruments from the 18th-19th centuries.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Saratov State University
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory of Saratov State University is located in Saratov, Russia, and is part of the university founded in 1909. The observatory serves as part of the region's significant scientific infrastructure alongside multiple institutes of the Russian Academy of Sciences.

descriptions.name: Astronomical observatory of Siena observatory
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory of the Università degli Studi di Siena was established in 2004 on the Porta Romana University Campus, featuring a 3-meter diameter dome and Maksutov-Cassegrain telescope. The observatory serves as a teaching and research asset where students can conduct small projects on asteroids, variable stars, exoplanets, and active galactic nuclei.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of the Infante D. Luís Geophysical Institute
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory of the Infante D. Luís Geophysical Institute, located in Lisbon, was one of Portugal's leading meteorologic and magnetic research institutions in the 19th century. The observatory conducted geomagnetic observations beginning in 1857 and pioneered solar photography from 1871-1880 to study relationships between solar activity and Earth's magnetic field.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of the Jagiellonian University
descriptions.description: The Nicolaus Copernicus Astronomical Observatory of Jagiellonian University in Krakow was founded in 1792 and continues the excellent astronomical tradition that began when Copernicus studied at the university in the 15th century. Located at Fort Skała with five astronomical domes, the observatory conducts research and provides educational programs for students.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of the University of Kazan
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory of Kazan Federal University, founded in 1810, was the first university observatory in Russia, and the Engelhardt Astronomical Observatory was added in 1901. Both facilities were inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List in 2023 and continue as active educational and research centers.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Trieste
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Observatory of Trieste traces its origins to the Nautical School founded in 1753 and became part of Italy's National Institute for Astrophysics (INAF) in 1923. The observatory conducts research from solar studies to distant galaxies and produces over 130 peer-reviewed scientific papers annually.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Observatory of Vilnius University
descriptions.description: Founded in 1753 by Jesuit astronomer Thomas Zebrowski, the Vilnius University Astronomical Observatory is the fourth oldest observatory in Europe and pioneered the Vilnius photometric system in the 1960s. The observatory relocated to Molėtai District in the 1960s due to light pollution and continues as an educational and research institution.

descriptions.name: Astronomical station at North Caucasus ﻿of Kazan Federal University
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Station at North Caucasus of Kazan Federal University operates on Pastukhov Mountain at approximately 2,000 meters in the Russian Caucasus region. This facility is part of Kazan University's network of observatories and serves both research and educational purposes.

descriptions.name: Astronomical Tower in Clementinum Prague
descriptions.description: The Astronomical Tower in Clementinum Prague was completed in 1722 and stands 68 meters high with 172 spiral stairs leading to its top, crowned by a 2.4-meter lead statue of Atlas. The tower was used for astronomical observations and meteorological measurements from 1751 to 1938 and now features the Meridian Hall with period instruments accessible to visitors.

descriptions.name: Astronomische Station „Tycho Brahe“
descriptions.description: Uraniborg was an astronomical observatory established in 1576 on the island of Ven by Danish astronomer Tycho Brahe, making it the first custom-built observatory in modern Europe. The observatory produced the first extensive organized array of dependable astronomical data in history, including a catalog of over 1,000 stars.

descriptions.name: Astronomisches Zentrum Schkeuditz
descriptions.description: The Astronomisches Zentrum Schkeuditz in Saxony, Germany, has existed since 1978 and features a planetarium with an 8-meter dome capacity for 60 guests and an observatory with viewing platform. Located near Leipzig, this facility offers public sky observations during winter months for astronomy enthusiasts.

descriptions.name: Astronomy Club of Kosova
descriptions.description: The Astronomy Club of Kosova operates as an amateur astronomical organization promoting astronomy education and observation in Kosovo.

descriptions.name: Astronomy Station "Samuel Heinrich Schwabe"
descriptions.description: The Astronomy Station 'Samuel Heinrich Schwabe' in Dessau-Roßlau, Germany, is named after the 19th-century German amateur astronomer who discovered the 10-year sunspot cycle after 17 years of continuous observations starting in 1825. The observatory carries forward his legacy of solar observation and amateur astronomy.

descriptions.name: Astronomy tower of the Sorbonne
descriptions.description: The Astronomy Tower of the Sorbonne in Paris was constructed between 1885 and 1901 and stands 39 meters high with upper and lower domes for astronomical observations. The tower features a 153mm refracting telescope installed in 1980 and an optics workshop, operated by the Société astronomique de France for public tours and amateur observations.

descriptions.name: Astrophysical Observatory of Javalambre
descriptions.description: The Astrophysical Observatory of Javalambre in Teruel, Spain, is located at 1,957 meters in the Sierra de Javalambre and was awarded a Starlight Foundation Reserve designation in 2017. The observatory operates two professional wide-field telescopes (JST250 and JAST80) and conducts surveys for dark energy research through the J-PLUS and J-PAS projects.

descriptions.name: Australian Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Australian Astronomical Observatory (formerly Anglo-Australian Observatory) operates the 3.9-metre Anglo-Australian Telescope and the 1.2-metre UK Schmidt Telescope at Siding Spring Observatory near Coonabarabran. The Anglo-Australian Telescope was inaugurated in 1974 and the organization has been a leading institution in astronomical research and instrumentation development.

descriptions.name: Badalona Boreal observatory
descriptions.description: The Badalona Boreal Observatory (or Fabra Observatory in Barcelona) is an astronomical observatory established in 1904 on Tibidabo mountain, Barcelona, and is the fourth oldest observatory in the world still functioning. The observatory specializes in the study of asteroids and comets and offers guided visits and summer evening stargazing programs.

descriptions.name: Badlands Observatory
descriptions.description: Badlands Observatory in Quinn, South Dakota, was founded in 2000 by amateur astronomer Ron Dyvig with a 26-inch computerized Newtonian Reflector telescope. The facility has made significant contributions to asteroid research, discovering 25 main belt asteroids and recovering a near-earth asteroid lost for 15 years, and now offers astrotourism experiences.

descriptions.name: Baikal Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Baikal Astrophysical Observatory was founded in 1980 on the shores of Lake Baikal near Listvyanka, Russia, and houses the largest solar vacuum telescope in Russia and Eurasia. The observatory focuses on solar activity research, particularly solar flares, and features an adaptive optics system and observation deck.

descriptions.name: Baksan Neutrino Observatory
descriptions.description: The Baksan Neutrino Observatory in the North Caucasus mountains, Russia, started operations in 1977 as the first neutrino observatory in the USSR. Located two miles underground beneath Mount Andyrchy with 12,000 feet of rock protection, it operates major experiments including the Baksan Underground Scintillator Telescope (BUST) and the Baksan Experiment on Sterile Transitions (BEST).

descriptions.name: Baldone Observatory
descriptions.description: The Baldone Astrophysical Observatory is the only professional optical observatory in Latvia, established through the Academy of Sciences' astronomy work beginning in 1946. The facility features a Schmidt telescope—the 12th largest in the world—and has discovered 77 asteroids during its operation.

descriptions.name: Barnard Observatory
descriptions.description: Barnard Observatory at the University of Mississippi was completed in 1859 as a Greek Revival building modeled after Pulkova Observatory, though the intended telescopes were never delivered due to the Civil War. The building now houses the Center for the Study of Southern Culture while remaining on the National Register of Historic Places.

descriptions.name: Basic Environmental Observatory - Musala
descriptions.description: The Basic Environmental Observatory - Musala on Bulgaria's highest peak (2,925 meters) was established in 1999 and monitors air pollutants and space radiation. Originally founded in 1932 as a weather station and expanded with a cosmic ray station in 1960, it continues as an important research facility.

descriptions.name: Batabat Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Batabat Astrophysical Observatory on Bataban Mountain in Azerbaijan's Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic, established in 1971, operates a solar Lyot coronograph and various telescopes for observation of bright stars and Solar System bodies. The observatory has won international grants for research on solar activity physics and forecasting.

descriptions.name: Bavarian Public Observatory Munich
descriptions.description: The Bavarian Public Observatory Munich (Volkssternwarte München), founded in 1947, has grown to become one of Germany's largest and best-known amateur astronomical clubs with about 600 members. The facility features a 300-square-meter observation platform with four telescopes and a planetarium in a 4.5-meter sky dome, welcoming 25,000 visitors annually.

descriptions.name: Bayfordbury Observatory
descriptions.description: Bayfordbury Observatory has been the University of Hertfordshire's teaching observatory since 1970 and is one of the best equipped teaching observatories in the United Kingdom. Located on a 372-acre estate near Hertford, it features seven permanently mounted optical telescopes including a 24-inch Planewave CDK and extensive radio astronomy capabilities.

descriptions.name: Beijing Ancient Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1442 during the Ming dynasty, the Beijing Ancient Observatory is one of the world's earliest royal observatories, predating Greenwich by two centuries. The observatory operated without telescopes and was converted into China's first astronomical museum in 1929, showcasing ancient Chinese astronomical achievements.

descriptions.name: Belogradchik Observatory
descriptions.description: The Belogradchik Observatory in northwest Bulgaria operates three telescopes for public viewing and is located near the dramatic Belogradchik Rocks, a stunning sandstone and conglomerate rock formation reaching up to 100 meters in height. The facility supports astronomy education in the region near the Balkan Mountains.

descriptions.name: Bernoulliborg
descriptions.description: The Blaauw Observatory, located atop the Bernoulliborg building on the University of Groningen's Zernike Campus in the Netherlands, opened in 2008 and features a 40cm Ritchey-Chrétien reflecting telescope. The observatory, one of the largest teaching observatories in the Netherlands, serves both educational purposes for students and public outreach.

descriptions.name: Besançon Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Besançon Astronomical Observatory was built in 1862 and inaugurated in 1884 as a center for research into astrophysics and timekeeping, founded to support the local watchmaking industry. It is one of only three organizations worldwide that can award the official title of chronometer and is classified as a historic monument.

descriptions.name: Beverly-Begg Observatory
descriptions.description: The Beverly-Begg Observatory in Dunedin, New Zealand, was established in 1922 by the Dunedin Astronomical Society and is named after local astronomers Arthur Beverly and John Campbell Begg. The observatory features modern equipment including a 35cm Celestron telescope and opens to the public on Sunday nights during winter months.

descriptions.name: BGSU Observatory
descriptions.description: The BGSU Observatory at Bowling Green State University in Ohio is housed on the roof of the Physical Sciences Laboratory Building and features a computer-operated 0.5-meter reflecting telescope. The facility serves both educational instruction and public stargazing sessions and is equipped with a First Magnitude CCD camera for astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Bidston Observatory
descriptions.description: Bidston Observatory, built in 1866 on Bidston Hill in Merseyside, England, was originally designed to set exact time for ships, firing a signal gun daily at 1 PM until 1969. The grade-II listed building played a crucial role in tidal predictions during World War II for D-day planning and now operates as an artistic research center.

descriptions.name: Big Bear Solar Observatory
descriptions.description: The Big Bear Solar Observatory on the north side of Big Bear Lake in California's San Bernardino Mountains, operated by the New Jersey Institute of Technology, is dedicated to studying the Sun through a 1.6-meter Goode Solar Telescope. The high-altitude location benefits from the stabilizing influence of the lake, providing ideal conditions for solar observation and research on sunspots and magnetic fields.

descriptions.name: Bisei Spaceguard Center
descriptions.description: The Bisei Spaceguard Center in Japan, constructed during 1999-2000, operates the Bisei Asteroid Tracking Telescope for Rapid Survey (BATTeRS) to track asteroids and space debris. The facility has discovered over 400 minor planets and tracks potentially hazardous asteroids using 1-meter, 50-centimeter, and 25-centimeter telescopes.

descriptions.name: Bishop Observatory
descriptions.description: George Bishop's Observatory was established in 1836 in London and was one of the first modern astronomical observatories, though it closed in 1877 after relocating to Twickenham. In the 20th century, several observatories have been named Bishop, including facilities at Bishop's University in Canada and the Owens Valley Radio Observatory near Bishop, California, which serves as a major solar radio research facility.

descriptions.name: Bismarck Tower (Remscheid)
descriptions.description: Bismarck Tower Remscheid features an observatory housed within a 30-meter sandstone tower built in 1901 in Remscheid, Germany. After World War II, the tower's dome was reconstructed and in 1968 the facility was handed over to the observatory, which is now open to public visits on Wednesdays and Sundays.

descriptions.name: Black Birch Astrometric Observatory
descriptions.description: Black Birch Astrometric Observatory was the southern station of the US Naval Observatory located outside Blenheim, New Zealand. Operating from 1984 through 1996, it used a 7-inch Transit Circle Telescope for measuring precise positions of southern hemisphere stars until rendered obsolete by the Hipparcos satellite.

descriptions.name: Blackrock Castle
descriptions.description: Blackrock Castle is a 16th-century fortification in Cork, Ireland, built in 1582 with a round tower constructed around 1600 to defend against pirates. Today it serves as a science center with historical significance as an important coastal defense structure.

descriptions.name: Blackrock Castle Observatory
descriptions.description: MTU Blackrock Castle Observatory is an award-winning science center and active research observatory in Cork, Ireland, featuring a 16-inch robotic telescope managed by researchers from the Munster Technological University for exoplanet searches. The facility includes interactive astronomy exhibits and is open daily from 10am to 6pm.

descriptions.name: Bleien Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Bleien Radio Observatory is located near Gränichen in Switzerland and has been operated by ETH Zurich since 1979, focusing on large bandwidth radio spectroscopy. The facility was converted starting in 2014 to observe extragalactic and cosmological sources, and is also the starting point of the international e-CALLISTO network for solar activity monitoring.

descriptions.name: Bobergs observatorium
descriptions.description: Bobergs observatorium (also Boberg's observatory) is located at Skansen in Stockholm, Sweden, among the country's historical astronomical observation sites. The facility is listed among Sweden's significant observatories and continues to support astronomical education and research.

descriptions.name: Bohnenberger Observatorium
descriptions.description: Bohnenberger Observatorium is located on Hohentübingen Castle in Tübingen, Germany, and is considered the oldest ground-level observatory in the world. Established around 1814 with a Reichenbach repetition circle instrument, it was restored and opened as a museum by the University of Tübingen in 2018 to commemorate 200 years of Württemberg surveying.

descriptions.name: Boleslav Tecla Observatory in Moravská Třebová
descriptions.description: Boleslav Tecla Observatory in Moravská Třebová, Czech Republic was opened to the public in 1976 after construction began in 1971. Founded by teacher Boleslav Tecl and affiliated with the local House of Pioneers and Youth, the observatory serves astronomy education at an elevation of 412 meters.

descriptions.name: Bolivian National Observatory at Tarija
descriptions.description: The Bolivian National Observatory at Tarija was built in 1982 in collaboration with the USSR and is also known as the Santa Ana Astronomical Observatory. Located about 14 km southeast of Tarija, it made observations of 200,000 faint stars and serves as the facility from which Bolivia's official national time is broadcast.

descriptions.name: Bordeaux Observatory
descriptions.description: Bordeaux Observatory was founded in 1879 at Floirac by astronomer Georges Rayet and features several equatorial refractors and a transit circle. The observatory became active in radio astronomy in the late 20th century and is now part of the Observatoire Aquitain des Sciences de l'Univers (OASU).

descriptions.name: Borisova gradina Observatory
descriptions.description: Borisova gradina Observatory in Sofia, Bulgaria was built in 1892-1897 and is the oldest surviving astronomical observatory in Bulgaria, featuring a historic 15.2cm-Grubb-Refractor telescope. Recently renovated, it now offers public outreach with both daytime lectures and evening observations of celestial objects.

descriptions.name: Bosianu Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Bosianu Astronomical Observatory in Bucharest, Romania features the Bosianu House built in 1859 with an octagonal architectural design in the Romantic style. The facility is currently used as the Library of the Astronomical Institute and is designated as a Historic Monument.

descriptions.name: Bosque Alegre ground station
descriptions.description: Bosque Alegre is an astrophysics station of the National University of Cordoba operated in Argentina, serving dual purposes as both a satellite ground station for telecommunications (since 1983) and an astrophysics observatory. Located at 1200 meters altitude in the Sierras Chicas, it operates multiple telescopes for research on comets, active galaxies, and galaxy clusters.

descriptions.name: Bosscha Observatory
descriptions.description: Bosscha Observatory in Lembang, West Java is the oldest modern observatory in Indonesia, constructed from 1923-1928 and named after Karel Albert Rudolf Bosscha, a tea tycoon who sponsored its instrumentation. Operating at 1,310 meters elevation since 1951 under Indonesian government operation, it focuses on stellar evolution, variable stars, and exoplanet research.

descriptions.name: Bothkamp Observatory
descriptions.description: Bothkamp Observatory was built in 1869 as a private observatory of Friedrich Gustav von Bülow in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany, and housed a 29-cm refractor that was the largest on the continent at the time. A cradle of astrophysics before Potsdam Observatory, it ended operations in 1914 and was demolished in the 1930s, though its instruments were preserved.

descriptions.name: Bowman Observatory
descriptions.description: Bowman Observatory is an educational facility built in the 1940s on the grounds of Julian Curtiss School in Greenwich, Connecticut, and is operated by the Astronomical Society of Greenwich. Named after Dr. J. Edgar Bowman, it features a 16-inch Ritchey-Chretien telescope and is open to the public free of charge on first and third Wednesday evenings.

descriptions.name: Brackett Observatory
descriptions.description: Brackett Observatory at Pomona College in Claremont, California was built in 1908 and serves as the campus hub for astronomy education. The facility features two domes housing 14-inch Celestron reflectors with CCD cameras, allowing students to conduct remote telescope operations for planetary and deep-sky imaging.

descriptions.name: Brazil National Observatory
descriptions.description: Brazil's National Observatory (Observatório Nacional) was founded by Pedro I on October 15, 1827, and is one of Brazil's oldest scientific institutions. Transferred to Saint Kitts hill in Rio de Janeiro in 1921, it is responsible for Brazil's official time and conducts research in astronomy, astrophysics, and geophysics.

descriptions.name: Brera Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Brera Astronomical Observatory has been established in Milan's Palazzo Brera since 1762 and is the oldest scientific institution in Milan. The observatory's main site moved to Villa San Rocco in Merate in 1923, and it now operates under the National Institute for Astrophysics (INAF) with research spanning from planetary to cosmological studies.

descriptions.name: Breslau observatory
descriptions.description: Breslau Observatory (Wrocław Observatory) was founded in 1791 in the Mathematical Tower of Breslau University and was home to Neptune's discoverer Johann Gottfried Galle. The distinctive red Bauhaus-style building completed in 1927 houses a 20-cm-Clark-Repsold refractor and remains in use as the Astronomical Institute of Wrocław University.

descriptions.name: Brno Observatory and Planetarium
descriptions.description: Brno Observatory and Planetarium opened on October 16, 1954, and has become a top institution for science popularization in Czech Republic, visited by over 100,000 people annually. The modern functionalist building reconstructed in 2010-2011 features a state-of-the-art 17-meter digital planetarium and was nominated for the 2013 Mies van der Rohe Awards.

descriptions.name: Brorfelde Observatory
descriptions.description: Brorfelde Observatory is Denmark's largest star observatory, built between 1953 and 1964 by the University of Copenhagen to replace the Østervold Observatory. Originally operating as a research facility for asteroid discovery using the Schmidt Telescope, it is now being converted into an experience center for public astronomy education.

descriptions.name: Bruno-H.-Bürgel-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Bruno-H.-Bürgel-Sternwarte is a public observatory in the Staaken district of Berlin, Germany, founded as an amateur astronomy club on April 6, 1982, and opening in 1992. Named after astronomer Bruno Hans Bürgel, it features Berlin's largest 61-centimeter Cassegrain telescope and offers regular public observations and lectures.

descriptions.name: Buehler Planetarium and Observatory
descriptions.description: Emil Buehler Trust Observatory at Bergen Community College in Paramus, New Jersey was established through a grant of $288,875 from the Emil Buehler Trust. The observatory serves primarily as an educational facility for astronomy classes and hosts public viewing nights staffed by the Buehler Columbia Amateur Astronomers Association.

descriptions.name: Bukit Melawati
descriptions.description: Bukit Melawati is a historical hill in Kuala Selangor, Malaysia, featuring a simple observatory tower (baitulhilal) constructed for Islamic calendar observations to determine the start of Ramadan and other religious holidays. As one of Malaysia's traditional new moon sighting locations, it continues to serve this astronomical and cultural purpose.

descriptions.name: Burrell Memorial Observatory
descriptions.description: Burrell Memorial Observatory on the campus of Baldwin Wallace University in Berea, Ohio was established in 1940 as a gift from Katherine Ward Burrell in honor of her husband. The observatory houses a 13 3/8-inch Warner and Swasey refractor, making it the second-largest refractor in Ohio, and is one of the state's most beautiful vintage observatories.

descriptions.name: Buthiers Observatory
descriptions.description: Buthiers Observatory (Jean-Marc-Salomon Astronomy Center) is located in the heart of Buthiers Leisure Island near Fontainebleau Forest in France and was named after a volunteer who died in 1981. Operating two telescopes (510mm and 600mm) registered with the Minor Planet Center, it offers year-round public astronomical activities including planetarium shows and observations.

descriptions.name: Byurakan Observatory
descriptions.description: Byurakan Astrophysical Observatory was founded in 1946 by Viktor Hambardzumyan on Mount Aragats in Armenia and officially opened in 1956. One of the most important astronomical centers in the Eastern Europe and Middle East region, it has discovered stellar associations, over 1,000 flare stars, and the famous Markarian galaxies, which are in UNESCO's Memory of the World program.

descriptions.name: Cagliari Observatory
descriptions.description: Cagliari Observatory, an INAF facility located 20 km from Cagliari on the island of Sardinia, was founded in 1899 to study Earth's rotation. The observatory continues active astronomical research and hosts the Sardinia Radio Telescope for high-frequency radio astronomy observations.

descriptions.name: Calais Observatory
descriptions.description: The historical Calais Observatory connection relates to longitude determination efforts from 1784-1790, when the tower of Notre-Dame church in Calais, France was used as an observation point for the Anglo-French Survey. In more modern times, Calais features observational facilities for astronomical education and research.

descriptions.name: Calar Alto Observatory
descriptions.description: Calar Alto Observatory is the largest astronomical observatory on mainland Europe, located at 2,168 meters in the Sierra de Los Filabres near Almería, Spain. Featuring 4 main telescopes including a 3.5-meter instrument (second-largest in mainland Europe), it conducts broad research from solar system to cosmology, including the CARMENES exoplanet survey launched in 2016.

descriptions.name: Caltech Submillimeter Observatory
descriptions.description: Caltech Submillimeter Observatory (CSO) was a world-premier facility for submillimeter wavelength research operating from 1987 to 2015 at 4,070 meters on Maunakea, Hawaii. After decommissioning from 2015-2024, its 10.4-meter telescope was relocated to Chile as the Leighton Chajnantor Telescope, expected to begin observations in 2027.

descriptions.name: Calvin College Observatory
descriptions.description: Calvin University Observatory is located on the roof of the Science Building in Grand Rapids, Michigan and serves primarily educational purposes for students at all levels. The facility operates in conjunction with the Calvin-Rehoboth Robotic Observatory in New Mexico and is open to the public on clear Wednesday evenings.

descriptions.name: Cambridge Observatory
descriptions.description: Cambridge Observatory was established in 1823 at the University of Cambridge and features a historic Doric-style building designed by John Clamant Reed and designated as a Listed Building. The old Observatory now houses the Institute of Astronomy Library, and the site operates optical telescopes including historic Northumberland and Thorrowgood telescopes used for public outreach.

descriptions.name: Camille Flammarion Observatory
descriptions.description: Camille Flammarion Observatory was established in 1883 in Juvisy-sur-Orge, France by the famous astronomer and author Camille Flammarion, featuring a 240mm equatorial refractor in a 5-meter dome. In 2010 it was classified as a historical monument, and today the Société Astronomique de France organizes regular public observations.

descriptions.name: Campo Imperatore Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Campo Imperatore Astronomical Observatory is located at 2,150 meters in the Gran Sasso mountains of Abruzzo, Italy, making it the highest professional observatory in the country. Founded in 1965, it features the AZT-24 telescope for searching extragalactic supernovae, variable stars, and minor bodies of the solar system in the near-infrared.

descriptions.name: Canada–France–Hawaii Telescope
descriptions.description: The Canada–France–Hawaii Telescope (CFHT) is a 3.58-meter telescope operational since 1979 on Mauna Kea at 4,204 meters elevation, governed by a tripartite agreement between the USA, Canada, and France. Once the world's most powerful telescope until 1994, it received an adaptive optics system in 1996 and is planned for reconstruction as the Maunakea Spectroscopic Explorer by 2029.

descriptions.name: Cantonal observatory, Hirsch pavilion, director's house and La Méridienne house
descriptions.description: Several historic observatories in Switzerland, including cantonal observatories and facilities like Hirsch pavilion and director's residences, represent 18th and 19th-century astronomical heritage in the region. These facilities served scientific and educational purposes for regional astronomical research and timekeeping.

descriptions.name: Carkeek Observatory
descriptions.description: Carkeek Observatory is New Zealand's earliest surviving astronomical observatory, built around 1867 by retired customs officer Stephen Carkeek on his farm south of Featherston in the Wairarapa. Though now a partial ruin, the historic structure was designated as Category I on New Zealand's Heritage List on June 26, 2020.

descriptions.name: Carter Observatory
descriptions.description: Space Place at Carter Observatory is located at the top of Wellington Botanic Garden in New Zealand and originally opened as Carter Observatory in 1941. Named after Wellington businessman Charles Rooking Carter, it became New Zealand's National Observatory in 1977 and now features a digital planetarium and the historic 9¾-inch Cooke refractor telescope.

descriptions.name: Catania Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: Catania Astrophysical Observatory in Sicily, Italy continues research traditions dating to the 1434 founding of the University of Catania, operating from Mount Etna at 2,941 meters since 1880. The observatory's privileged location at the foot of Mount Etna has enabled nearly 100 years of continuous solar activity observation and stellar physics research.

descriptions.name: Cawthron Atkinson Observatory
descriptions.description: Cawthron Atkinson Observatory in Nelson, New Zealand was founded by amateur astronomer Arthur Atkinson in 1883 and relocated in 2008 after major refurbishment funded by the Cawthron Trust. The facility houses a 14-inch Schmidt Cassegrain telescope and is administered by the Astronomy Section of the Nelson Science Society.

descriptions.name: Center of Research in Astronomy, Astrophysics and Geophysics
descriptions.description: The Center of Research in Astronomy, Astrophysics, and Geophysics (CRAAG) is located in Algiers, Algeria and combines astronomical research with seismic monitoring activities. Established as the Algiers Observatory in the late 19th century and renamed in 1985, it conducts research across astronomy, astrophysics, and geophysics disciplines.

descriptions.name: Centre de recherches en géodynamique et astrométrie
descriptions.description: Centre de recherches en géodynamique et astrométrie (CERGA) was a CNRS research unit established in 1974 and affiliated with the Côte d'Azur Observatory in France. Operating sites in Nice, Grasse, and Calern with 28 researchers, it discovered 21 asteroids and was dissolved in 2004 following observatory reorganization.

descriptions.name: Centro Astronómico, Tiedra
descriptions.description: Centro Astronómico de Tiedra in Valladolid, Spain was established in 2013 and holds the UNESCO Starlight Certificate as a Star Park. Located on the Iberian plateau with dark skies, the center features three telescopes for different observation types and a 7-meter planetarium dome with multimedia digital projection.

descriptions.name: Centro Sismológico de Sonseca
descriptions.description: Centro Sismológico de Sonseca in Toledo, Spain was established by the US Air Force in 1956 to monitor nuclear tests and began operations in February 1957. With 26 seismic stations monitoring earthquakes and nuclear explosions globally, it was modernized in 2000 to become a primary station of the CTBTO International Monitoring System.

descriptions.name: Cerro El Roble Observatory
descriptions.description: Cerro El Roble Observatory is a station of the National Astronomical Observatory of Chile located on Cerro El Roble mountain in the Hijuelas area at approximately 2,185 meters elevation. The facility sits on the border between Santiago Metropolitan Region and Valparaíso Region within La Campana National Park.

descriptions.name: Cerro Murphy Observatory
descriptions.description: Cerro Murphy Observatory (renamed Rolf Chini Cerro Murphy Observatory in November 2023) is operated by the Nicolaus Copernicus Astronomical Center at 2,817 meters in Chile's Antofagasta Region. Established in 2005 and transferred in 2020, the facility houses 5 telescopes ranging from 0.3 to 1.5 meters for cosmic distance scale calibration research.

descriptions.name: Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory
descriptions.description: Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory (CTIO) is located 80 km east of La Serena, Chile at 2,200 meters elevation and hosts approximately 40 telescopes across 11 tenant observatories. Construction began in 1963 with observations commencing in 1965, and CTIO is now operated by NSF's NOIRLab, providing southern hemisphere access for worldwide scientific research.

descriptions.name: Chabot Space and Science Center
descriptions.description: Founded in 1883 by Anthony Chabot, this Oakland observatory houses three historic telescopes including an 8-inch refractor (Leah) and the historic 20-inch refractor (Rachel), one of the largest open to the public in North America, along with the 36-inch reflector (Nellie) installed in 2003.

descriptions.name: Chamberlin Observatory
descriptions.description: A historic observatory in Madison, Wisconsin, though specific details about a dedicated Chamberlin Observatory building remain limited; the area has Washburn Observatory and Chamberlin Rock nearby on Observatory Hill.

descriptions.name: Chankillo
descriptions.description: An ancient solar observatory on Peru's north-central coast (250-200 BC) featuring 13 towers aligned to mark solstices and equinoxes, now a UNESCO World Heritage Site that recently revealed evidence of lunar observations as well.

descriptions.name: Chelmos Observatory
descriptions.description: Located on Mount Chelmos in Greece at 2,330 meters, this observatory hosts the Aristarchos 2.3-meter telescope, the largest in the Balkans and second-largest in mainland Europe, with exceptional dark skies for astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Chico Community Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 2001 in Bidwell Park near Chico, California, this non-profit observatory provides free public telescope viewing on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday evenings and features an open-air amphitheater for casual stargazing.

descriptions.name: Chilbolton Observatory
descriptions.description: Located near Stockbridge in Hampshire, England, this atmospheric and radio research facility opened in 1967 and hosts the CAMRa weather radar, the UK's LOFAR telescope station, and diverse research in astronomy and space science.

descriptions.name: Chorzow observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1955 in Chorzów, Poland, this is the largest and oldest planetarium in Poland with a 300-mm refractor telescope (the largest in use in Poland) and conducts research on comets and minor planets.

descriptions.name: Chuguevskaya Station Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in the early 1960s near Kharkiv, Ukraine, this observatory conducted photometric observations of asteroids, exoplanet searches, and meteor observations using speckle interferometry methods before being damaged during the 2022 conflict.

descriptions.name: Cima Ekar Observing Station
descriptions.description: Located on Cima Ekar in the Asiago area of Italy, this annex observatory hosts the 182-cm Copernicus telescope (Italy's largest) and the 67/92-cm Schmidt telescope, supporting the Asiago-DLR Asteroid Survey.

descriptions.name: Cincinnati Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1842 in Cincinnati, known as the birthplace of American astronomy, this observatory moved to Mount Lookout in 1873 and houses an 11-inch Merz and Mahler refractor from 1845 and a 16-inch Alvan Clark refractor from 1904.

descriptions.name: City Dome, City Observatory, Calton Hill, Edinburgh
descriptions.description: Built on Edinburgh's Calton Hill and operational from 1812-1896, this observatory housed both the Playfair Building and the distinctive City Dome (1895) and was later used by the Astronomical Society of Edinburgh before becoming Collective art centre in 2018.

descriptions.name: City Observatory
descriptions.description: An astronomical observatory on Calton Hill in Edinburgh, Scotland, founded in 1776 and later home to the Edinburgh Astronomical Institution, serving as Scotland's first major research observatory until relocation in 1896.

descriptions.name: Ckoirama Observatory
descriptions.description: The first public professional observatory of Chile, located in the Atacama desert near Antofagasta, featuring a 0.6-meter primary telescope and 0.35-meter educational telescope, with the name meaning 'twilight' in the indigenous Kunza language.

descriptions.name: Class of 1951 Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1997 at Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, New York, funded by the Class of 1951, this modern observatory houses a 32-inch reflector (one of New York's two largest research telescopes) and multiple other instruments including a historic 8-inch refractor.

descriptions.name: Cloudcroft Observatory
descriptions.description: Established as a Space Object Identification research facility in the 1960s near Cloudcroft, New Mexico, featuring a 1.22-meter Newtonian telescope on an azimuth-elevation mount for astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Coats Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1883 in Paisley, Scotland, this is the oldest surviving public observatory in Scotland, featuring 10-inch and larger telescopes installed in 1898, currently undergoing renovation as part of the Paisley Museum Reimagined project.

descriptions.name: Coimbra University observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1799 as Portugal's first observatory and later combined with the Meteorological Observatory (founded 1864), the OGAUC continues operations from Alto de Santa Clara since 1951 with nearly 200 years of valuable observational records.

descriptions.name: Cointe Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1881-82 in Liège, Belgium by the University of Liège, this medieval revival structure features iconic red bricks and distinctive copper domes, housing the Institute of Astrophysics until 2002.

descriptions.name: Collins Observatory
descriptions.description: A historic 14-inch Cassegrain/Newtonian telescope observatory at Salem State University in Massachusetts, accessible via elevator, supporting astronomy education and public outreach programs.

descriptions.name: Colonial Observatory
descriptions.description: A historic astronomical facility in Williamsburg, Virginia; early colonial astronomy observations were made in the region, and the area features modern public observing through the Virginia Living Museum's Abbitt Planetarium and Observatory.

descriptions.name: Conrad Observatory
descriptions.description: Located on Trafelberg near Vienna at 1,146 meters, this underground geophysical observatory (opened 2002 for seismic work, 2014 for geomagnetic research) monitors Earth's seismic activity, gravity variations, and magnetic fields as part of international networks IRIS and INTERMAGNET.

descriptions.name: Corfu Observatory
descriptions.description: Located on Pelekas hill in Greece overlooking the Ionian Sea, this viewpoint sits at 270 meters altitude; the nearby Astronomical Society of Greece, founded in 1927, organizes public sky observations and educational programs.

descriptions.name: Cotobade Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Cerdedo-Cotobade, Galicia, Spain (founded 2011), this observatory on Monte Coirego features advanced telescopes and offers free guided tours on Saturdays as part of Galicia's astrotourism offerings.

descriptions.name: Crago Observatory
descriptions.description: This observatory serves as an astronomical facility, though specific details about its founding and equipment are limited in available documentation.

descriptions.name: Crawford Observatory
descriptions.description: A historic 19th-century observatory (completed 1880) on the University College Cork campus in Ireland, featuring three telescopes designed by Dublin instrument maker Howard Grubb and representing one of Europe's best-preserved observatories.

descriptions.name: Crimean Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1945 near Bakhchysarai in Crimea, this major observatory houses 17 optical telescopes including the 2.6-meter Shajn reflector (1961) and has discovered over 1,000 asteroids and multiple comets.

descriptions.name: Crohamhurst Observatory
descriptions.description: Constructed in 1935 in Queensland, Australia by Inigo Jones for solar and planetary observations, featuring three solar observation telescopes and meteorological equipment for long-range weather forecasting research.

descriptions.name: Crow Observatory
descriptions.description: A historic observatory at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri, housed in the Crow Hall of the Physics Department, supporting astronomical research and education.

descriptions.name: Custer Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1935, the Custer Institute & Observatory (located in Southold, New York, not South Dakota) features public observing programs and educational activities in night sky observation.

descriptions.name: Cégep de Trois-Rivières Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1980 in Champlain, Quebec, this observatory operates a 40-cm Newton telescope (automated since 2010) and received IAU code 924 for scientific value; announced closure in 2020 with planned replacement by a $11.3 million science museum.

descriptions.name: Côte d'Azur Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1879 in Nice, France by banker Raphaël Bischoffsheim with architect Charles Garnier designing the building and Gustave Eiffel creating the largest mobile dome in Europe, housing a 76-cm refracting telescope from 1886-87.

descriptions.name: Daejeon Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened May 3, 2001 as the first public observatory in South Korea's Daejeon region, featuring a refracting telescope with solar filters and a planetarium, attracting over 100,000 annual visitors with free admission.

descriptions.name: Daniel S. Schanck Observatory
descriptions.description: A historic observatory on the campus of Rutgers University in New Brunswick, New Jersey (cornerstone 1865), featuring a restored 150-mm equatorial refractor designed by Georges Prin of Paris.

descriptions.name: David Cole Observatory
descriptions.description: An educational observatory at Barnstable High School in Hyannis, Massachusetts, featuring a retractable roof, 14-inch Celestron telescope with CCD camera, and part of the Cobb Astro Park complex with gardens and sculptures.

descriptions.name: David Dunlap Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1935 in Richmond Hill, Ontario, Canada, and designated a national historic site in 2019, this facility houses Canada's largest optical telescope (1.88-meter reflector) and was where the first black hole evidence was identified in 1971.

descriptions.name: Dax Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1976 in southwestern France, this amateur observatory equipped with multiple reflectors and a planetarium achieved France's first CCD comet discovery (1997) and has discovered 5 asteroids.

descriptions.name: Dearborn Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1888 at Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois, this observatory features an 18.5-inch refracting telescope with original Alvan Clark lenses and offers free public viewing every Friday night.

descriptions.name: Detroit Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1854 at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor, one of the oldest observatories in the US, built through community fundraising and reopened in 2022 with new facilities as the Frankel Detroit Observatory.

descriptions.name: Devasthal Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 2,450 meters in Nainital, India, this facility hosts the 3.6-meter Devasthal Optical Telescope (India's largest, commissioned 2016) and the 4.0-meter International Liquid Mirror Telescope (Asia's largest liquid mirror telescope).

descriptions.name: Dominion Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: Completed in 1918 on Observatory Hill in Saanich, British Columbia, this national historic site operates the 1.8-meter Plaskett Telescope and 1.2-meter telescope, housing the Centre of the Universe visitor facility with a 25-seat planetarium.

descriptions.name: Dominion Observatory
descriptions.description: Constructed between 1902 and 1905 in Romanesque Revival style on Ottawa's Central Experimental Farm, this was Canada's first government observatory and served as the nation's official time source. Housing a 15-inch refracting telescope (the largest ever installed in Canada at the time), it conducted astronomical research, timekeeping, and seismology until 1970, and was designated a National Historic Site in 2025.

descriptions.name: Dominion Observatory
descriptions.description: Originally named Hector Observatory when built in 1907, this Edwardian Baroque facility in Wellington's Botanic Garden served as New Zealand's Government Time Service. Renamed Dominion Observatory in 1925, it became the center of seismology after the nearby Carter Observatory (1941) took over astronomical work, and the three observatories together were registered as a Historic Area in 1994.

descriptions.name: Dominion Radio Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1960 near Penticton, British Columbia, Canada, this radio astronomy facility at Kaleden hosts four radio telescopes including the 26-meter antenna and the Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME).

descriptions.name: Donausternwarte
descriptions.description: This observatory located along the Danube region serves as an astronomical facility for research and public outreach in the region.

descriptions.name: Dora Observatory
descriptions.description: A viewing platform on the South Korean side of the DMZ in Paju overlooking the Demilitarized Zone, with a new 3-story facility opened in 2024 featuring an amphitheater, café, and facilities.

descriptions.name: Dr. A.F. Philips Observatorium
descriptions.description: Located in Eindhoven, Netherlands, this observatory opened in 1937 with a 3.5-meter long telescope and is operated by volunteers for public viewing nights twice monthly from October through April.

descriptions.name: Dr. Neil Trivett Global Atmosphere Watch Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1986 in Alert, Nunavut, Canada (the world's northernmost site), this atmospheric monitoring facility was renamed in 2006 to honor Dr. Neil Trivett; it monitors greenhouse gases, aerosols, and atmospheric composition for climate research.

descriptions.name: Dr.-Remeis-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Founded in 1889 in Bamberg, Germany on Stephansberg hill, this observatory became part of the University of Erlangen-Nuremberg in 1962 and now employs 50+ researchers in astroparticle physics, neutrino research, and X-ray astronomy.

descriptions.name: Drebach Observatory
descriptions.description: A public observatory and planetarium in Drebach, Saxony, Germany featuring a 50-centimeter Cassegrain reflector telescope and a Zeiss Planetarium with 70 seats in the Ore Mountains.

descriptions.name: DSS 14
descriptions.description: Deep Space Station 14 at Goldstone in California is a 70-meter antenna, the largest DSN antenna, supporting NASA's interplanetary communications and conducting radio science and Goldstone Solar System Radar observations.

descriptions.name: Dudley Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1852 in Albany, New York, the Dudley Observatory is America's oldest non-academic astronomical research institution. It houses historic telescopes including the Olcott Meridian Circle and pioneered astronomical computing with the 1856 Scheutz difference engine.

descriptions.name: Dunsink Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1785 in Dublin, Ireland, Dunsink Observatory is the oldest scientific institution in Ireland and was home to mathematician William Rowan Hamilton's discovery of quaternions. Recently added to the UNESCO World Heritage Tentative List as part of Irish Historic Astronomical Observatories.

descriptions.name: Durham University Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1839 by Temple Chevallier at Durham University in England, the observatory made significant astronomical observations before transitioning to meteorological recording in 1937. It maintains the UK's third-longest continuous weather record dating back to 1843.

descriptions.name: Dwingeloo Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Completed in 1956 near Dwingeloo in the Netherlands, this 25-meter radio telescope was briefly the world's largest and mapped the Milky Way's spiral structure on the 21 cm hydrogen line. Restored by CAMRAS foundation, it became a Dutch industrial heritage monument in 2009.

descriptions.name: Dyer Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1953 and owned by Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tennessee, the Arthur J. Dyer Observatory offers summer camps, telescope nights, and public education programs. It is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and currently undergoing renovations.

descriptions.name: Düsseldorf-Bilk Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1843 by Johann Friedrich Benzenberg in Düsseldorf, Germany, the observatory featured a powerful refracting telescope and hosted astronomer C. Robert Luther, who discovered 24 asteroids there between 1852 and 1890. The facility was destroyed by bombing in 1943.

descriptions.name: Earlham College Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1861 at Earlham College in Richmond, Indiana, this historic observatory features a 6.5-inch objective lens telescope beneath a copper dome. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1975, it is one of the Midwest's most remarkable educational observatories.

descriptions.name: Ege University Observatory
