descriptions.description: Formally opened June 22, 1965, in Kurudağ near Izmir, Turkey, Ege University Observatory sits at 800 meters elevation and houses four research telescopes ranging from 30 to 48 cm in diameter for scientific and educational astronomy.

descriptions.name: Ehrensberg Observatory Traunstein
descriptions.description: Located in Traunstein, Bavaria, the Ehrensberg Observatory opened in 1913 at 605 meters elevation. The observatory offers free guided tours showcasing its history and technical equipment, with code designation 065 at the Minor Planet Center.

descriptions.name: Einstein Tower
descriptions.description: Built in 1924 by architect Erich Mendelsohn on Potsdam's Telegraphenberg, the expressionist Einstein Tower is a solar observatory designed to test Einstein's relativity theory. Fully restored and operational since September 2023, it conducts spectropolarimetric solar research.

descriptions.name: Elgin National Watch Company Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1910 for the Elgin National Watch Company in Illinois, this observatory provided scientifically accurate time data for precision watchmaking with state-of-the-art instruments. Donated to the school district in 1960, it became Illinois's first school planetarium in 1963.

descriptions.name: Elginfield Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1969 by the University of Western Ontario, Elginfield Observatory featured a 1.2-meter Ritchey-Chrétien telescope for spectroscopy and photometry. Though closed for astronomical research in 2010, the facility continues supporting meteor physics research with automated camera systems.

descriptions.name: Embry-Riddle Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Prescott, Arizona, the Embry-Riddle Observatory Complex is unique in combining both optical and radio telescopes at one site. It includes a new 20-inch Planewave telescope added in 2024 and serves undergraduate research and public outreach in astronomy.

descriptions.name: Engelhardt Observatory
descriptions.description: Completed in 1901 near Kazan, Russia, the Engelhardt Observatory is a UNESCO World Heritage Site featuring a 21-hectare astronomy park with 50,000 glass photographic plates. Now operated by Kazan Federal University primarily for educational purposes.

descriptions.name: Erbil Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1973 at 2,127 meters on Mount Korek in Iraqi Kurdistan, the Erbil Observatory was partially built with three telescopes but suffered severe damage during the Iran-Iraq War. Currently closed, it requires $35-40 million in restoration to become a major Middle Eastern astronomy hub.

descriptions.name: Eschenberg Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1979 by the Astronomical Society of Winterthur in Switzerland with volunteer labor and modest funding, Eschenberg Observatory has provided over 22,000 high-precision asteroid and comet measurements to the Minor Planet Center. It sits at 542 meters in a remote forest south of Winterthur.

descriptions.name: Eskdalemuir Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1904 in Dumfries and Galloway, Scotland, Eskdalemuir Observatory relocated magnetic instruments from Kew to escape electromagnetic interference. With continuous meteorological records since 1908 and WMO Centennial status since 2019, it is a key environmental monitoring station.

descriptions.name: Estació sísmica de Garraf
descriptions.description: The Garraf seismic station (CGAR) near Barcelona operates as part of Catalonia's seismic network managed by the Institut Cartogràfic i Geològic de Catalunya. The station sits on bedrock with high seismic velocity, making it suitable for earthquake monitoring and research.

descriptions.name: Eta Carinae observatory
descriptions.description: Multiple observatories in Chile including SOAR and Gemini South have observed the Eta Carinae binary star system. The Very Large Telescope Interferometer and ESO's Paranal Observatory have obtained highly detailed images of this explosive stellar system.

descriptions.name: Etelman Observatory
descriptions.description: Located on St. Thomas in the U.S. Virgin Islands, Etelman Observatory houses the Virgin Islands Robotic Telescope, a fully automated 0.5-meter research-grade Cassegrain telescope directed by the University of the Virgin Islands for robotic astronomy.

descriptions.name: European Space Astronomy Centre
descriptions.description: Located 30 km west of Madrid in Spain, the European Space Astronomy Centre is ESA's lead research facility for space science and astronomy. It hosts science operations centers for over 15 ESA missions and employs 350+ scientists and engineers from all ESA Member States.

descriptions.name: Evpatoria Observatory
descriptions.description: Operated by the Center for Deep Space Communications in Yevpatoria, Crimea, this facility features a massive 70-meter radio telescope antenna designed for planetary radar and communication with deep space missions. It has been used for asteroid studies and deep space contact attempts.

descriptions.name: Fabra Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1904 on Tibidabo Mountain in Barcelona and listed as one of the world's fourth oldest still-operating observatories, Fabra Observatory features a 38-cm refractor telescope built by Mailhat, Paris. Its focus includes asteroid and comet observations, with public guided tours available.

descriptions.name: Fabra observatory
descriptions.description: Also known as Observatori Fabra, this is the Barcelona-based observatory established in 1904 that conducts asteroid, comet, meteorology, and seismology research. It features the historic double refractor with large objective lenses and hosts educational programs for visitors.

descriptions.name: Farm Cove Observatory
descriptions.description: Farm Cove Observatory in Pakuranga, Auckland, New Zealand was an amateur observatory built in 2000 featuring a 14-inch Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope. It achieved notable results including the discovery of main-belt asteroid 386622 New Zealand in September 2009.

descriptions.name: Federal Observatory
descriptions.description: Federal Observatory references various historic institutions across different countries established for astronomical and meteorological observations, serving important scientific and timekeeping functions for their respective nations.

descriptions.name: Ferdinando Caliumi astronomic observatory
descriptions.description: Located on Mount Armidda in Gairo, Sardinia, Italy, the Ferdinando Caliumi Astronomical Observatory has operated since 1989 under the Ogliastrina Astronomy Association. Its isolated location provides some of Europe's darkest skies and attracts astronomers from across Italy.

descriptions.name: Fernbank Observatory
descriptions.description: Located between Decatur and Atlanta, Georgia, Fernbank Observatory houses a 0.9-meter (36-inch) Cassegrain reflector beneath a 10-meter dome—the largest telescope in the southeastern United States dedicated to public viewing. It offers free public observations Thursday and Friday evenings.

descriptions.name: Foothill Observatory
descriptions.description: Operated by the Peninsula Astronomical Society and Foothill College in Los Altos Hills, California, Foothill Observatory features a 16-inch computer-controlled Schmidt-Cassegrain reflector and a hydrogen-alpha solar telescope. It offers free public viewing Friday nights and Saturday mornings.

descriptions.name: Forcarei Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened March 13, 2009, in Galicia, Spain, Forcarei Astronomical Observatory sits at 670 meters with a 50-cm reflector telescope equipped with advanced CCD cameras. It is operated by the Sky, Science and Culture Foundation for scientific research and public education.

descriptions.name: former Nižbor observatory
descriptions.description: The former Nižbor observatory in Czech Republic represents historical astronomical observation efforts in the region, contributing to Czech astronomical heritage.

descriptions.name: former observatory of Brussels
descriptions.description: The former observatory in Brussels, Belgium was established in 1826 by King William I of the Netherlands under mathematician Adolphe Quetelet's direction. Originally located in Saint-Josse-ten-Noode, it relocated to Uccle in 1890 and continues as the Royal Observatory of Belgium.

descriptions.name: Fountain Hills Observatory
descriptions.description: The International Dark Sky Discovery Center opening in summer 2026 in Fountain Hills, Arizona features a 27.5-inch PlaneWave CDK700 telescope with advanced astrophotography cameras housed in a 20.5-foot dome. The $25 million facility will also include a 65-seat planetarium and interactive exhibits.

descriptions.name: Frankfurt observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1908 in Frankfurt, Germany, the Sternwarte Frankfurt features a 21-cm refracting telescope with historic optics by Max Pauly and a specialized solar observation refractor. Operated by the Physikalischer Verein, one of Germany's oldest scientific associations founded in 1824.

descriptions.name: Franz-Kroller-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Located in Traiskirchen, Austria, the Franz-Kroller-Sternwarte is the oldest observatory in Lower Austria. It offers free guided solar tours on the first Sunday monthly and evening observing sessions every Monday for viewing planets, nebulae, and star clusters.

descriptions.name: François-Xavier Bagnoud Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1995 at 2,200 meters in Saint-Luc, Valais, Switzerland, the François-Xavier Bagnoud Observatory features 60cm and 15cm telescopes and contributed to the 2007 discovery of exoplanet Gliese 436b. It remains one of Switzerland's rare public professional observatories.

descriptions.name: Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1966 on Mount Hopkins in southern Arizona, the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory is the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory's largest satellite facility. It houses multiple telescopes including the 6.5-meter MMT and VERITAS gamma-ray observatory for diverse astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Frei Rosário Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Caeté, Minas Gerais, Brazil, at 1,751 meters elevation, the Frei Rosário Astronomical Observatory is operated by the Federal University of Minas Gerais and features a 60cm telescope. It opens to the public on the first Saturday of each month.

descriptions.name: Fremont Peak Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1986 near San Juan Bautista, California, Fremont Peak Observatory features a 30-inch Newtonian telescope called Challenger on an English equatorial mount. Operated by volunteers, it offers public viewing Saturday nights April-October and solar viewing programs monthly.

descriptions.name: Fritz-Weithas-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Located at 595 meters on Mariahilfberg near Neumarkt in Bavaria, Germany, the Fritz-Weithas-Sternwarte observatory opened in 1913 and was renamed in 2007 after its founder. It offers guided star tours almost every Friday evening when weather permits.

descriptions.name: Fuertes Observatory
descriptions.description: Built between 1916-1917 at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York, Fuertes Observatory houses a 12-inch refracting telescope with optics ground in 1920. The Cornell Astronomical Society conducts public viewing every Friday night during the academic year from 8 PM to midnight.

descriptions.name: Félix Aguilar Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1953 at El Leoncito in San Juan Province, Argentina at 2,400 meters elevation, the Félix Aguilar Observatory features a double astrograph with dual 20-inch lenses. It was renamed Carlos Ulrico Cesco Astronomical Station in 1974 and is operated by the National University of San Juan.

descriptions.name: G.V. Schiaparelli Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 1,230 meters on Campo dei Fiori in Varese, Italy, the G.V. Schiaparelli Observatory was founded in 1956 by volunteers. It houses one of Europe's largest amateur telescopes, an 84cm reflector, and is an international center for stellar spectroscopy and asteroid monitoring.

descriptions.name: Gahberg Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 860 meters near Weyregg am Attersee in Upper Austria, Gahberg Observatory was established by the Astronomischer Arbeitskreis Salzkammergut. It offers guided tours and operates various telescopes for night sky photography and viewing by reservation.

descriptions.name: Gaithersburg Latitude Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1899 in Gaithersburg, Maryland as part of six International Latitude Observatories to measure Earth's polar wobble, this National Historic Landmark was taken out of service in 1982. GPS systems using survey markers installed on the grounds make periodic course corrections today.

descriptions.name: Galbergweg 12
descriptions.description: Galbergweg 12 represents a historical observatory location designation in the astronomical community.

descriptions.name: Galileum Solingen
descriptions.description: Opened July 5, 2019, in Solingen, North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany, Galileum Solingen is the world's first planetarium built inside a decommissioned spherical gas container. It features an observatory with advanced telescopes and a 12-meter dome with GOTO Chronos II projector.

descriptions.name: Gaocheng Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1279 by Guo Shoujing during China's Yuan Dynasty near Dengfeng, the Gaocheng Astronomical Observatory is China's oldest of 27 ancient observatories. A UNESCO World Heritage site since 2010, it features a 28-foot high brick and stone platform with a Chinese sundial.

descriptions.name: Garden observatory of Siegfried Gebhard
descriptions.description: The Garden observatory of Siegfried Gebhard represents a private observational installation contributing to amateur astronomical observations in the region.

descriptions.name: Gauribidanur Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Located 100 km north of Bengaluru, India, the Gauribidanur Radio Observatory has operated since 1976 under the Raman Research Institute and Indian Institute of Astrophysics. It features a 1000-dipole array monitoring the sun and pulsars in radio frequencies, and conducts all-sky surveys.

descriptions.name: Gekko Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan, Gekko Observatory was founded in 1957 and features a 50cm astronomical telescope and 20cm solar telescope. Between 1987 and 2000, astronomers Yoshiaki Oshima and Tetsuo Kagawa discovered 172 minor planets at this site, ranking it 40th worldwide for asteroid discoveries by 2000.

descriptions.name: Gelber Turm
descriptions.description: The Gelber Turm (Yellow Tower) in Hildesheim, Germany was originally built in 1886 as a viewing tower and later transformed into an observatory. It houses a large reflector telescope with a 4.80-meter focal length featuring two mirrors and a computerized mounting system, open to the public for stargazing.

descriptions.name: Gemini North
descriptions.description: Gemini North, located on Hawaii's Mauna Kea, achieved first light in 1999 and began scientific operations in 2000. This 8.1-metre telescope is one of two twin Gemini observatories equipped with instruments like GMOS for visible-wavelength observations.

descriptions.name: Gemini Observatory
descriptions.description: Home to Gemini South, one of twin 8.1-meter telescopes operated by an international partnership led by the U.S. National Science Foundation, this facility achieved first light in January 2002 atop Cerro Pachón at 2,722 meters elevation. The exceptionally dry and stable atmosphere makes it ideal for optical and infrared observations, and it shares the mountaintop with SOAR and the Vera C. Rubin Observatory.

descriptions.name: Gemini Observatory
descriptions.description: The Frederick C. Gillett Gemini Telescope (Gemini North) sits near the summit of Mauna Kea at 4,213 meters, operating one of twin 8.1-meter telescopes with silver-coated mirrors optimized for infrared astronomy. Part of an international collaboration including the U.S., Canada, Chile, Brazil, Argentina, and South Korea, it features advanced adaptive optics and laser guide star systems and is often operated fully remotely from base facilities.

descriptions.name: Gemini South
descriptions.description: Gemini South, one of two 8.1-metre Gemini telescopes, is situated at high altitude in Chile's Andes mountains and began operations in 2000. Equipped with state-of-the-art instruments, it conducts visible and infrared observations as part of the International Gemini Observatory partnership.

descriptions.name: Georgetown University Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Georgetown University Astronomical Observatory, founded in 1841 by Father James Curley and completed in 1844, is the third oldest observatory in the United States. It housed a 12-inch equatorial telescope and played a key role in 19th-century astronomical research on variable stars and determining Washington DC's precise longitude.

descriptions.name: Georgia College Observatory
descriptions.description: Georgia College's Pohl Observatory houses a 24-inch Corrected Dall-Kirkham Astrograph telescope with f/6.8 focal ratio manufactured by Planewave Instruments. Located on the fourth floor of Herty Hall, it offers public observation nights monthly in conjunction with the full-dome planetarium.

descriptions.name: Georgian National Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Georgian National Astrophysical Observatory was founded in 1932 by Academician Evgeni Kharadze on Mount Kanobili and was the first high-altitude astrophysical observatory in the Soviet Union. Its research focuses on galaxies, stars, solar physics, and the solar system, equipped with both historic telescopes from the 1930s-1940s and modern instruments.

descriptions.name: Geospatial Information Authority of Japan
descriptions.description: The Geospatial Information Authority of Japan operates geodetic observatories and satellites stations, including the Mizusawa Geodetic Observatory and Esashi Station with magnetotelluric monitoring systems. Since 1949, the GSI has conducted continuous geomagnetic surveys and observations to map Japan's geomagnetic field variations.

descriptions.name: Gifford Observatory
descriptions.description: Gifford Observatory is a private astronomical observatory located in Mount Victoria, Wellington, New Zealand. It serves amateur astronomers and provides public stargazing opportunities in the Mount Victoria area.

descriptions.name: Girawali Observatory
descriptions.description: The IUCAA Girawali Observatory, located 80 km from Pune, India, features a 2-metre telescope with primary mirror of 200 cm and f/3 focal ratio. The observatory uniquely sets aside observing time for training and observations from Indian Universities, available during October to May in two four-month proposal cycles.

descriptions.name: Givatayim Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1968 by the Israeli Astronomical Association and Givatayim municipality, Givatayim Observatory is Israel's oldest and most active public observatory. Located atop a hill in a public park with a 16-inch Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope, it hosts regular public lectures and observations, though severely impacted by light pollution from nearby illuminated skyscrapers.

descriptions.name: Glashütte Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1910 in Glashütte, Germany, this observatory was later transformed into a chronometer certification center by the Wempe family in the 1930s. Today it is the only place in Germany for testing chronometers and certifies watches according to the German standard DIN 8319 for precision and reliability.

descriptions.name: Glen D. Riley Observatory
descriptions.description: The Glen D. Riley Observatory is an amateur astronomy facility operated by the Naperville Astronomical Association in Naperville, Illinois, founded in 1973. It houses a 16-inch Newtonian reflecting telescope and hosts free public observation nights year-round.

descriptions.name: GNS Science
descriptions.description: GNS Science operates New Zealand's geomagnetic observatories at Eyrewell and Scott Base in Antarctica, providing continuous magnetic field data from the Southern Hemisphere. As the designated International Civil Aviation Organization volcano observatory for New Zealand, it monitors volcanoes, earthquakes, and geological hazards through its GeoNet programme.

descriptions.name: Godlee Observatory
descriptions.description: Godlee Observatory is located on the roof of the University of Manchester's historic Sackville Street Building and was completed in 1902. It houses original Grubb telescopes and features one of only two papier-mâché domes surviving in the UK, though currently closed for university redevelopment.

descriptions.name: Goethe Link Observatory
descriptions.description: Built between 1937 and 1939 by Dr. Goethe Link, this observatory near Brooklyn, Indiana houses a 36-inch reflecting telescope on a 200-ton concrete pier. Donated to Indiana University in 1948, it is now operated by the Indiana Astronomical Society and offers monthly public viewing through the historic telescope.

descriptions.name: Golden Ears Observatory
descriptions.description: The Golden Ears Observatory is a privately-owned facility in Maple Ridge, British Columbia dedicated to asteroid detection and variable star research. It operates as a signatory of the International Asteroid Warning Network, employing a 14-inch wide-field Cassegrain telescope and a 10-inch Ritchey-Chrétien telescope for monitoring potentially hazardous asteroids.

descriptions.name: Goldendale Observatory State Park
descriptions.description: Dedicated in 1973 and situated on a 2,100-foot hill, Goldendale Observatory State Park features one of the nation's largest public telescopes with 20-foot and 10-foot diameter domes. The facility offers free admission (with parking pass) and provides visitor center and program access by reservation.

descriptions.name: Goodsell Observatory
descriptions.description: Goodsell Observatory at Carleton College in Northfield, Minnesota, constructed in 1887, was at the time the largest observatory in Minnesota and 12th largest in the world. It houses three historic telescopes including a 16.2-inch John Brashear refractor and is used for both classes and monthly public open houses.

descriptions.name: Gornergrat Kulm Hotel
descriptions.description: The Gornergrat Kulm Hotel sits at 3,120 metres above sea level in the Swiss Alps near Zermatt, with observatories housed in domes on both towers. It offers a unique 'Dining with the Stars' experience featuring astronomy lectures, stargazing with telescopes, and views of the Matterhorn and surrounding peaks.

descriptions.name: Gotha Observatory
descriptions.description: Originally established as the Seeberg Observatory on Seeberg hill near Gotha, Germany, this institution played a pivotal role in astronomical history by organizing the first international astronomical congress in 1798. Founded by director Peter Andreas Hansen, it was dedicated to astrometry, geodetics, and timekeeping until 1934.

descriptions.name: Grainger Observatory
descriptions.description: The Grainger Sky Theater at the Adler Planetarium, which opened in May 2011, was the most technologically advanced dome theater in the world at the time. It functions as a virtual observatory providing immersive astronomy education to the public.

descriptions.name: Graz-Lustbühel satellite station
descriptions.description: The Graz-Lustbühel satellite station is Austria's fundamental station for cosmic and satellite geodesy, located near Graz in Styria. Officially established in 1976 and continuously measuring since 1982, it was the first in the world to break the 1-centimeter accuracy barrier in Satellite Laser Ranging.

descriptions.name: Green Bank Observatory
descriptions.description: The Green Bank Observatory operates the Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope, the world's largest fully steerable radio telescope standing 485 feet tall. Located in West Virginia's National Radio Quiet Zone established in 1956, it is now an independent institution providing free admission to its Science Center and hands-on exhibits.

descriptions.name: Green Point Observatory
descriptions.description: Green Point Observatory is a private astronomical observatory in Oyster Bay, Sydney, Australia, operated by the Sutherland Astronomical Society. It features a 41cm Newtonian telescope and a 35cm Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope, hosting annual public star parties and school/community group bookings.

descriptions.name: Greenhill Observatory
descriptions.description: Greenhill Observatory at the University of Tasmania, located on Bisdee Tier near Hobart, was officially opened in February 2013. It houses a 1.3-metre telescope and includes a 7.3m-tall spacecraft communication antenna installed in 2023 for Earth-space science research.

descriptions.name: Griffith Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened to the public on May 14, 1935, Griffith Observatory is located on Mount Hollywood in Los Angeles's Griffith Park. After a $93 million renovation that reopened it in 2006, it features a 75-foot planetarium dome, free admission, and daily public telescope observing and live demonstrations.

descriptions.name: Gunma Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Prefectural Gunma Observatory was established in 1999 in Nakayama, Takayama Village, and is Japan's most-visited night observation facility. It features a 150cm reflector telescope and was designed by renowned architect Arata Isozaki at 900 meters elevation in the 'Village of Beautiful Starry Skies'.

descriptions.name: Göttingen Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1751, Göttingen Observatory is one of the oldest observatories in the German-speaking world and was rebuilt between 1803-1816 with state-of-the-art architecture. Carl Friedrich Gauss served as its first director from 1815-1855 and helped establish it as a leading astronomical institution.

descriptions.name: Haggart Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at Clackamas Community College's Environmental Learning Center on the Oregon City campus, Haggart Observatory opened in 1989. Named after telescope builder Harold Haggart, it features a handcrafted 24-inch Newtonian reflector in a 1948-built dome and offers public viewing through partnership with Rose City Astronomers.

descriptions.name: Hakin Observatory
descriptions.description: Hakin Observatory is a ruined Grade One Listed astronomical observatory and training college built at the end of the 18th century in Milford Haven, Wales. Although the octagonal observatory was completed with scientific instruments, Charles Greville's original vision for a mathematical college never materialized after his death in 1809.

descriptions.name: Haldde observatory
descriptions.description: Built on Mount Haldde in Alta, Norway at 900 metres elevation, the Haldde Observatory became the world's first Northern Lights observatory in 1899 through Kristian Birkeland's initiative. Decommissioned in 1926, it served as a stable workplace for leading geophysics researchers and was designated a historic site by the European Physical Society in 2018.

descriptions.name: Hale Solar Laboratory
descriptions.description: Built in 1923-1925 in Pasadena, California, the Hale Solar Laboratory was where astronomer George Ellery Hale refined the spectrohelioscope for detailed solar observations. Designated a National Historic Landmark in 1989, it continued supporting important solar research including the development of magnetometry by Harold and Horace Babcock.

descriptions.name: Haleakalā Observatory
descriptions.description: The Haleakalā High Altitude Observatory near Maui's volcanic summit sits above one-third of Earth's troposphere at 3,050 metres elevation and was established in 1958. Dubbed 'Science City', the 18-acre facility operates multiple telescopes including the world's largest solar telescope, the NSF's Inouye Solar Telescope with a 4-metre-class mirror.

descriptions.name: Halley observatory
descriptions.description: Halley Research Station, a British Antarctic Survey facility on the Brunt Ice Shelf, was established in 1956 and became famous for the discovery of the ozone hole in 1985. The current Halley VI station, opened in 2013, is the world's first fully relocatable terrestrial research station and provides atmospheric and chemical composition monitoring.

descriptions.name: Hamamatsu City Observatory
descriptions.description: The Hamamatsu City Observatory is located on the 45th floor of ACT City Tower in central Hamamatsu, Japan at 185 metres elevation. Designed to resemble a harmonica reflecting the city's musical heritage, it offers sweeping panoramic views of the city, surrounding sea, and on clear days, Mount Fuji.

descriptions.name: Hamburg-Bergedorf Observatory
descriptions.description: Hamburg Observatory (Hamburger Sternwarte) was founded in 1825 and relocated to Bergedorf in 1912 due to light pollution, where it remains operated by the University of Hamburg. It houses historic instruments including a 60cm Great Refractor and a 1-metre reflector, and contains a library of approximately 70,000 astronomy and astrophysics books.

descriptions.name: Hamilton Astronomical Society Observatory
descriptions.description: The RASC Hamilton Observatory was established in 1974 by the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada's Hamilton Centre. Based in Ontario, it provides exclusive member access to advanced telescopes and observational equipment for studying stars, planets, and deep-sky objects.

descriptions.name: Hampstead Observatory
descriptions.description: Hampstead Observatory, operated by the Hampstead Scientific Society in London, features a historic 6-inch Cooke refracting telescope presented to the Society in 1923. Located atop a covered underground reservoir at one of London's highest points, it is open to the public Friday and Saturday nights during the autumn and winter observing season.

descriptions.name: Hanging Rock Raptor Observatory
descriptions.description: The Hanging Rock Raptor Observatory, built on an old fire tower atop Peters Mountain in Monroe County, West Virginia, is one of the oldest hawk watch points in the eastern United States. Since 1952, it has served as a critical site for tracking raptor migrations and contributing to global ornithological research.

descriptions.name: Hankasalmi Observatory
descriptions.description: Hankasalmi Observatory in Finland is a remote-controlled astronomical facility operated by astronomy club Jyväskylän Sirius ry featuring a 40cm Ritchey-Chrétien telescope and 3-metre radio telescope. Located in dark countryside ideal for Northern Lights research, it is the site of the world's first observation station studying the sounds of auroras.

descriptions.name: Hans-Ludwig-Neumann-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: The Hans-Ludwig-Neumann-Sternwarte, opened in 1998 on Kleiner Feldberg in the Taunus mountains near Glashütten, Germany, operates two Cassegrain telescopes (24-inch and 12.5-inch). It provides ideal conditions for amateur astronomical research, astrophotography, and has observers who regularly discover minor planets.

descriptions.name: Hans-Nüchter-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: The Hans-Nüchter-Sternwarte is a public and school observatory in Fulda, Germany, built in 1971 and officially inaugurated in 1977. Located on the roof of the Freiherr-vom-Stein-Gymnasium, it features a 30cm Newtonian reflector convertible to a Cassegrain telescope and houses a digital planetarium with a 4-metre dome.

descriptions.name: Harestua Solar Observatory
descriptions.description: Located 45 kilometres north of Oslo, Harestua Solar Observatory was used for solar research from 1954-1986 and has served as an astronomy education centre since 1987. Snøhetta's modern design added a 1,500 m² planetarium and interstellar cabins in 2008, making it Northern Europe's largest solar observatory facility.

descriptions.name: Harquahala Peak Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1920 by the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory on Harquahala Peak, Arizona at 5,680 feet elevation, this adobe structure measured solar radiation using pyrheliometers and a theodolite. Operational from 1920-1925, it was abandoned due to extreme weather and difficult access, and today is stabilized but closed to visitors.

descriptions.name: Hartebeesthoek Radio Astronomy Observatory
descriptions.description: The Hartebeesthoek Radio Astronomy Observatory (HartRAO), originally built as NASA's Deep Space Station 51 in 1961, was transferred to South Africa in 1975. Operating a 26-metre, 260-ton radio telescope, it conducts research in radio astronomy and space geodesy with receivers covering 18cm to 1.3cm wavelengths.

descriptions.name: Hartung–Boothroyd Observatory
descriptions.description: The Hartung-Boothroyd Observatory at Cornell University near Ithaca, New York uses a 0.6-metre mirror created as a test pouring for the Palomar Observatory's historic 200-inch telescope. Completed in 1974 and primarily used for upper-level undergraduate astronomy teaching, it was designed and directed by James R. Houck from 1974-2012.

descriptions.name: Harvard College Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1839, Harvard College Observatory is home to the Department of Astronomy at Harvard University and made the first daguerreotype of a star (Vega) in 1850. It hosts monthly Public Observatory Nights and was historically significant for breakthrough stellar classification research by pioneering female astronomers including Annie Jump Cannon and Henrietta Leavitt.

descriptions.name: Harvard Observatory, Arequipa
descriptions.description: Founded in 1888 as the Boyden Station by Harvard College Observatory near Arequipa, Peru at 8,000 feet elevation, this Southern Hemisphere observatory played a crucial role in astronomical research including Henrietta Leavitt's groundbreaking work on Cepheid variable stars. The station operated until 1927 when it was relocated to South Africa, leaving behind an important legacy in photographic surveys of the southern sky.

descriptions.name: Harvard–Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
descriptions.description: Established in 1973 as a collaborative partnership between the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory and Harvard College Observatory, the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Massachusetts is one of the world's leading astronomy research institutions. It fosters innovation and discovery through coordinated research activities across multiple observatories and research programs.

descriptions.name: Hat Creek Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in the late 1950s by UC Berkeley's Radio Astronomy Laboratory, Hat Creek Radio Observatory in northern California operates at 986 meters elevation. The facility is home to the Allen Telescope Array and hosts various radio astronomy instruments used for SETI research and cosmic observations, with public tours available Thursday-Friday.

descriptions.name: Haterumajima Astronomical Observatory Tower
descriptions.description: Located on Hateruma Island, Japan's southernmost inhabited island, this astronomical observatory features a three-story building with an opening dome, a 200mm refraction telescope, and a planetarium. The facility offers stargazing sessions where visitors can observe the Southern Cross from December to mid-June and operates public viewing programs.

descriptions.name: Haute-Provence Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1937 in southeastern France near Saint-Michel, Haute-Provence Observatory made history in 1995 when its telescopes helped discover the first exoplanet orbiting a main-sequence star (51 Pegasi b), a discovery that earned Michel Mayor and Didier Queloz the 2019 Nobel Prize in Physics. The observatory operates multiple telescopes including the notable 1.93-meter instrument and remains an active research facility.

descriptions.name: Haynald Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1878 by Cardinal Haynald at Kalocsa, Hungary, this observatory conducted solar, meteorological, and educational research using a 7-inch Merz-Browning refractor. It became particularly notable under director Gyula Fényi, who made over 6,000 drawings of the Sun from 1880 to 1919, providing invaluable records of solar activity.

descriptions.name: Haystack Observatory
descriptions.description: MIT's Haystack Observatory in Westford, Massachusetts is an interdisciplinary research center established to lead in radio astronomy, geodesy, and geospace studies. The facility features the 37-meter Haystack Radio Telescope completed in 1964 within a protective radome, along with advanced incoherent scatter radars for studying Earth's upper atmosphere.

descriptions.name: Heidelberg-Königstuhl State Observatory
descriptions.description: Inaugurated on June 20, 1898, the Heidelberg-Königstuhl State Observatory in Germany was one of Europe's first mountain observatories after Nice Observatory. It was directed by Max Wolf, who discovered nearly 400 asteroids from the site between 1912 and 1957, and remains an active research facility operated by the University of Heidelberg's Center for Astronomy.

descriptions.name: Heinz-Reinhardt-Sternwarte St. Ottilien
descriptions.description: Built at the Archabbey St. Ottilien near Munich, Germany, this observatory serves the local school and community with high-quality telescopes and astronomy education programs. Operating on a voluntary basis since 2014, it offers nighttime viewing sessions and educational courses for astronomy enthusiasts of all levels.

descriptions.name: Heliometer building, Old Observatory, Leiden
descriptions.description: Built in 1878, the Heliometer Tower at Leiden's Old Observatory was designed by architect Pierre Cuypers and houses a 48-cm Zunderman Reflector with a fork mounting. The tower was designed for stellar photometry observations, and the surrounding 1860 observatory building now functions as a visitor center after extensive restoration completed in 2012.

descriptions.name: Hellendoorn Public Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 2013 by Dutch astronaut André Kuipers, the Hellendoorn Public Observatory in Nijverdal, Netherlands features an enormous dome with multiple telescopes, a sun-observatory, observation platform, and radio telescope. The facility has been nicknamed the 'Theatre of the Cosmos' and offers both public viewing events and interactive planetarium experiences.

descriptions.name: Helmrich-Lambrecht-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Built in 1961 at St. Kanzian/Klopeiner See in Austria, the Helmrich-Lambrecht-Sternwarte was constructed by Helmrich Lambrecht on his residential house roof with a 3.2-meter diameter dome. The observatory houses Dobsonian telescopes and binocular mounts for amateur astronomical observation and research.

descriptions.name: Helsinki University Observatory
descriptions.description: Designed in 1834 by Friedrich Wilhelm Argelander and architect Carl Ludvig Engel, Helsinki University Observatory was the first to implement an innovative east-west structure with domes along its length to prevent viewing obstruction. It influenced the design of many European observatories and now functions as the Helsinki University Museum's astronomy visitor center since 2012.

descriptions.name: Hereford Arizona Observatory
descriptions.description: Operating at 1,423 meters elevation near the Arizona-Mexico border, Hereford Arizona Observatory is owned and operated by amateur astronomer Bruce L. Gary. The facility houses two separate observatory installations with an 11-inch Schmidt-Cassegrain and a 16-inch Ritchey-Chrétien telescope for observational studies of unusual stellar phenomena.

descriptions.name: Herstmonceux Science Centre
descriptions.description: Located at Herstmonceux Castle in East Sussex, this science centre was the former home of the Royal Greenwich Observatory from 1957 until 1988. Today it features over 100 hands-on science exhibits among the historic domes and telescopes, offering an interactive blend of astronomy history and modern science discovery.

descriptions.name: Higginson Tower
descriptions.description: Located in Vankleek Hill, Ontario, Canada, the Higginson Tower was originally built around 1830 as a windmill for grain grinding. After the windmill proved unsuccessful, it was transformed into Canada's first private observatory in Eastern Ontario and now serves as a heritage site with interpretive programs and guided tours.

descriptions.name: High Altitude Water Cherenkov Experiment
descriptions.description: Located at 4,100 meters on the Sierra Negra volcano in Puebla, Mexico, HAWC is a gamma-ray and cosmic ray observatory completed in 2015. The facility consists of 300 water Cherenkov detectors used to study cosmic rays, gamma-ray sources, and high-energy physics, achieving numerous groundbreaking detections including TeV gamma rays from the sun.

descriptions.name: High Energy Stereoscopic System
descriptions.description: Operating since 2002 in the Khomas Region of Namibia, H.E.S.S. is a system of five imaging atmospheric Cherenkov telescopes for studying gamma-ray emission. The facility was upgraded in 2012 with a 28-meter central telescope—the largest Cherenkov telescope ever built—capable of detecting gamma-rays down to 30 GeV energies.

descriptions.name: High School, Academy Road, Stirling
descriptions.description: This Scottish educational observatory at Academy Road in Stirling served the local high school community for astronomy education and public outreach programs during the 20th century.

descriptions.name: Hoher List Observatory
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in 1954 on the Hoher List mountain 60 kilometers southwest of Bonn, Germany, this observatory was established to escape urban light pollution. The facility hosted important astrometric and photometric research until its closure in 2012, after which a local society established the observatory as a heritage site with public tours.

descriptions.name: Holcomb Observatory and Planetarium
descriptions.description: Located on the north end of Butler University's Indianapolis campus, Holcomb Observatory houses a 38-inch Cassegrain reflector alongside smaller telescopes and a state-of-the-art fulldome digital planetarium. Built in 1954 and recently upgraded with advanced laser-phosphor projection technology, it serves as one of the largest public observatories in the world.

descriptions.name: Holden Observatory
descriptions.description: Holden Observatory at Syracuse University, built in 1887, is the second-oldest building on campus and named after Charles Demerest Holden. Though initially named after Edward S. Holden, the first director of Lick Observatory, it represents an important part of Syracuse's scientific heritage.

descriptions.name: Hong Kong Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1883 in Tsim Sha Tsui, Kowloon, the Hong Kong Observatory has served for over 140 years as the government's primary center for weather monitoring, forecasting, and radiation assessment. The Observatory pioneered the world's first location-specific rainfall nowcast service and developed the widely-downloaded MyObservatory mobile application.

descriptions.name: Hong Kong Space Museum
descriptions.description: Opened on October 8, 1980, the Hong Kong Space Museum features a distinctive hemispherical dome housing a planetarium with 100+ interactive exhibits on the Solar System, cosmology, and spaceflight. The museum housed the world's first computerized planetarium and boasts one of the largest OMNIMAX screens in the Eastern Hemisphere.

descriptions.name: Hoober Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Hoober Observatory is owned and operated by the Mexborough & Swinton Astronomical Society. Built by members between 1991 and 1993, it features a 16-foot-diameter dome housing multiple telescopes including a 130mm refractor and 14-inch Schmidt-Cassegrain, with public access during designated observing nights.

descriptions.name: Hooker Telescope
descriptions.description: The Hooker Telescope, a 100-inch (2.5-meter) reflector completed in 1917 at Mount Wilson Observatory, was the world's largest telescope for 32 years. Funded by industrialist John D. Hooker, it enabled Edwin Hubble's landmark discoveries about galactic distances and the expanding universe before being deactivated in 1989 and restarted in 1992.

descriptions.name: Hopkins Observatory
descriptions.description: The oldest extant observatory in the United States, Hopkins Observatory at Williams College in Williamstown, Massachusetts was built between 1836 and 1838 by students under Prof. Albert Hopkins. It houses historic telescopes including an 1852 7-inch refractor by Alvan Clark and a modern 24-inch reflector for astronomical research and education.

descriptions.name: Hoshi no Mura Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Tamura, Fukushima Prefecture, Japan, Hoshi no Mura Observatory features a 65-centimeter reflector—the largest telescope in Fukushima—plus a planetarium and stargazing facilities. Set beneath the clear Abukuma Kogen skies renowned for stargazing, the observatory offers special observing experiences and night sky photography sessions.

descriptions.name: Hradec Králové Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1961, the Hradec Králové Observatory in the Czech Republic combines an astronomical observatory with a digital planetarium. The facility features a circular hall with a hemispherical projection screen and hosts interactive exhibitions on physics and astronomy alongside regular sky observation programs and solar studies.

descriptions.name: Hume Cronyn Memorial Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened on October 25, 1940, on the University of Western Ontario campus in London, Canada, the Hume Cronyn Memorial Observatory was funded by Frances Cronyn in memory of her late husband. The stone building houses both optical telescopes and serves as an educational facility with regular Saturday public nights throughout the year.

descriptions.name: Höfingen observatory
descriptions.description: The Höfingen Observatory at the western edge of Stuttgart, Germany is maintained by the local Höfingen cultural association and features a 16-inch Ritchey-Chrétien reflector, 5-inch refractor, and mobile telescopes. Operating as a community facility, it provides public tours and hosts astronomy lectures on current topics in astrophysics and space exploration.

descriptions.name: IceCube Neutrino Observatory
descriptions.description: IceCube Neutrino Observatory is a large facility for detecting cosmic neutrinos at the South Pole, Antarctica, using the Antarctic ice sheet as its detection medium. The observatory contributed to opening a new window on the high-energy universe through neutrino astronomy and continues detecting neutrinos from cosmic sources and events.

descriptions.name: Indian Astronomical Observatory (IAO)
descriptions.description: Located at 4,500 meters elevation on Mount Saraswati in Hanle, Ladakh, India, the Indian Astronomical Observatory is one of the world's highest sites for optical and infrared astronomy. With 270 clear nights annually and extremely dry atmospheric conditions similar to the Atacama Desert, it hosts a 2-meter optical-infrared telescope and other specialized instruments.

descriptions.name: Infrared Optical Telescope Array
descriptions.description: The Infrared Optical Telescope Array (IOTA) was a stellar interferometer built in 1993 at Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory. Using three 45-cm collectors with a maximum baseline of 38 meters, IOTA achieved first fringes in December 1993 and enabled aperture synthesis imaging before being decommissioned in 2006 due to funding constraints.

descriptions.name: INPE, Cachoeira Paulista
descriptions.description: INPE's Cachoeira Paulista facility in Brazil serves as a major data collection center for the Brazilian Environmental Data Collection System. The Center for Weather Forecasting and Climate Studies (CPTEC) was inaugurated here in 1994, enabling Brazil to implement advanced numerical weather prediction, and operates atmospheric monitoring radars for studying upper-level dynamics.

descriptions.name: Institut de radioastronomie millimétrique
descriptions.description: IRAM (Institut de radioastronomie millimétrique) is Europe's leading millimeter-wave radio astronomy center, founded in 1979 as a French-German-Spanish collaboration. The institute operates the NOEMA array of eleven 15-meter antennas on France's Plateau de Bure and the IRAM 30-meter telescope in Spain, hosting the world's premier facilities for millimeter astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Institute of Astronomy
descriptions.description: The Institute of Astronomy at Cambridge University is one of the UK's largest astronomy research departments with around 180 academics and staff engaged in theoretical and observational work. Established on its current Madingley Road site in the early nineteenth century, it hosts historic telescopes including the 1833 Northumberland 12-inch refractor and offers free public observing nights.

descriptions.name: Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics
descriptions.description: Established in 1988 on the Pune University campus by astrophysicist Jayant Narlikar and colleagues, the Inter-University Centre for Astronomy and Astrophysics promotes research in gravitational waves, cosmology, optical and radio astronomy across Indian universities. IUCAA operates the Girawali Observatory's 2-meter telescope and is a key partner in major projects like LIGO-India and the Thirty Meter Telescope.

descriptions.name: Iranian National Observatory
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in 2021 in central Iran on Mount Gargash at 3,600 meters elevation, the Iranian National Observatory achieved first light in October 2022 with its home-grown INO340 optical telescope featuring a 3.4-meter primary mirror. As Iran's largest telescope, it conducts astronomical and cosmological research while developing relevant domestic technologies.

descriptions.name: Isaac Newton Group of Telescopes
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in 1985 at Roque de los Muchachos on La Palma in the Canary Islands, the Isaac Newton Group of Telescopes operates three major instruments including the 2.54-meter Isaac Newton Telescope (moved from Greenwich in 1979). The group remains an important facility for optical astronomy research, jointly developed by the UK, Netherlands, and Spain.

descriptions.name: Isaac Roberts’ Observatory
descriptions.description: Isaac Roberts' Observatory, established in Crowborough, Sussex in 1890, was the private astronomical observatory of British astronomer Isaac Roberts (1829-1904). Housing a 7-inch refractor and 20-inch reflector, Roberts conducted pioneering astrophotography that revealed the spiral structure of galaxies, advancing human understanding of the cosmos.

descriptions.name: Ishigakijima Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 2006 on Ishigaki Island in Japan's Yaeyama Islands, this observatory is equipped with the 105-centimeter MURIKABUSHI Telescope—the largest in the Kyushu-Okinawa region. Its extremely stable atmosphere allows observation of 86 constellations, while the facility conducts research on Solar System objects and offers public tours and a 4D theater experience.

descriptions.name: Iso-Heikkilä Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1937 for Turku University, Iso-Heikkilä Observatory in Finland became notable when Väisälä's research team discovered 807 minor planets and 7 comets from the site. After the university relocated in the 1950s, the observatory has been operated since 1972 by the Turun Ursa amateur astronomical association for public stargazing events.

descriptions.name: Istanbul University Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1936, Istanbul University Observatory was Turkey's first modern observatory, featuring impressive Bauhaus architecture designed by architect Arif Hikmet Holtay. Though urban light and air pollution prevent nighttime observations, the facility serves nearly 20,000 annual visitors with monthly public nights including talks, planetarium shows, and historical telescope viewing.

descriptions.name: Jacobus Kapteyn Telescope
descriptions.description: The Jacobus Kapteyn Telescope (JKT) is a 1-meter optical telescope operating at Roque de los Muchachos Observatory on La Palma, Spain since 1984. Funded jointly by the Netherlands and UK with construction completed in 1983, it underwent a decade of inactivity before being transformed into a remotely-operated facility through a SARA consortium partnership.

descriptions.name: Jan Paagman Sterrenwacht
descriptions.description: The Jan Paagman Sterrenwacht is a Dutch public observatory in Asten, Netherlands, built as a memorial to Jan Paagman after his death in 1962 by his father Ben Paagman. The facility features the Pieterse Planetarium, presentation rooms, and hosts monthly public viewing nights with lectures on the night sky and telescope observations in clear weather.

descriptions.name: Jardim da Luz observatory
descriptions.description: Established in November 1798 as a botanical garden under the Portuguese Crown, Jardim da Luz in São Paulo opened to the public in 1825 as Brazil's first public garden. An astronomical observatory was added during the 1872-1875 tenure of province president João Teodoro, making it one of São Paulo's earliest scientific installations.

descriptions.name: Jena Observatory
descriptions.description: Jena Observatory in Germany was first built in 1813, funded by local regent Karl August and designed by Johann Wolfgang Goethe. The new 1962 observatory in nearby Großschwabhausen houses a 90-centimeter reflector, 25-centimeter Cassegrain, and 20-centimeter refractor from Carl Zeiss, with the original city-center observatory now serving as the public Volkssternwarte Urania.

descriptions.name: Jennifer Chalsty Planetarium
descriptions.description: The Jennifer Chalsty Planetarium at Liberty Science Center in Jersey City, New Jersey is the largest planetarium in the Western Hemisphere, featuring a 100-foot diameter dome with an 89-foot screen. Opened in December 2017 and named after its $5 million donor, it offers 88 million pixel resolution and advanced immersive astronomical shows.

descriptions.name: Jesuit observatory in Litoměřice
descriptions.description: Built in 1705, the Jesuit Observatory (Lusthaus) at Litoměřice in the Czech Republic is a prismatic-spire observation pavilion integrated into the town's historic fortifications. As one of the best-preserved portions of the city walls, it represents an important example of early astronomical observation facilities in Central Europe.

descriptions.name: Jewett Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1953 and dedicated at Washington State University in Pullman, Washington, the Jewett Observatory houses a historic 12-inch Alvan Clark refractor telescope. Originally ground between 1887-1889, the lens was purchased by the university at auction in the 1950s. The observatory serves undergraduate education and public outreach through monthly star parties.

descriptions.name: Jiangmen Underground Neutrino Observatory
descriptions.description: Completed in August 2025 and located 700 meters underground near Kaiping, China, JUNO is the world's largest transparent liquid-scintillator neutrino detector. With a 35.4-meter diameter acrylic sphere containing 20,000 tonnes of liquid scintillator, it aims to determine neutrino mass hierarchy with over 700 scientists from 17 countries collaborating on this US$376 million facility.

descriptions.name: Jodrell Bank Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1945 by Bernard Lovell in Cheshire, England, Jodrell Bank Observatory is home to the iconic 76-meter Lovell Telescope, the third largest steerable telescope in the world when completed in 1957. It hosted crucial early space missions including receiving the first photographs from the Moon's surface in 1966 and became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2019.

descriptions.name: Johann-Kern-Sternwarte Wertheim
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in 1981 in Wertheim, Germany, this observatory features a Newton telescope with a 24-inch mirror beneath a six-meter aluminum dome, originally commissioned in the 1960s by amateur astronomer Johann Kern. A second building with a retractable roof was added in 2004, and the observatory offers public tours with sky and solar observations for schools and community groups.

descriptions.name: Johannes-Kepler-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Located on Freinberg hill in Linz, Austria at 341 meters elevation, the Johannes-Kepler-Sternwarte opened in 1983 and is the only publicly accessible observatory in the Upper Austrian region. Named after the astronomer who lived in Linz from 1612-1626, it features a computer-controlled Cassegrain mirror telescope and offers regular public sky observations and astronomical lectures.

descriptions.name: Johannes-Kepler-Volkssternwarte
descriptions.description: This public observatory is located in Rudolstadt, Germany, and serves as an educational facility for astronomy in the region. As part of Germany's network of school and public observatories dedicated to Johannes Kepler, it provides opportunities for students and the general public to engage with astronomical observation and learning.

descriptions.name: John Payson Williston Observatory
descriptions.description: Constructed in 1880-1881 at Mount Holyoke College in Massachusetts and completed in time for the 1882 transit of Venus, the Williston Observatory is the oldest academic building on campus. It houses a rare Alvan Clark refractor telescope from the 1880s and a modern 24-inch Ritchey-Chretien reflector, serving as the cornerstone of the college's astrophysics program.

descriptions.name: Jones Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1936 in Chattanooga, Tennessee using a Public Works Administration grant, the Clarence T. Jones Observatory was renamed in 1947 to honor local architect Clarence T. Jones who designed it free of charge. Its 20.5-inch Cassegrain telescope was the largest amateur-built telescope in the world when completed, and the observatory remains dedicated to astronomy education with free public star parties.

descriptions.name: Jura Observatory
descriptions.description: Located near Vicques in the Canton of Jura, Switzerland and built in 1993-1998, the Jura Observatory is operated by the Jura Astronomy Society. The facility discovered the periodic comet P/2008 Q2 (Ory) in 2008 and offers semi-professional visual astronomy capabilities with regular guided visits for solar and night-sky observations.

descriptions.name: Ka-Dar Observatory
descriptions.description: Known as the TAU Station, this is a remote observing station of the private Ka-Dar Observatory, located in the North Caucasus near Nizhny Arkhyz at approximately 2,000 meters elevation. Situated close to the Special Astrophysical Observatory of the Russian Academy of Sciences, the station benefits from the region's exceptionally clear skies and made its first comet discovery confirmed by the Minor Planet Center in 2011.

descriptions.name: Ka-Dar Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 2004 near Kuz'minskoye in the Moscow Oblast, this private astronomical observatory sits at 180 meters elevation about 50 kilometers south of Moscow. It serves as the headquarters for Ka-Dar, which also operates a remote station (TAU Station) in the North Caucasus for observations requiring darker skies and better atmospheric conditions.

descriptions.name: Kadaň Observatory
descriptions.description: The Astronomical and Natural Science Observatory in Kadaň, located on Prostřední vrch in the Czech Republic, opened on February 5, 2022. Equipped with two domes and a viewing platform, it serves educational activities and public outreach with regular guided observations held every 14 days on Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays.

descriptions.name: Kalyazin Radio Astronomy Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1992 in Tver Oblast, Russia, the Kalyazin Observatory operates the RT-64 radio telescope, one of two 64-meter aperture radio telescopes in Russia. A team of 17 scientists uses it to study pulsars, white dwarfs, and distant galaxies, joining ESA's astrobiology program with ExoMars in 2016.

descriptions.name: Kamenskoe Plateau Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1947 at the Fesenkov Astrophysical Institute near Almaty, Kazakhstan at 1,450 meters elevation, the Kamenskoe Plateau Observatory features four telescopes for observing galaxies, stars, planets, and geostationary satellites. On August 17, 1979, it made the first observation of a star being covered by an asteroid within the USSR.

descriptions.name: Kamioka Gravitational wave detector
descriptions.description: KAGRA is a large-scale cryogenic gravitational wave telescope constructed 1,000 meters underground at Kamioka Mine in Japan, featuring a 3-kilometer laser interferometer. As part of a global network with LIGO and Virgo, it is the first underground observatory and the first to use cryogenically cooled mirrors to detect gravitational waves from cosmic events.

descriptions.name: Kandilli Observatory
descriptions.description: Originally established in 1868 as the Imperial Observatory in Istanbul and relocated to its current Kandilli location in 1911, this Turkish institution combines astronomy with earthquake research. Now part of Boğaziçi University since 1982, the Kandilli Observatory and Earthquake Research Institute offers graduate programs in earthquake engineering and geophysics.

descriptions.name: Kanzelhoehe Solar Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1943 near Villach, Austria at 1,526 meters elevation, the Kanzelhoehe Solar Observatory is affiliated with the University of Graz and has operated continuously for 80 years. It performs high-cadence full-disk solar observations with four telescopes covering H-alpha, white light, and Ca II K wavelengths, issuing automated flare alerts within minutes.

descriptions.name: Karl Schwarzschild Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1960 in Tautenburg, Germany and re-established in 1992 as the Thuringian State Observatory, this facility houses the largest Schmidt camera in the world with a 2-meter mirror. The Alfred Jensch Telescope allows observation of extensive celestial objects, and the observatory also operates a station of the European LOFAR radio telescope.

descriptions.name: Karlsruhe Observatory
descriptions.description: The Sternwarte Karlsruhe opened on May 11, 1959 in Karlsruhe, Germany as a public astronomical observatory. Its instrumentation traces back to the Mannheim Observatory founded in 1774, which relocated to Karlsruhe in 1880 to escape deteriorating observation conditions in an increasingly developed urban area.

descriptions.name: Kasin Observatory
descriptions.description: The Kazan Observatory, founded in 1810, was the first university observatory in Russia with Joseph Johann Littrow as its first director. The old observatory (built 1837) and the suburban Engelhardt Astronomical Observatory (opened 1901) were jointly designated UNESCO World Heritage Sites in September 2023, becoming the 32nd World Heritage site in Russia.

descriptions.name: KATRIN
descriptions.description: The Karlsruhe Tritium Neutrino Experiment is located at the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology and measures electron antineutrino mass via beta decay of tritium. Recent 2025 results set a world record upper limit of 0.45 eV/c² for neutrino mass, with plans to add the TRISTAN detector in 2026 to search for sterile neutrino dark matter candidates.

descriptions.name: Kauppi observatory
descriptions.description: Located on the roof of the Kauppi Water Tower in Tampere, Finland at 135 meters elevation, the Kauppi Observatory is operated by Tampere Ursa astronomy organization. It features main telescopes for stargazing and offers public observation opportunities, with an annual August Star Night celebration beginning the autumn observing season.

descriptions.name: Kawaguchi Science Museum
descriptions.description: Located in Kawaguchi, Saitama Prefecture, Japan, the Kawaguchi Science Museum features a state-of-the-art 20-meter dome planetarium with 160 seats offering immersive astronomy shows. Its observatory includes a 65-cm reflector, 20-cm refractor, and solar telescopes, with free public night sky observations held on second and fourth Saturdays.

descriptions.name: Keeble Observatory
descriptions.description: Rebuilt in 2017 at Randolph-Macon College in Ashland, Virginia, the Keeble Observatory houses a state-of-the-art 40-cm Ritchey-Chretien telescope with CCD cameras. It is the largest telescope between Washington D.C. and the Blue Ridge Mountains and serves as a teaching laboratory for astrophysics research and public viewing under student direction.

descriptions.name: Kennon Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1939 by the Public Works Administration in Oxford, Mississippi, the Kennon Observatory features two copper-roofed domes housing a 15-inch refracting telescope (the historic 1892 Grubb Twin Equatorial) and a 17-inch Plane Wave Corrected Dall Kirkham telescope. The University of Mississippi offers regular astronomy open houses with public telescope viewing.

descriptions.name: Kepler-Schule Graz observatory
descriptions.description: The BRG Kepler school in Graz, Austria is the only school in Austria with a permanently installed observatory, built in the 1990s. The school also features the Keplerraum, a museum dedicated to Johannes Kepler including a walk-through mirrored icosahedron, and both participate in the ORF Long Night of Museums since 2009.

descriptions.name: Kielder Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in April 2008 in Kielder Forest, Northumberland, England, the Kielder Observatory is located in the third largest protected Dark Sky reserve in the world. Award-winning architecture by Charles Barclay Architects is powered by solar and wind energy, hosting over 40 viewing events monthly and attracting nearly 20,000 visitors annually.

descriptions.name: Kihoku Astronomical Museum
descriptions.description: Designed by architect Masaharu Takasaki and opened August 10, 1995 in Kihoku-cho, Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan at 550 meters elevation, this distinctive museum features telescopes, space science exhibits, and a planetarium. Recognized for exceptional night sky viewing conditions, it offers workshops and educational programs connecting the community with astronomy.

descriptions.name: Killarney Provincial Park Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in July 2010 as North America's first free public self-use observatory in any provincial park, the Killarney Observatory was upgraded in 2018 with a research-grade 16-inch telescope. Located at George Lake Campground, it became Ontario's first Dark Sky Preserve in 2018 and offers astronomer-led programs during summer and fall months.

descriptions.name: Kilpisjärvi Atmospheric Imaging Receiver Array
descriptions.description: KAIRA is a dual-array VHF radio receiver system near Kilpisjärvi, Finland operated by the Sodankylä Geophysical Observatory, with 48 low-band and 48 high-band LOFAR antennas. Capable of measuring faint radio signals and determining their precise directions, KAIRA studies solar wind interactions with the atmosphere and serves as a pathfinder for the EISCAT_3D system.

descriptions.name: Kinnordy House
descriptions.description: Kinnordy House is an estate near Kirriemuir in Angus, Scotland with an observatory built in the mid-to-late 18th century, possibly by botanist Charles Lyell. Now listed as a historic structure within the Kinnordy Walled Garden, it has associations with notable figures including geologist Charles Lyell and is connected to Charles Darwin through scientific correspondence.

descriptions.name: Kirkwood Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1900 and dedicated in 1901 at Indiana University in Bloomington, the Kirkwood Observatory houses the restored original 12-inch Brashear refractor telescope by Warner & Swasey Company. Named for astronomer Daniel Kirkwood who discovered the asteroid belt divisions, it is used for public education, undergraduate classes, and hosts weekly viewing events weather permitting.

descriptions.name: Kislovodsk Mountain Astronomical Station
descriptions.description: A station of the Pulkovo Observatory located at 2,070 meters elevation near Kislovodsk, Russia, this facility is the leading establishment for the Solar Survey of the USSR. Equipment includes coronagraphs, chromospheric-photospheric telescopes, spectroheliographs, and radio telescopes, with monthly Solar Data bulletins and annual Solar Activity catalogs published for the research community.

descriptions.name: Kiss György Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded around 1980 by amateur astronomer György Kiss in Nagyszénás, Hungary, this observatory was directed by István Zahorecz after Kiss's death in 2000. It currently houses six telescopes including five reflectors and one refractor, serving the local amateur astronomy community.

descriptions.name: Kitami Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in the Kitami-Abashiri Region Cultural Centre in eastern Hokkaido, Japan, the Kitami Observatory is notable for asteroid discoveries made by amateur astronomers Atsushi Takahashi and Kazuro Watanabe. As of 2012, over 680 asteroids have been discovered at this facility, which includes planetarium and exhibition hall facilities.

descriptions.name: Kitt Peak National Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1958 on the Tohono O'odham Nation 87 km southwest of Tucson, Arizona at 2,096 meters elevation, Kitt Peak is home to the largest array of optical and radio telescopes in the world. The Nicholas Mayall 4-meter telescope and other major instruments have supported decades of groundbreaking astronomical research, with guided tours available to the public.

descriptions.name: Kleť Observatory
descriptions.description: The highest observatory in the Czech Republic, located south of Kleť mountain peak at 1,070 meters elevation and constructed in 1957, Kleť is a world leader in near-Earth asteroid monitoring. Over 1,000 asteroids and comet 196P/Tichý have been discovered here, with approximately 150 clear nights per year and telescopes featuring a 57-cm mirror and 30-cm lens.

descriptions.name: Kodaikanal Solar Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded on April 1, 1899 near Kodaikanal, India following recommendations from an 1893 meeting chaired by Lord Kelvin, the Kodaikanal Solar Observatory has maintained one of the world's longest continuous solar observation records for over 125 years. The Evershed effect was first detected here in 1909, and its digitized data is publicly available for global research.

descriptions.name: Koenigsberg Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1813 in Königsberg (now Kaliningrad, Russia) and attached to the Albertina University, Friedrich Wilhelm Bessel at this observatory made the first measurement of stellar parallax, determining a star's distance. The facility was destroyed in 1944 during World War II but remains significant in the history of positional astronomy and astrometry.

descriptions.name: Konkoly Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1871 by Hungarian nobleman Miklós Konkoly-Thege as a private observatory and nationalized in 1899, Konkoly Observatory is Hungary's largest astronomical research institute. The Piszkéstető Observatory, relocated in the 1960s to escape urban light pollution, houses the largest telescope in Hungary—a 1-meter Ritchey-Chretien reflector installed in 1975.

descriptions.name: Kopernik Space Center
descriptions.description: The Copernicus Science Centre (Centrum Nauki Kopernik) in Warsaw, Poland reopened its planetarium in April 2025 after full renovation with a striking 16-meter dome featuring Sony 4K digital projectors and traditional starball optics. Its 139-146 reclining seats project 20 million stars with 2D and 3D shows for all ages along the Vistula River.

descriptions.name: Kourovskaya observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Sverdlovsk Oblast and named after K.A. Barkhatova, the Kourovskaya Observatory was established in 1965 and is affiliated with Ural State University in Ekaterinburg. Since 1995, it has hosted annual winter conferences for students from astronomical departments of universities across Russia.

descriptions.name: Krasnopresnenskaja Observatory MSU
descriptions.description: Established in 1831 on the Moscow State University campus, the Krasnopresnenskaja Observatory is one of Russia's oldest, with the Sternberg Astronomical Institute founded at the site in 1931. Now primarily a museum, the observatory preserves vintage equipment including a 15-inch double astrograph telescope and offers lectures and tours for all visitors.

descriptions.name: Kremsmünster Observatory
descriptions.description: Built between 1748-1758 at Kremsmünster Abbey in Austria, the 50-meter high 'Mathematical Tower' was an architectural innovation for its time. Benedictine monk Placidus Fixlmillner computed the orbit of Uranus here, and the monastery operated the world's longest continuous weather station since 1763, still collecting meteorological data today.

descriptions.name: Kryoneri Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1972 at Mount Kyllini in Corinth, Greece at 930 meters elevation, the Kryoneri Observatory operates the 1.23-meter Korgialenio Cassegrain reflector, one of Greece's largest telescopes. Upgraded in 2016 for lunar impact monitoring through ESA's NELIOTA program, it participated in laser communications with NASA's Psyche spacecraft in July 2025.

descriptions.name: Kryzhanivka Observatory
descriptions.description: A research station of Odesa University in Ukraine established in the late 1950s, the Kryzhanivka Observatory operates a TV Meteor Patrol using an upgraded Schmidt telescope for observing telescopic meteors since 2003. The station is equipped with reflectors, refractors, catadioptrical telescopes, and Schmidt cameras for systematic astronomical observations.

descriptions.name: Kuffner observatory
descriptions.description: Constructed from 1884-1886 in Vienna's Ottakring district as a private research institution financed by brewery mogul Moriz von Kuffner, the Kuffner Observatory became one of the Austro-Hungarian Empire's most important astronomy sites. After closure in 1915 and reopening in 1947, it was fully refurbished from 1989-1995 and now serves public education with tours and night sky observation.

descriptions.name: Kuiper Airborne Observatory
descriptions.description: The Gerard P. Kuiper Airborne Observatory (KAO) was a Lockheed C-141A Starlifter jet aircraft with a 36-inch infrared telescope, operating from 1974-1995 at NASA's Ames Research Center. Major discoveries include Saturn's rings' composition, Pluto's atmosphere detection, and evidence of the supermassive black hole at the Milky Way's center before being succeeded by SOFIA.

descriptions.name: Kulin Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Kulin, Western Australia, approximately 280 km east of Perth in the Wheatbelt region, this facility serves the local astronomical community in an agricultural district. The observatory provides opportunities for amateur astronomers in the region.

descriptions.name: Kumamoto Civil Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Kumamoto Prefecture, Japan, this civil astronomical observatory is part of Japan's network of public astronomical facilities. It provides opportunities for community members and astronomy enthusiasts to observe celestial objects and engage with educational astronomy programs.

descriptions.name: Kurashiki Observatory
descriptions.description: Japan's first private observatory, built around 1926, featuring a 31.5cm reflecting telescope and historic preservation of documents from notable comet hunter Mr. Honda. Located near Kurashiki's historical quarter, it now offers public stargazing experiences with reclining chairs overlooking the night sky.

descriptions.name: Kvistaberg Observatory
descriptions.description: Swedish branch observatory 50 km south of Uppsala, founded in 1957 with a donation from artist Nils Tamm. Home to the world's second-largest Schmidt telescope (100/135 cm), it discovered hundreds of minor planets between 1975 and 2005 before closing for active research around 2004.

descriptions.name: Kwasan Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1929 by Kyoto University and located behind the famous Kiyomizu temple, this Japanese observatory pioneered solar coronal and Martian meteorology research. Though inactive due to light pollution, it remains a sacred site for amateur astronomers with historical significance in Japanese astronomy.

descriptions.name: La capitale Observatory
descriptions.description: A Spanish observatory complex near Toledo dedicated to observing dwarf planets, detecting asteroids with the University of Huelva, and analyzing lunar impacts through the MIDAS project. Serving dual purposes of astronomical research and educational outreach with specialized instruments.

descriptions.name: La Hita observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Murcia's Carrascoy mountains, this Spanish municipal observatory features a 16-inch Meade Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope dedicated to studying minor planets. Offers Friday night guided observation visits and educational programs for the public.

descriptions.name: La Murta Observatory
descriptions.description: A Spanish observatory in Valencia dedicated to astronomical research and public education. The facility conducts observations and provides outreach programs for the local community.

descriptions.name: La Plata Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: An Argentine observatory established in 1883 under the direction of Pedro Benoit, with a historic 2.15-meter Ritchey-Chretien reflecting telescope later installed at El Leoncito. The 7-hectare campus retains 18 original buildings from the late 19th century with antique astronomical collections.

descriptions.name: La Posta Astro-Geophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: A 60-foot radio-telescope in California's Laguna Mountains at 3,900 feet altitude, built in 1964 for solar research and ionospheric forecasting. Played a critical role in Apollo moon missions by predicting solar activity that could affect spacecraft communications before decommissioning in 1986.

descriptions.name: La Sagra Observatory
descriptions.description: A Spanish observatory near Granada dedicated to tracking near-Earth objects and space debris using four remotely-controlled robotic telescopes at 1,500 meters elevation. Known for detecting asteroid 2012 DA14 and maintaining one of mainland Spain's darkest sites for optimal astronomical observations.

descriptions.name: La Silla Observatory
