descriptions.description: European Southern Observatory facility in Chile's Atacama Desert at 2,400 meters elevation with exceptional clear skies averaging 300+ cloudless nights yearly. Home to multiple major telescopes including the New Technology Telescope with active optics and HARPS spectrograph for exoplanet discovery.

descriptions.name: La Specola
descriptions.description: A historic 14th-century tower in Padua, Italy, converted to an astronomical observatory in 1767 with instruments designed by Giuseppe Toaldo. Visited by Goethe and other luminaries, it operated as a major European facility until 1942, now housing a museum with telescopes and astronomical collections.

descriptions.name: Ladd Observatory
descriptions.description: Brown University's astronomical observatory in Providence, Rhode Island, dedicated in 1891 with a 12-inch refractor telescope. Operated a regional timekeeping service starting in 1893 and continues serving education through public observing nights while maintaining historical significance as a National Register site.

descriptions.name: Lamont–Doherty Earth Observatory
descriptions.description: A Columbia University research institution in Palisades, New York, founded in 1949 on the former estate of banker Thomas Lamont. With 500+ scientists and staff, it was instrumental in developing plate tectonics theory and operates the research vessel Marcus G. Langseth for seismic mapping.

descriptions.name: Land's End Observatory
descriptions.description: Built 1936-37 by the WPA and Forest Service on Grand Mesa's rim in Colorado, this scenic ranger observatory provided panoramic views of four mountain ranges and valleys. Served as the first visitor center with peak use in the 1950s; currently closed but the scenic drive remains popular.

descriptions.name: Las Campanas Observatory
descriptions.description: Carnegie Institution facility established in 1969 in Chile's Atacama Desert, 100 km northeast of La Serena, with exceptional dark skies and optimal astronomical seeing. Home to twin 6.5-meter Magellan telescopes and the under-construction Giant Magellan Telescope with 24.5-meter effective aperture.

descriptions.name: Las Cumbres Observatory
descriptions.description: Global network of robotic telescopes founded in 1993 and expanded to international scale in 2005, with facilities distributed around Earth for continuous 24-hour observations. Currently operates 18 telescopes across six observatories, used for studying supernovae, exoplanets, and near-Earth objects with integrated software scheduling.

descriptions.name: Leibniz Institute for Astrophysics Potsdam
descriptions.description: Founded 1992 as successor to Berlin Observatory (1700) and Astrophysical Observatory Potsdam (1874), this German research institute studies stellar, solar, and exoplanetary physics. Operates the Einstein Tower solar observatory, Great Refractor, and robotic telescopes on Tenerife from its Babelsberg campus.

descriptions.name: Leiden Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1633, the world's oldest operating university observatory, located in the Netherlands with continuous research tradition. Originally in the city center, relocated to botanical gardens in 1860, then moved to campus in 1974; the restored historic building now serves as a visitor center.

descriptions.name: Leoncito Astronomical Complex
descriptions.description: Argentine complex established 1983 in El Leoncito National Park with over 250 clear nights yearly and minimal atmospheric contamination. Features the 2.15-meter Jorge Sahade telescope and 1.5-meter Solar Submillimeter Telescope for solar flare observations, attracting thousands of visitors annually.

descriptions.name: Leopold-Figl-Observatorium
descriptions.description: Austrian outstation of Vienna University Observatory, located on Mitterschopfl mountain at 882 meters elevation within the Wienerwald Biosphere Park. Established 1965 and inaugurated 1969, it houses a 1.5-meter primary telescope and 0.6-meter secondary telescope for student training and long-term research projects.

descriptions.name: Leviathan of Parsonstown
descriptions.description: Historic 72-inch reflecting telescope completed in 1845 by William Parsons, 3rd Earl of Rosse, representing the world's largest telescope until 1917. Made from difficult-to-work-with speculum metal through three attempts, it famously revealed the spiral nature of the Whirlpool Galaxy; reconstructed with modern mirror for public viewing since 1997.

descriptions.name: Lick Observatory
descriptions.description: California mountaintop observatory founded 1888 on Mount Hamilton with the world's first 36-inch Great Refractor telescope, a revolutionary design. Pioneer of exoplanet, supernova, and galaxy research with adaptive optics development; continues active research and public programs.

descriptions.name: Lilienthal Observatory
descriptions.description: German observatory near Bremen founded 1785 by astronomer Johann Hieronymus Schroter as 'Uranienlust,' one of world's best-equipped facilities with ten telescopes. The 1793 'Riesenteleskop' had a 50cm aperture and helped discover asteroid Juno; the original structure was rebuilt in 2015.

descriptions.name: Lille observatory of astronomy
descriptions.description: French university observatory built 1932 with geometric architectural design influenced by Robert Mallet-Stevens, featuring a 32cm dome telescope among France's largest. Associated with IMCCE research institute and offering university diploma courses in astronomy since 2019.

descriptions.name: Lindheimer Astrophysical Research Center
descriptions.description: Northwestern University research facility built 1966 with two domes housing a 16-inch Cassegrain reflector for student use and a 40-inch Cassegrain with rapid-scanning spectrometer for research. The facility contributed to stellar spectroscopy research.

descriptions.name: Litchfield Observatory
descriptions.description: Connecticut amateur astronomy club observatory at White Memorial Conservation Center, built 1997 by the Mattatuck Astronomical Society. Features 14-inch and 12-inch computerized reflecting telescopes in a roll-off observatory, hosting monthly public star parties with lectures and sky observation sessions.

descriptions.name: Llano de Chajnantor Observatory
descriptions.description: High-altitude observatory at 4,800+ meters in Chile's Atacama Desert, home to ALMA with 66 antennas, APEX, ASTE, and the high-altitude TAO telescope. The extreme aridity and high elevation make it one of Earth's driest locations, ideal for submillimeter observations unaffected by atmospheric water vapor.

descriptions.name: Llano del Hato National Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Venezuelan national observatory at 3,600 meters in the Andes near Merida, with access to both northern and southern skies at the closest major optical observatory to the equator. Equipped with four large optical telescopes installed in 1954-1955, managed by CIDA with museum and exhibition center for public education.

descriptions.name: LOFAR
descriptions.description: Large radio telescope array at 10-240 MHz frequencies with about 20,000 antennas in 52 stations across Netherlands and 7 European countries. Revolutionary 'software telescope' using digital processing to achieve Earth-spanning resolution for studying cosmic history and radio transients.

descriptions.name: Lohrmann Observatorium
descriptions.description: Research observatory at TU Dresden founded 1961 and named after geodesist Wilhelm Gotthelf Lohrmann, focusing on celestial mechanics and astrometry. Located in 1913-built Beyer Building with 30cm Heyde refractor, currently studying ESA's Gaia mission data and testing general relativity theories.

descriptions.name: Lomnický Štít Observatory
descriptions.description: Slovak observatory at 2,632 meters on Lomnicky Stit peak in the High Tatras with meteorological measurements since 1940 and astronomical observations since 1962. Equipped with solar instruments including new Coronal Multi-Channel Polarimeter (CoMP-S) and Solar Chromospheric Detector (SCD) installed 2011-2016.

descriptions.name: Loomis Observatory
descriptions.description: Historical Massachusetts observatory built in 1838, the third in the United States and second oldest still standing, featuring original 1837 instruments including a Troughton & Simms equatorial telescope. Restored multiple times, housing both historical instruments and modern equipment for education.

descriptions.name: Los Molinos Observatory
descriptions.description: Uruguay's only professional observatory near Las Piedras, founded to study comets and asteroids as one of few southern hemisphere facilities dedicated to small bodies. Recognized with asteroid 10476 Los Molinos named in its honor, operating under Ministry of Education and University of the Republic collaboration.

descriptions.name: Louis-Théophile Moreux observatory
descriptions.description: French observatory established by Abbe Theophile Moreux in 1907 at Bourges, later expanded with a weather station recording daily data from 1913-1950. Moreux studied lunar and Martian surface features; a Mars crater was named for him, and the observatory reflects his contributions to science.

descriptions.name: Lowell Observatory
descriptions.description: Arizona observatory founded 1894 by astronomer Percival Lowell, site of Pluto's 1930 discovery by Clyde Tombaugh and designated National Historic Landmark in 1965. Features the original 61-cm Clark Refractor for public education with 85,000+ annual visitors and the 4.3-meter Lowell Discovery Telescope for research.

descriptions.name: Lubomir Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Polish mountain observatory on Lubomir peak, destroyed in 1944 by German forces but rebuilt with two domes (3m and 5m diameter) housing modern telescopes. Operates for research and education in the Polish mountains.

descriptions.name: Lulin Observatory
descriptions.description: Taiwan observatory at 2,862 meters on Mount Lulin's summit, featuring the 1-meter Lulin Telescope (LOT) as Taiwan's largest-diameter optical telescope. One of world's few observatories unreachable by motor vehicle; has discovered 800+ asteroids since 2002 and identified Comet Lulin (C/2007 N3).

descriptions.name: Lumezzane observatory
descriptions.description: Italian observatory in Lumezzane near Brescia, featuring a 40cm dome telescope as part of the Serafino Zani Astronomical Observatory. Hosts planetarium operations, works with high school students, and offers public observation programs combining astronomical education with constellation museum facilities.

descriptions.name: Lund Observatory
descriptions.description: Swedish university observatory founded 1749, preceded by an earlier 1672 facility destroyed in 1676's Battle of Lund. Created the Lund Panorama of the Milky Way by mapping 7,000 stars (completed 1955); operates a planetarium at Vattenhallen Science Center welcoming thousands of annual visitors.

descriptions.name: Lviv Polytechnic Observatory
descriptions.description: Ukrainian observatory founded 1771 by Jesuit college, the 17th oldest in Europe and oldest in Ukraine, featuring two large green domes on the main building's roof. Instruments stand on 30-meter reinforced concrete pillars isolated from building vibrations; currently conducts GNSS observations for international centers.

descriptions.name: Lyon Observatory
descriptions.description: French observatory established 1878 in Saint-Genis-Laval with staff of 200 across historic and modern sites, featuring 21 buildings and 40+ historic instruments. Originally provided weather forecasts and precise timekeeping for Lyon; modern work includes polychromatic artificial stars for adaptive optics laser systems.

descriptions.name: Lübeck observatory
descriptions.description: German school observatory operated by Arbeitskreis Sternfreunde Lubeck, originally on Johannes Kepler School roof until 2017 demolition. Reopened in 2021 with new observation tower after renovation; collaborates with the world's first school planetarium, the 1931 Sternkammer.

descriptions.name: Macalester College Observatory
descriptions.description: Saint Paul college observatory with remotely-controlled telescopes from dedicated computing lab in Olin-Rice Hall, featuring automated dome and science-grade CCD camera. Leads the MACRO Consortium managing the fully robotic Robert L. Mutel Telescope at Winer Observatory for improved observing conditions.

descriptions.name: Madhava Observatory
descriptions.description: University of Calicut observatory established 2005, India's largest university-level facility with 6.6-meter hemispherical dome and 1.75-meter slit. Features 14-inch Meade Cassegrain telescope and 18-inch NGT reflector from Indian Institute of Astrophysics, named after medieval mathematician-astronomer Madhava of Sangamagrama.

descriptions.name: Madras Observatory
descriptions.description: Indian observatory established 1792 by William Petrie, originally for navigation assistance and timekeeping standards, operating until 1931. Discovered 58 asteroids and 21 variable stars; Thomas Glanville Taylor's star catalogue catalogued 11,000 stars; the historic meridian marker remains at regional meteorological center.

descriptions.name: Magdalena Ridge Observatory
descriptions.description: New Mexico high-altitude observatory at 10,600 feet on 1,000 acres in Magdalena Mountains, featuring a 2.4-meter fast-tracking telescope and multi-element optical/infrared interferometer. NASA-contracted for near-Earth asteroid astrometry and characterization.

descriptions.name: Maiaky Observatory
descriptions.description: Ukrainian observatory founded 1957 in Odesa Oblast with multiple observation stations for tracking stars, meteors, and geostationary satellites. Houses world's third-largest glass plate image collection (100,000+ plates 1909-1989) after Harvard and Sonneberg; expanded with radiotelescope in 1980s for broader celestial research.

descriptions.name: Main Astronomical Observatory of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine
descriptions.description: Ukrainian observatory founded July 1944 near Kyiv's Golosiiv forest by astronomer O.Ya. Orlov, dedicated to fundamental astrometry and solar system dynamics. Led by Academician Yaroslav Yatskiv since 1975; museum opened 2004 with exhibits, equipment displays, and guided tours.

descriptions.name: main building of the Old Observatory, Leiden
descriptions.description: Historic 1860 Dutch observatory in botanical gardens, modeled after Russian palace architecture with offices, living quarters, and observation domes. Restored 2008-2012 and now operates as visitor center for the world's oldest continuously-operating university astronomical facility with guided tours.

descriptions.name: Malakoff Tower
descriptions.description: Parisian Crimean War memorial tower reconstructed in plaster at amusement park in Vanves by Alexandre Chauvelot, named after the 1855 Battle of Malakoff. The original fortress was demolished 1870 during Paris siege; the name inspired the nearby Malakoff suburb.

descriptions.name: Man Singh Observatory
descriptions.description: An 18th-century astronomical observatory built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh on the rooftop of the 300-year-old Man Mandir Palace in Varanasi, India, featuring traditional instruments like the Samrat Yantra for determining celestial positions. Digitalized as a specialized museum by the government in 2019, it remains one of five surviving observatories built by Jai Singh in India.

descriptions.name: Manila Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1865 by Jesuit missionaries, the Manila Observatory on the Ateneo de Manila University campus in Quezon City conducts research in seismology, geomagnetism, and climate dynamics. Rebuilt after World War II destruction and relocated to Loyola Heights in 1962, it continues important work on atmospheric and geological monitoring.

descriptions.name: Mannheim Observatory
descriptions.description: Constructed between 1772-1774 in Mannheim, Germany, this historic observatory discovered binary stars under astronomer Christian Mayer's direction and hosted notable visitors including Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart. Transferred to Heidelberg in 1898, it served as an internationally renowned research facility before decline during the Napoleonic Wars.

descriptions.name: Mannou Observatory
descriptions.description: Located near the summit of Mt. Daisen in Japan, Mannou Observatory features a public dome telescope for observing planets, stars, nebulae, and the moon. Its clear mountain location and staff guidance make it a popular destination for amateur and public stargazing.

descriptions.name: Manuel Foster Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1903 on Cerro San Cristobal near Santiago, Chile, the Manuel Foster Observatory operated with what was once the largest fully steerable telescope in the southern hemisphere. Though technical problems halted operations in 1948, restoration efforts since the 1980s and its designation as a national monument in 2010 revived it as a public attraction.

descriptions.name: Maragheh Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1259 CE in present-day Iran under the patronage of Ilkhanid Hulagu, the Maragheh Observatory was directed by Persian astronomer Nasir al-Din al-Tusi and became one of the most advanced scientific institutions in Eurasia. Hosting over a hundred astronomers and containing a library of approximately 400,000 volumes, it pioneered sophisticated pre-Copernican astronomical systems.

descriptions.name: Maria Mitchell Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1908 in Nantucket, Massachusetts and named after America's first female astronomer Maria Mitchell, the observatory features the historic Loines Observatory with a 24-inch research telescope. Its summer NSF internships and extensive collection of 8,000 photographic plates from 1913-1995 have earned recognition including a 2009 Presidential Award for Excellence in Science Education.

descriptions.name: Marina Towers Observatory
descriptions.description: Officially opened in 1993 in Swansea's Maritime Quarter, Marina Towers Observatory was designed as a sea-facing tower featuring a distinctive stained glass dome and originally housed Wales' largest optical telescope, a 20-inch Shafer-Maksutov reflector. Though an astronomical society disagreement forced closure in 2010, the building was transformed into a cafe and bar in 2022.

descriptions.name: Markree Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1830 in County Sligo, Ireland, Markree Observatory housed the world's largest refractor telescope at that time with its 13.3-inch Cauchoix lens. Known for discovering asteroid 9 Metis in 1848 and compiling a 60,000-item star catalogue in the 1850s, it remained active until 1902 and its historic telescope was relocated to Hong Kong.

descriptions.name: Marseille Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1701 in Montee des Accoules near Vieux Port, Marseille, this historic French observatory became a branch of the Paris Observatory in 1863. Notable for the 1877 discovery of Stephan's Quintet and featuring the pioneering 80-cm Foucault reflector, it now operates as a joint research facility with a planetarium added in 2001.

descriptions.name: Mauna Kea Observatories
descriptions.description: Located at 4,205 meters on the summit of Mauna Kea in Hawaii, Mauna Kea Observatories comprise the world's largest observatory with telescopes from eleven countries operating within a 525-acre Astronomy Precinct. Its exceptional observing conditions above 40% of Earth's atmosphere with clear, calm, cloudless nights make it the premier site for optical, infrared, and submillimeter astronomy.

descriptions.name: Mauna Loa Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded on June 28, 1956 at 3,397 meters on Mauna Loa's north flank in Hawaii, Mauna Loa Observatory was established to monitor solar, atmospheric, and meteorological parameters in the free atmosphere. Famous for the continuous CO2 measurements beginning in 1958 that produced the foundational Keeling Curve documenting Earth's greenhouse gas composition, it remains a vital climate monitoring station.

descriptions.name: Mauna Loa Solar Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1965 on the slopes of Mauna Loa and operated by the High Altitude Observatory, Mauna Loa Solar Observatory featured the pioneering K-coronameter for solar corona observations. Its 3,440-meter elevation on lava fields provided ideal conditions free from atmospheric contamination for solar research.

descriptions.name: McCormick Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1881 for the University of Virginia after receiving an Alvan Clark & Sons refractor in 1878, McCormick Observatory houses the equal-largest telescope in the United States when completed. Now primarily used for teaching and public outreach from Mount Jefferson near Charlottesville, it offers free monthly observation nights through historic and smaller telescopes.

descriptions.name: McDonald Observatory
descriptions.description: Endowed by Texas banker William Johnson McDonald, McDonald Observatory was established in 1939 near Fort Davis in the Davis Mountains with its then second-largest telescope in the world. Now operated by the University of Texas at Austin, it features four research telescopes including the 10-meter Hobby-Eberly and hosts over 20,000 annual visitors through its Frank N. Bash Visitors Center.

descriptions.name: McKim Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1884 in Greencastle, Indiana by DePauw University, McKim Observatory was Indiana's first observatory and remains largely unchanged with its original equipment intact. Its main 9.53-inch Clark Refractor telescope from 1885 and other original instruments continue supporting stargazing events and serve as excellent examples of late 1800s observatory design.

descriptions.name: Mead Observatory
descriptions.description: Now called WestRock Observatory (formerly Mead Observatory), this facility at Columbus State University's Coca-Cola Space Science Center in Georgia was established in 1996 for night sky and solar research. With capabilities for remote operation and recognized asteroid research status (MPC code W22), it conducts narrowband solar imaging and variable star photometry for student and public education.

descriptions.name: Medicina Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Located 30 kilometers from Bologna, Italy and operated by the National Institute for Astrophysics, Medicina Radio Observatory hosts two significant radio telescopes: the Northern Cross transit radio telescope (one of the world's largest) and a 32-meter parabolic dish. The facility conducts VLBI observations, SETI experiments, and serves as a European VLBI Network station.

descriptions.name: Melbourne Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1862 adjacent to the Royal Botanic Gardens in Melbourne, Australia, Melbourne Observatory began operations in 1863 and maintained accurate time measurements through transit telescope observations. Its 48-inch refractor briefly the world's largest steerable telescope participated in the 1874 Transit of Venus observations and continues operating today under the Astronomical Society of Victoria.

descriptions.name: Merate Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Merate, Italy and part of the Brera Astronomical Observatory system, Merate Observatory has housed a 1-meter Zeiss telescope since its inauguration in 1927. Now managed by the National Institute for Astrophysics, it welcomes public visitors for guided tours and observation nights showcasing modern astronomical research and innovation.

descriptions.name: Mercedes Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1974 in Mercedes, Buenos Aires Province, Argentina, the Mercedes Astronomical Observatory was relocated to a rural area in 2007 for improved sky quality and operates with a 60-centimeter Cassegrain reflector and 30-centimeter reflecting telescope. It also hosts a Boston University All-Sky Imager for upper atmosphere research accessed remotely via Internet.

descriptions.name: Metsähovi Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1974 in Kirkkonummi, Finland and operated by Aalto University, Metsahovi Radio Observatory is Finland's only astronomical radio facility featuring a 14-metre radio telescope enclosed in a radome. Observing 98% of available hours year-round at millimeter and microwave frequencies, it conducts research on solar radiation, active galaxies, and participates in very long baseline interferometry.

descriptions.name: Meudon Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1876 by Jules Janssen in Meudon, a suburb southwest of Paris, the Observatory was entirely devoted to the new discipline of astrophysics, integrating laboratory facilities with telescopes. The Grande Coupole completed in 1895 houses the Grande Lunette, a double refractor with an 83-centimeter lens that remains the world's third-largest refractor.

descriptions.name: Michigan State University Observatory
descriptions.description: Located south of Michigan State University's campus in East Lansing, Michigan State Observatory was mostly completed in 1969 and equipped with a 24-inch Ritchey-Chretien reflecting telescope in 1970. Closed from 1981-1986, it reopened for Halley's Comet's return and now hosts monthly public observing when conditions permit.

descriptions.name: Michigan-Dartmouth-MIT Observatory
descriptions.description: The Michigan-Dartmouth-MIT (MDM) Observatory was established in 1975 on Kitt Peak near Tucson, Arizona and originally housed Michigan's 1.3-meter McGraw-Hill telescope. Now operated by a consortium of five institutions, MDM features 2.4-meter and 1.3-meter telescopes with state-of-the-art optical and infrared instruments for major astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Milford Sound Discovery Centre and Underwater Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1994 as the world's first floating underwater observatory in Harrison Cove, Milford Sound, New Zealand now includes the Discovery Centre and allows visitors to observe black coral found at unusual depths, fish, seals, and penguins. The facility remains a unique marine observation point in Fiordland National Park.

descriptions.name: Millimeter Anisotropy eXperiment IMaging Array
descriptions.description: MAXIMA was a balloon-borne cosmic microwave background experiment funded by NSF, NASA, and the Department of Energy that conducted two flights from Palestine, Texas in 1998-1999. By providing the most accurate CMB measurements on small angular scales and confirming the standard cosmological model with a baryon density of 4%, it significantly advanced understanding of the universe's composition.

descriptions.name: Mills Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1935 on Balgay Hill in Dundee, Scotland, Mills Observatory was the first purpose-built public astronomical observatory in the UK and features a Victorian refracting telescope in a distinctive seven-meter papier-mache dome. Now celebrating over 90 years of service, it offers free public access and features a planetarium, computerized telescope detecting 30,000 sky objects, and spectacular Tay River views.

descriptions.name: Millstone Hill Observatory
descriptions.description: The Millstone Hill Geospace Facility at MIT Haystack Observatory in Westford, Massachusetts operates a high-power, large-aperture incoherent scatter radar built in 1958. Since 1974 supported by the National Science Foundation, it provides unique capabilities for studying ionospheric features and has pioneered the Madrigal distributed data system adopted as the CEDAR database standard.

descriptions.name: Milmaru Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at the center of Sejong Administrative City in South Korea, Milmaru Observatory offers 360-degree views of the city and surrounding regions from its 9th-floor elevator access. With free admission and no booking required, the observatory provides visitors an urban trip course showcasing Sejong's transformation from fields to a modern administrative center.

descriptions.name: Milwaukee Astronomical Society Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1932, the Milwaukee Astronomical Society operates one of the world's largest amateur club observatories on 3 acres in New Berlin, Wisconsin, featuring 9 observatory buildings entirely financed and maintained by members. The facility includes multiple named telescopes such as the 18-inch Kyle Baron Reflector and hosts open house nights for public stargazing from late Spring through early Fall.

descriptions.name: MINERνA
descriptions.description: MINERvA (Main Injector Experiment for nu-A) is a neutrino scattering experiment at Fermilab using the high-intensity NuMI beamline to measure low-energy neutrino interactions on five different nuclei. The detector's 200 hexagonal panels with scintillator strips enable three-dimensional particle tracking and have produced the world's most precise measurements of neutrino interactions in the 1-10 GeV energy range.

descriptions.name: Misato Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 400 meters elevation in Kimino, Wakayama Prefecture, Japan, Misato Astronomical Observatory features a 105-centimeter reflecting telescope accessible to 30-person capacity audiences. Offering planetarium shows, telescope demonstrations, and accommodations in three nearby bungalows, it provides ideal conditions for stargazing with clear mountain air and minimal light pollution.

descriptions.name: MIT Lincoln Laboratory
descriptions.description: Created in 1951 at Hanscom Air Force Base in Lexington, Massachusetts, MIT Lincoln Laboratory is a Department of Defense federally funded research and development center chartered to address national security technology challenges. With core competencies in sensors, signal processing, communications, and cyber security, it has launched over 100 start-ups and transferred advanced technology to government, industry, and academia.

descriptions.name: Mitzpe Hadar
descriptions.description: Mitzpe Hadar is an observatory established in 2017 in Israel, named after Hadar Goldin. As a relatively recently established observation point, it represents modern efforts to expand astronomical observation capabilities in the Middle East.

descriptions.name: Mitzpe Revivim
descriptions.description: Mitzpe Revivim is a museum and historic observation point founded in 1943 as part of a plan to establish research stations in Israel's Negev region to examine settlement prospects. This kibbutz offers visitors a tower with incredible desert vistas, archaeological sites including a Nabatean cave, and insight into the 1948 War of Independence when it fell behind Egyptian lines.

descriptions.name: Modine-Benstead Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1963 in Union Grove, Wisconsin, Modine-Benstead Observatory was funded by two generous benefactors from prominent manufacturing companies and features a 16-inch main telescope and 14-inch secondary dome telescope. Public monthly open house events from April through October offer free admission and parking for amateur and professional astronomers.

descriptions.name: Modra Observatory
descriptions.description: Owned and operated by Comenius University in Bratislava, Modra Observatory in Slovakia has discovered 175 numbered and 34 unnumbered asteroids, including near-Earth objects, and performed the first observation of a transiting exoplanet in Slovakia. As a member of the European bolide network with meteor detection grid infrastructure, it conducts photometry of asteroids and comets and studies atmospheric phenomena like sprites and elves.

descriptions.name: Molėtai Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1969 on Kaldiniai Hill near Moletai, Lithuania and operated by Vilnius University, Moletai Astronomical Observatory houses the 165-centimeter diameter telescope the largest scientific device in Northern Europe. The facility hosts organized excursions introducing visitors to astronomy, telescopes, and color photographs of celestial objects.

descriptions.name: Mon Plaisir Tower
descriptions.description: Mon Plaisir Tower represents the ruins of an astronomical tower near Pobiedna village. While limited information is available about this historical observation site, it exemplifies early astronomical infrastructure development in Eastern Europe.

descriptions.name: Mont d'Arbois astronomical observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 1,800 meters on Mont d'Arbois ridge in Saint-Gervais Mont-Blanc in the French Alps, this public observatory is accessed via signposted hiking paths. Operated by passionate astronomers, it offers introductory astronomy evenings throughout the summer where visitors learn about planets, galaxies, nebulae, and comets under ideal high-altitude conditions.

descriptions.name: Mont Mégantic Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1978 near Sherbrooke, Quebec and jointly operated by Universite de Montreal and Universite Laval, Mont Megantic Observatory features a 1.6-meter telescope at 1,111 meters elevation in the Eastern Townships. As Canada's fourth-largest and most efficient observatory surrounded by the world's first International Dark Sky Association Dark Sky reserve, it attracts over 20,000 visitors annually through its ASTROLab education center.

descriptions.name: Monte Generoso Observatory
descriptions.description: Originally opened in 1996 on the Swiss-Italian border atop Monte Generoso at 1,800 meters, this observatory operated near the railway's summit station with Saturday evening observations and weekend observations May-November. After 20 years of operation, the original telescope was relocated due to decreased interest.

descriptions.name: Monte Mario Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1938 in the historic Villa Mellini on Monte Mario hill overlooking Rome's Tiber River, Monte Mario Observatory became the seat of Italy's National Institute for Astrophysics (INAF) in 2002. Its 1951 Solar Tower with independent protective structures and 45-centimeter lens enables direct solar observations now open to the public since 2010, while also housing the Astronomical Copernican Museum.

descriptions.name: Monte Viseggi Observatory
descriptions.description: The 'Luciano Zannoni' Astronomical Observatory on Monte Viseggi overlooking La Spezia, Italy at 347 meters elevation was built by amateur astronomers using disused anti-aircraft positions from 1935. Inaugurated in 1989 by renowned astronomer Margherita Hack and renewed in 2024, it discovered six asteroids including Palmaria.

descriptions.name: Montpellier Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1879 in Montpellier's Jardin des Plantes botanical garden, Montpellier Observatory features the Foucault telescope installed by Crova and constructed at the Paris Observatory in 1877. Even earlier, the 1745 Tour de la Babote served as an observatory, and the main facility was classified as a heritage object in 2006 for its scientific and historical significance.

descriptions.name: Montsec Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Sant Esteve de la Sarga, Lleida, Catalonia and managed by the Institute of Space Studies of Catalonia, Montsec Observatory operates the 0.8-meter robotic Joan Oro Telescope (TJO) at the finest observing site in Catalonia. The surrounding Montsec Astronomical Park holds the international Starlight award, designated as the world's third and Europe's second Starlight Reserve.

descriptions.name: Mount Abu Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1962 near Guru Shikhar in Rajasthan, India at 1,680 meters elevation and managed by the Physical Research Laboratory, Mount Abu InfraRed Observatory (MIRO) houses a 1.2-meter infrared telescope with cutting-edge spectrography. With discoveries of three exoplanets using older telescopes and the indigenously-developed PARAS-2 spectrograph finding another, it provides about 200 cloud-free observing nights annually.

descriptions.name: Mount Cuba Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1958 in Greenville, Delaware by seven individuals inspired by native astronomer Annie Jump Cannon, Mount Cuba Astronomical Observatory operates as a private 501(c)(3) nonprofit with a 24-inch Tinsley telescope and 1.3-meter remote research telescope. Serving as the research hub for the Whole Earth Telescope and hosting public and family night programs, it engages with schools, universities, and youth organizations.

descriptions.name: Mount Graham International Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1989 in southeastern Arizona's Pinaleno Mountains near Mount Graham, Mount Graham International Observatory operates three major telescopes including the world's most powerful Large Binocular Telescope that began dual-mirror operations in 2008. The University of Arizona's Steward Observatory division hosts weekend tours via Discovery Park visitor center.

descriptions.name: Mount John University Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1965 at 1,029 metres atop Mount John in New Zealand's Mackenzie Basin, this observatory is home to the MOA telescope, the largest optical telescope in the country. It serves as a research facility while being part of the Aoraki Mackenzie International Dark Sky Reserve and offers public stargazing tours through the Dark Sky Project.

descriptions.name: Mount Laguna Observatory
descriptions.description: Dedicated in June 1968 and operated by San Diego State University, this observatory is located at 6,100 feet in the Cleveland National Forest with excellent observing conditions. The three major research telescopes include a 50-inch Phillips reflector and a 40-inch reflector, achieving photometric sky conditions 60% of the time.

descriptions.name: Mount Lemmon Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in the Santa Catalina Mountains 28 km northeast of Tucson, Arizona, this observatory was converted from an air defense radar station in 1970 into an infrared facility. Home to eight telescopes including the 1.52-meter Steward Observatory telescope used for the Mount Lemmon Survey, it is ranked among top space observatories to visit in the US.

descriptions.name: Mount Lemmon Survey
descriptions.description: Part of the Catalina Sky Survey, this research program uses a 1.52-meter Cassegrain reflector at Mount Lemmon to discover and track near-Earth objects to meet congressional mandates. Since its operation, it has discovered numerous asteroids and continues tracking potentially hazardous asteroids.

descriptions.name: Mount Pleasant Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Located 20 km east of Hobart in Tasmania, this radio observatory has operated since 1986 with a 26-meter radio antenna relocated from the Orroral Valley Tracking Station. It houses the Grote Reber Museum honoring the father of radio astronomy, welcoming about 5,000 visitors annually.

descriptions.name: Mount Stony Brook Observatory
descriptions.description: An educational observatory operated by Stony Brook University, located on the roof of the Earth and Space Sciences Building in Stony Brook, New York. It houses a 14-inch Maksutov-Cassegrain telescope with CCD imaging equipment and is used for class demonstrations and undergraduate astronomy labs.

descriptions.name: Mount Stromlo Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1924 near Canberra, Australia, this observatory was severely damaged in the 2003 bushfires, destroying five telescopes but leaving only the 1886 Farnham telescope. All research telescopes were relocated to Siding Spring Observatory, and the facility is now a major partner in constructing the Giant Magellan Telescope.

descriptions.name: Mount Suhora Observatory
descriptions.description: Established November 5, 1987, on Mount Suhora in the Gorce Mountains of Poland at 1,000 m elevation, this observatory was built as a teaching facility after Lubomir Observatory's destruction. It houses a 0.6-metre Cassegrain telescope and is part of the Whole Earth Telescope network for simultaneous variable star observations.

descriptions.name: Mount Terskol Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1980 at 3,150 meters on Terskol Peak in the Northern Caucasus Mountains near Mt. Elbrus, this international observatory operates a 2-meter Zeiss telescope for optical observations. Its high astroclimatic characteristics make it suitable for observations from October to June.

descriptions.name: Mount Wilson Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1904 by George Ellery Hale in the San Gabriel Mountains near Los Angeles, this observatory housed the world's largest telescopes of its era, including a 100-inch reflector. Historic discoveries by Hubble, Shapley, and others revolutionized astronomy; today it is open to the public with observing programs and lectures.

descriptions.name: Mukai Chiai Children's Science Museum
descriptions.description: Honoring astronaut Mukai Chiaki, Japan's first woman in space, this science museum in Gunma Prefecture features a 23-meter planetarium dome with 240 seats. Interactive exhibits include a moonwalker experience and hands-on demonstrations of physics principles, attracting families interested in space exploration.

descriptions.name: Mullard Radio Astronomy Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1957 at Lord's Bridge southwest of Cambridge, England, this observatory houses major aperture synthesis radio telescopes and is recognized by the 1974 Nobel Prize awarded for pioneering radio astronomy techniques. It operated groundbreaking instruments including the One-Mile Telescope and Ryle Telescope.

descriptions.name: Murchison Radio-astronomy Observatory
descriptions.description: Established by CSIRO in 2009 in remote Western Australia 800 km north of Perth, this observatory operates within a 520-km radio quiet zone to minimize electromagnetic interference. It hosts the ASKAP telescope, the MWA array, and the SKA-Low under construction, serving as one of the world's premier radio astronomy sites.

descriptions.name: Mykolaiv Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1821 as a Naval Observatory by Admiral Aleksey Samuilovich Greig in Ukraine, this is the oldest naval observatory in south-eastern Europe. Its photographic observations of solar system bodies rank among the world's most accurate, with nearly 35 catalogs of celestial body positions created.

descriptions.name: Mårtsbo observatory
descriptions.description: An astronomical observatory located in Sweden in Gavle Municipality, situated in the Martsbo area of central Sweden. While details are limited, it serves the regional astronomical community for observational work.

descriptions.name: Mühlenturm
descriptions.description: A historic structure in Geldern, Germany, this 1546-built gun tower was converted to a windmill in 1643 with additional conical stories added. Today it serves as a viewing tower offering panoramic views and hosts rotating art exhibitions and cultural events rather than functioning as a traditional observatory.

descriptions.name: Nançay Decameter Array
descriptions.description: Constructed between 1974 and 1977 as part of the Nancay Radio Observatory in France, this decameter array consists of 144 spiral antennas sensitive to wavelengths between 3-30 meters. With a collecting area equivalent to a 67-meter dish, it has observed the Sun and Jupiter almost daily since 1977.

descriptions.name: Nançay Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Operating since 1956 in Nancay, France and associated with Paris Observatory and University of Orleans, this facility houses the Grand Radiotelescope with an 8,000 square meter collecting surface. For six decades it has contributed to astrophysical advances studying pulsars, galaxy velocities, and the universe's expansion.

descriptions.name: NAOJ Mizusawa Campus
descriptions.description: Home to the VERA project, a Japanese VLBI array spanning 2,300 km across four 20-meter antennas, this campus near the 39-degree latitude line in Iwate Prefecture creates 3D maps of the Milky Way. It continues the legacy of the historic Mizusawa International Latitude Observatory.

descriptions.name: NASA Infrared Telescope Facility
descriptions.description: A 3.2-meter telescope optimized for infrared astronomy atop Mauna Kea in Hawaii, this NASA facility has supported planetary, solar system, and deep space research since its construction for the Voyager missions. Operated by the University of Hawaii, 50% of observing time is reserved for solar system studies.

descriptions.name: Natal Observatory
descriptions.description: A historical astronomical observatory in the Brazilian territory of Natal that operated from 1882 to 1911. Though distinct from the National Observatory in Rio de Janeiro, it represented early scientific astronomical endeavor in colonial South America.

descriptions.name: National Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The term refers to a category of national observatories found worldwide, each serving as the primary astronomical research center for their respective countries. These institutions typically conduct fundamental research in cosmology, stellar astronomy, and planetary science.

descriptions.name: National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
descriptions.description: The national center of astronomical research in Japan, operating since 1988 with multiple domestic campuses and international facilities including the Subaru Telescope in Hawaii and ALMA in Chile. NAOJ manages the Nobeyama Radio Observatory and participates in major international projects like the Thirty Meter Telescope.

descriptions.name: National Astronomical Observatory of Japan Hawaii Observatory
descriptions.description: Operated by NAOJ and located on Maunakea's summit, the Subaru is an 8.2-meter optical-infrared telescope that officially began operations in April 1997. With a base facility in Hilo housing 100 staff and research laboratories, it represents Japan's commitment to world-class observational astronomy.

descriptions.name: National Astronomical Observatory of San Pedro Mártir
descriptions.description: Operated by UNAM since 1929 and relocated to the Sierra San Pedro Martir in Baja California in 1971 to escape light pollution, this observatory features six telescopes ranging from 0.28 to 2.1 meters. Modern robotic instruments like BOOTES-5, COATLI, and DDOTI conduct automated observations.

descriptions.name: National Observatory of Athens
descriptions.description: Founded in 1842, this is the oldest scientific research institute in Greece, featuring the iconic X-shaped building designed by Theophil Hansen and financed by banker Georgios Sinas. Located atop the Hill of Nymphs, it operates four sites and maintains a Geoastrophysics Museum with 19th-century instruments.

descriptions.name: National Radio Astronomy Observatory
descriptions.description: A federally funded research center operating since 1956 for US radio astronomy, headquartered in Charlottesville, Virginia. It operates the VLA in New Mexico (the world's most advanced radio telescope array spanning 22 miles) and the VLBA stretching across 5,351 miles for the sharpest dedicated observations.

descriptions.name: National Research Institute of Astronomy and Geophysics
descriptions.description: Founded in 1839 as a Royal Observatory, making it the oldest research institute in North Africa and a UNESCO-recognized world heritage site. Located at Helwan, Egypt since 1903, NRIAG employs over 300 researchers in five divisions covering astronomy, geophysics, and maintains specialized laboratories for seismic monitoring.

descriptions.name: National Solar Observatory
descriptions.description: The US national center for solar physics, headquartered in Boulder, Colorado and funded by NSF since 1984. It manages the construction of the Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope and operates the six-telescope Global Oscillations Network Group for understanding the Sun's influence on Earth.

descriptions.name: National Space Facilities Control and Test Center
descriptions.description: A Ukrainian state institution responsible for managing space flight operations and deep space research, established in 1996 in Yevpatoria. Following the 2014 Crimea annexation, headquarters relocated to Kyiv; it comprises four branches conducting navigation field monitoring and interplanetary flight management.

descriptions.name: Nayoro Municipal Observatory Kitasubaru
descriptions.description: Opened in April 2010 in Nayoro, Hokkaido, Japan, this municipality-run observatory features a 1.6-meter Pirika telescope and Japan's second-largest public telescope installed by Hokkaido University. Located 15 minutes from downtown with minimal light pollution, it offers seasonal viewing and astronomy workshops.

descriptions.name: NenuFAR
descriptions.description: A very large low-frequency radio telescope under construction in Nancay, France, operating between 10-85 MHz as a LOFAR super station. With 1,938 dual-polarization antennas distributed hierarchically, it searches for exoplanets, cosmic dawn signatures, and pulsars with capabilities among the world's most powerful in its frequency range.

descriptions.name: Neue Universitätssternwarte Innsbruck
descriptions.description: The new university observatory at Innsbruck, Austria, featuring a 60-cm Ritchey-Chretien telescope installed in 1996 on a building completed in 1986. Since 2015 upgrades including a new fork mount and state-of-the-art spectrographs support student education and variable star research.

descriptions.name: Neumünster public observatory
descriptions.description: A public observatory established in 1971 in Neumuenster, Germany by the Volkshochschule (Adult Education Centre), featuring a one-ton main telescope. The facility offers professional sky-watching and astronomy courses, though recent operations have been temporarily restricted for structural repairs.

descriptions.name: NEVOD
descriptions.description: A neutrino detector and cosmic ray experiment located within the MEPhI campus in Moscow, Russia, using a quasispherical Cherenkov water detector. The facility researches all cosmic ray components on Earth's surface, including pursuing solutions to the 'muon puzzle' observed in extensive air showers.

descriptions.name: New Plymouth Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1920 on Marsland Hill in New Plymouth, New Zealand, this observatory is home to the New Plymouth Astronomical Society and operates one of the country's most powerful public-access telescopes. Located with panoramic views of the coastline, it opens Tuesday evenings for public observing.

descriptions.name: Nice Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1879 by banker Raphael Bischoffsheim on Mount Gros, this observatory features an iconic building designed by Charles Garnier with the main dome engineered by Gustave Eiffel. Its 76-cm refracting telescope, operational since 1888, was the world's largest at the time.

descriptions.name: Nichihara Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1985 as Japan's first public observatory, located atop 255-meter Mt. Makurase in Tsuwano-cho, Shimane Prefecture. It features a 75-centimeter Nasmyth telescope and offers access to some of Japan's darkest skies with the second-least light pollution nationwide.

descriptions.name: Nizamia observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1901 by the 6th Nizam of Hyderabad in Ameerpet, this optical observatory participated in the Carte du Ciel international program and catalogued over 3 lakh stars by 1928. Relocated to Rangapur in 1968 due to urbanization, it houses a 48-inch telescope, the second-largest in Asia.

descriptions.name: Nobeyama radio observatory
descriptions.description: A major division of NAOJ operating three radio instruments at 1,350 meters elevation near Minamimaki, Nagano, the Nobeyama Radio Observatory houses the 45-meter telescope, one of the world's largest millimeter-wave observatories since 1982. Its technologies directly influenced modern telescopes like ALMA.

descriptions.name: Norikura Solar Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1949 at 2,876 meters atop Norikura Mountain in Japan's Northern Alps, this solar observatory was the first off-campus facility of Tokyo Astronomical Observatory. Operating only in summer due to heavy snow, it features coronagraphs studying the Sun's corona and continues under NAOJ operation.

descriptions.name: Norman Lockyer Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded by Joseph Norman Lockyer in 1912 in Sidmouth, Devon following the closure of the South Kensington Observatory, this optical observatory is an active center for amateur astronomy and science education. A 60-seat planetarium was added in 1996 and the Connaught Dome in 2012 for radio astronomy.

descriptions.name: North Bohemian Observatory and Planetarium in Teplice
descriptions.description: Located on Sand Hill in Teplice, Czech Republic, 80 km north of Prague, this modernized observatory focuses on artificial satellite and space debris observations using the SHOT telescope. The facility features distinctive domes and wooden observation towers with titanium zinc roofing.

descriptions.name: North cupola of Brno Observatory and Planetarium
descriptions.description: Part of the Brno Observatory and Planetarium complex in the Czech Republic, the north cupola is one of multiple observational structures at this facility opened in 1954. The site underwent significant modernization in 2010-2011, maintaining observational capabilities on Kravi Hora (Cow Hill).

descriptions.name: Northumberland Astronomical Society
descriptions.description: Founded in January 2000, this English amateur astronomical society comprises approximately 70 professional and amateur astronomers from the North East. Its mission involves public outreach and science education, with an active observing program using a 14-inch telescope secured in 2005.

descriptions.name: Noto Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: A 32-metre radio telescope VLBI station on Sicily, Italy near Noto, operated by the Istituto di Radioastronomia di Bologna. Completed in 1988 with an active surface for various wavelengths, it participates in very long baseline interferometry for high-resolution astronomical imaging.

descriptions.name: Nyrölä Observatory
descriptions.description: An amateur astronomical observatory in Finland owned and operated by Jyvaskylan Sirius ry near Jyvaskyla, equipped with a 0.4-meter Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope. The facility has contributed to astronomical discoveries including asteroid 22978 Nyrola named in its honor.

descriptions.name: O'Brien Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1968 by the University of Minnesota about 35 kilometers northeast of Minneapolis, this observatory was among the first infrared facilities built. Featuring a 0.76-meter Cassegrain reflector capable of optical and infrared observations, it is used for instruction, instrument testing, and research.

descriptions.name: Oak Ridge Observatory
descriptions.description: Operated by the Center for Astrophysics Harvard & Smithsonian until 2005, this Harvard facility in Massachusetts tracked minor planets and asteroids for its first 40 years before shifting to exoplanet detection. It housed an 84-foot radio telescope used in Project BETA for searching extraterrestrial intelligence.

descriptions.name: Obihiro City Children's Hall
descriptions.description: A children's science facility in Obihiro, Hokkaido, Japan featuring a planetarium, science exhibition rooms, and lodging for school groups. With free admission for students and affordable rates for adults, it includes interactive exhibits and the 'Mokkun Plaza' with wooden toys for young children.

descriptions.name: Observatoire Astronomique de Mont-Soleil
descriptions.description: A tourist and educational observatory founded on Mont-Soleil above Saint-Imier in the canton of Bern, Switzerland. Equipped with a 355 mm telescope and a 4.5 m planetarium, it offers evening observations of celestial objects including planets, nebulae, and star clusters for visitors regardless of weather conditions.

descriptions.name: Observatoire de Saint-Maur
descriptions.description: Founded in 1883 by Eleuthere Mascart near Paris, the Observatoire de Saint-Maur-des-Fosses was a meteorological and geophysical research center. It recorded Earth's magnetic field from 1883-1900 and was incorporated into the Institut de Physique du Globe de Paris, with data serving Meteo-France.

descriptions.name: observatoire du Mont Ménard
descriptions.description: The Observatoire du Mont-Megantic was inaugurated in 1978 in Quebec, Canada at 1100 metres altitude. It houses a 1.6m telescope jointly administered by l'Universite de Montreal and l'Universite Laval, making it the largest telescope of eastern North America.

descriptions.name: Observatoire du Mont-Sinaï
descriptions.description: A military observatory established in October 1914 on the heights of Verzy during World War I, offering strategic views over 30 km to observe German positions across the Vesle River. Today, three concrete observatories remain classified as Historical Monuments, with the accessible observatory named 'Chambre du general Gouraud'.

descriptions.name: Observatoire Midi-Pyrénées
descriptions.description: The Observatoire Midi-Pyrenees (OMP) is an Observatory of the Sciences of the Universe at the University of Toulouse, with the famous Pic du Midi Observatory at 2,877 metres in the French Pyrenees. Astronomy has been studied there since 1873, and it houses the 2-metre Bernard Lyot Telescope, the largest in France.

descriptions.name: Observatori Astronòmic de Castelltallat
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in 2004 on a hill at 911 metres altitude in Sant Mateu de Bages, Catalonia, the Observatori Astronomic de Castelltallat features a 420mm diameter telescope in a 5.25-metre diameter dome. Its isolated location makes it a privileged location for astronomy and it has been designated a Starlight Stellar Park.

descriptions.name: Observatori de l'Ebre
descriptions.description: Founded in 1904 in Roquetes (Baix Ebre), Spain, the Observatori de l'Ebre was officially inaugurated on August 30, 1905. From its inception, it was devoted to studying solar influence on Earth's physical phenomena, excelling in geomagnetic activity, solar research, and atmospheric electricity research.

descriptions.name: Observatorio Astronómico de Cabezo de la Jara
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in 2001 at 800 metres altitude near Puerto Lumbreras in the Region of Murcia, Spain, the Observatorio Astronomico de Cabezo de la Jara features a 12-inch Meade LX 200 reflecting telescope and educational facilities. In February 2020, it was declared a Starlight Stellar Park.

descriptions.name: Observatorio Astronómico de Mallorca
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in May 1991 near Costitx, Mallorca, Spain, the Observatorio Astronomico de Mallorca was the first astronomical center in the Balearic Islands and the easternmost in Spain. The observatory is renowned for comet and asteroid research and has made the largest number of direct discoveries in Spanish astronomy history.

descriptions.name: Observatorio Astronómico del CURE
descriptions.description: Inaugurated on September 2, 2016 in the Rocha department, Uruguay, the Observatorio Astronomico del CURE is equipped with a MEADE 0.30m telescope and automated dome. It focuses on astrometry of minor bodies and provides support for teaching, research, and public outreach activities in astronomy.

descriptions.name: Observatorio Astronómico del Torcal de Antequera
descriptions.description: Located at 1,200 metres altitude in the Torcal de Antequera Natural Area in Malaga, Spain, this public observatory was established in 2010 to promote astronomy dissemination and research. It features an automated telescope and conducts important meteor research with all-sky surveillance cameras.

descriptions.name: Observatorio Astronómico Educativo Turístico UNMSM - M. D. Maranganí
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in August 2017 in the district of Marangani, Cusco, Peru, the observatory (renamed Observatorio Astronomico Maria Luisa Aguilar in 2017) is located on the Apu Huchuy Ateria plateau. It was built with an investment of approximately half a million and is equipped with an 8-inch LX200 Schmidt Cassegrain telescope.

descriptions.name: Observatorio de La Cañada
descriptions.description: Founded in 2002 by Juan Lacruz in Avila, Spain, Observatorio J87 La Canada is a privately owned facility dedicated to monitoring near-Earth objects, asteroids, and comets. By August 2025, it had discovered 78 numbered asteroids and joined the international asteroid warning network IAWN in 2022.

descriptions.name: Observatorio del Instituto de Profesores Artigas
descriptions.description: Located in the La Aguada neighborhood of Montevideo, Uruguay, the Observatorio del Instituto de Profesores Artigas acquired a modern Meade LX90 reflector telescope in 2009. The observatory serves students from the teaching program and schools, and in 2013 published an article in Nature regarding asteroid occultation tracking.

descriptions.name: Observatorio Geofísico de Almería
descriptions.description: Founded in 1912 in Almeria, Spain, the Observatorio Geofisico operated with Seismology, Meteorology, and Geomagnetism sections. It ceased operations in 1989 due to urban growth affecting magnetic field recording, and its functions were transferred to the Geophysical Observatory of San Pablo de los Montes (Toledo).

descriptions.name: Observatorio Hipatia de Tepezalá
descriptions.description: Formally inaugurated on October 6, 2023 after 15 years of construction on Cerro de San Juan in Tepezala, Aguascalientes, Mexico, the Observatorio-Planetario Hipatia features state-of-the-art telescopes with 4K laser projectors. It is the largest and most modern planetarium open to the public in Mexico.

descriptions.name: Observatorio Ramón María Aller
descriptions.description: Founded in 1943 by Professor Ramon Maria Aller Ulloa at the University of Santiago de Compostela, the Observatorio Ramon Maria Aller is Galicia's only university observatory. It specializes in research on binary and multiple stars, teaching, astronomical outreach, and meteorology, with a 62 cm aperture telescope installed in 2003.

descriptions.name: Observatorium Sonnblick
descriptions.description: Established in 1886 at 3,106 metres altitude in the Austrian Alps, the Observatorium Sonnblick is the highest-altitude continuously operated meteorological observatory in the world. It has been staffed year-round with only four days unmanned since 1886 and serves as a research station for climate and atmospheric studies.

descriptions.name: Observatorium Tusculanum
descriptions.description: Founded by Ole Romer in 1704 near Vridslosemagle, Denmark, Observatorium Tusculanum was the first observatory outside Copenhagen and the first equipped with a Meridian Circle. After Romer's death, the observatory fell into disrepair, but its remains were rediscovered in 1978 and can now be visited via the nearby Kroppedal museum.

descriptions.name: York Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1832 and 1833 in the grounds of York Museum Gardens in Yorkshire, England, the York Observatory is the oldest working observatory in Yorkshire. Its 4-inch refractor telescope was built by Thomas Cooke in 1850, and after restoration in 1981, it remains open to the public for stargazing.

descriptions.name: Observatory and Planetarium dr. Zdeňka Kvíze
descriptions.description: Located in Trebic, Czech Republic, the Observatory and Planetarium dr. Zdenka Kvize expanded with a planetarium in November 2023. It features a six-meter dome planetarium capacity, observation facilities with Meniscas-Cassegrain 150/2200 and Newton telescopes, and offers educational programs for children and adults.

descriptions.name: Observatory Großschwabhausen
descriptions.description: The Astrophysikalisches Institut und Universitats-Sternwarte Jena's observatory in Grossschwabhausen was built in 1962 to avoid light pollution from Jena. Located 10 kilometres west of Jena at 1962 metres altitude, it is equipped with a 90 cm reflector telescope and serves for both research and student practical training.

descriptions.name: Observatory House
descriptions.description: Observatory House in Slough, England was an 18th-century astronomical observatory housing William and Caroline Herschel's famous 40-foot telescope, the largest in the world at that time. The original building was demolished in 1963 and replaced with an office block also called Observatory House.

descriptions.name: Observatory in Banská Bystrica
descriptions.description: A specialized cultural and educational facility in Banska Bystrica, Slovakia, the Observatory aims to disseminate astronomy and related sciences among the public, especially youth. Located on Urpin Mountain at Vartovka, it cooperates closely with observatories in other Slovak towns.

descriptions.name: observatory in Boskovice
descriptions.description: A small observatory in Boskovice, Czech Republic, dedicated to astronomical observation and public education. While specific founding details are limited, it remains part of the Czech astronomical observatory network.

descriptions.name: Observatory in Mikulášovice
descriptions.description: Historical observatory in Mikulasovice, Czech Republic, referenced as being built in the 1960s by a pharmacist named Krause. The building also served as a pharmacy with pre-war tradition, representing early astronomical infrastructure in the region.

descriptions.name: Observatory in Prague-Podolí
descriptions.description: Stefanik's Observatory in Prague-Podoli area is an astronomical observatory founded in 1928 and named after Slovak astronomer Milan Rastislav Stefanik. The building features three domes and offers public viewing of the night sky and daytime solar observations with modern telescopes.

descriptions.name: Observatory in Valašské Meziříčí
descriptions.description: The Hvezdarna Valasske Mezirici (Observatory of Valasske Mezirici) in the Czech Republic recently introduced a new half-meter robotic telescope for systematic comet CCD photometry. In November 2025, a new building was opened as part of the largest facility expansion in approximately 60 years.

descriptions.name: observatory Ledeč nad Sázavou
descriptions.description: A small astronomical observatory in Ledec nad Sazavou, Czech Republic, serving the local astronomy enthusiast community. It contributes to the broader Czech network of observatories dedicated to public outreach and amateur astronomy.

descriptions.name: Observatory of Geneva
descriptions.description: Founded in 1772 in Geneva, Switzerland, the Observatory of Geneva was created to support the watchmaking industry by accurately determining mean time. Today located in Versoix at the Sauverny site, it operates the 1.2-metre Leonhard Euler Telescope and is a world leader in astrophysical research.

descriptions.name: Observatory of Kunstkamera, Saint Petersburg
descriptions.description: Established in 1728 at the Kunstkamera museum in Saint Petersburg, Russia, the Observatory of Kunstkamera was where Russian astronomy, meteorology, and geodesy were born. The first Petersburg meridian was established here, becoming the basis for mapping Russia and planning the city.

descriptions.name: Observatory of Maximilian Hell, Žiar nad Hronom
descriptions.description: A regional observatory and planetarium in Ziar nad Hronom, Slovakia, named after Slovak astronomer Maximilian Hell and founded in 1973. It features a digitalized planetarium with a 10-metre diameter spherical projection area and offers regular public programs along with educational activities.

descriptions.name: Observatory of Strasbourg
descriptions.description: Designed by August Winnecke and constructed between 1876 and 1880, the Observatory of Strasbourg was officially inaugurated on September 22, 1881. It houses the Great Refractor (48.7 cm aperture), one of the largest in France, and is home to the Centre de donnees astronomiques de Strasbourg hosting SIMBAD and VizieR.

descriptions.name: Observatory of the Collegio Romano
descriptions.description: Established in 1774 at the Collegio Romano in Rome, the observatory was later relocated to the top of Sant'Ignazio di Loyola church under Father Angelo Secchi. Under Secchi's direction, it became one of the first and most active centers of astrophysics in the world before being nationalized in 1870.

descriptions.name: Observatory of university federal of Rio Grande do Sul
descriptions.description: Founded in 1906 as the Instituto Astronomico e Meteorologico at the School of Engineering in Porto Alegre, Brazil, the Observatory of the Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul conducted astronomical and meteorological research for decades. The Morro Santana Observatory was later inaugurated in the 1940s for astrophysics research.

descriptions.name: Observatory Sankt Andreasberg
descriptions.description: Opened in August 2014 on a plateau near the village of Grossschwabhausen in the Harz mountains, Germany at 710 metres altitude, the Observatory Sankt Andreasberg is designed to be the first completely barrier-free observatory in Germany. According to the Federal Agency for Nature Conservation, it is one of six best locations for astronomy in Germany.

descriptions.name: Observatory TT1
descriptions.description: Observatory TT1 (Toppo Telescope #1) is located at Toppo di Castelgrande in Basilicata, Italy at 1250 metres altitude. It serves as a research facility for astronomical observations and studies in southern Italy.

descriptions.name: Observatory Vsetín
descriptions.description: Founded in 1950 by the local branch of the Czechoslovak Astronomical Society, the Observatory Vsetin in the Czech Republic features several telescopes including a main refractor with 3,000 mm focal distance. It conducts public observations and comets photometry throughout the year.

descriptions.name: Observatório Astronómico da Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade do Porto/Professor Manuel de Barros e respetivas instalações
descriptions.description: The Observatorio Astronomico Professor Manuel de Barros of the Faculty of Sciences at the University of Porto was founded in 1948 on Monte da Virgem. It serves as a research center and teaching facility for Astronomy, Geodesy and Earth Sciences, and is particularly involved in radioastronomy and the SKAO observatory project.

descriptions.name: Observatório Municipal de Americana
descriptions.description: Located in a privileged area between an Ecological Park and Botanical Garden, the Observatorio Municipal de Americana (OMA) in Sao Paulo, Brazil reopened on July 23, 2016 after a fire. It features a Schmidt-Cassegrain Reflector Telescope and offers video sessions, lectures, and astronomy courses with maximum capacity of 15 people per visit.

descriptions.name: Observatório Municipal de Campinas Jean Nicolini
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in 1977 as the first municipal observatory in Brazil, the Observatorio Municipal de Campinas Jean Nicolini is located in the Joaquim Egidio District about 30 km from downtown. It offers astronomy exhibitions, thematic videos, and telescope observations of celestial objects through four telescopes.

descriptions.name: Observeum Burgum
descriptions.description: Located in Burgum, Netherlands, the Observeum is an observatory, planetarium, and local museum combined in one facility. It features the only large Middle Stone Age exhibition in the Netherlands and offers various educational packages and exhibitions for schools and visitors.

descriptions.name: Odesa Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1871, the Astronomical Observatory of Odesa National University in Ukraine occupies 1.4 hectares in Shevchenko Park. With two observation stations and multiple telescopes, it focuses on stellar research, solar observation, variable stars, and meteors, and houses a museum with over 20,000 exhibits.

descriptions.name: Ohio Wesleyan University Student Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1896 at Ohio Wesleyan University in Delaware, Ohio, the OWU Student Observatory was designed by architect Sidney Rose Badgley. In the 1980s, students organized to restore the building; it now houses a 9-1/2-inch refracting telescope and was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1985.

descriptions.name: Old Innsbruck Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1904 by astronomer Egon von Oppolzer at the University of Innsbruck, Austria, the historic Innsbruck Observatory was incorporated into the university in 1909. After renovation in 2014, it opened as the 'Historic Observatory Museum' and continues to use a Coude refractor for teaching and public relations.

descriptions.name: Old Naval Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 23rd and E Street in Northwest Washington, D.C., the Old Naval Observatory operated from 1844 to 1893 before moving to Massachusetts Avenue. The moons of Mars were discovered here in 1877 using its telescope, and the building remains a National Historic Landmark designated in 1965.

descriptions.name: Old Observatory
descriptions.description: The Old Observatory in Geneva, Switzerland was demolished in 1969 after the new observatory in Versoix began operations in 1967. Founded in 1772, it was revolutionary for its time and served the Geneva watchmaking industry's need for accurate timekeeping.

descriptions.name: Old Observatory of Geneva
descriptions.description: The Old Observatory of Geneva, Switzerland was established on the city's fortifications in 1772 with the mission to accurately determine 'mean time' for the watchmaking industry. In 1830, a second observatory was built 70m away, and the original building was demolished in 1969 when the new Versoix observatory opened.

descriptions.name: Old Perth Observatory
descriptions.description: Constructed in 1896 and officially opened in 1900 by John Forrest, the original Perth Observatory in Australia was located at Mount Eliza overlooking Perth. It moved to Bickley in 1965 due to city expansion, and the old observatory dome was demolished in the 1960s; the site is now home to the National Trust of WA.

descriptions.name: Old University of Alabama Observatory
descriptions.description: The Old University of Alabama Observatory in Tuscaloosa operated from 1849 until the 1890s and was one of seven buildings that survived the Federal raid of April 4, 1865. Now known as Frederick R. Maxwell Hall, it has been restored and currently houses the university's Creative Campus Assembly and was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1972.

descriptions.name: Ole Rømer Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1911 in Aarhus, Denmark, the Ole Romer Observatory was designed by architect Anton Rosen and named after the Danish astronomer Ole Romer. The facility features two rotating cupolas with 11-inch Schmidt-Cassegrain telescopes and serves as both a research laboratory for Aarhus University and a public museum, having been extensively restored and reopened in September 2023.

descriptions.name: Omni-Theatre, Science Centre Singapore
descriptions.description: Officially opened on December 10, 1987, the Omni-Theatre at Science Centre Singapore is Southeast Asia's first 8K 3D digital dome theatre with a 23-meter diameter seamless screen. This 221-seat facility offers immersive planetarium shows and digital movies, featuring a dome screen tilted at 30 degrees to maximize the viewing experience for visitors exploring space and celestial phenomena.

descriptions.name: Ondake Observatory
descriptions.description: Located on Fukuejima island in the Goto Islands of Nagasaki Prefecture, Japan, the Ondake Observatory sits near the 315-meter summit of Mt. Onidake. Opened to showcase the wonders of space to island visitors, it features a 60cm Newtonian telescope for seasonal stargazing and offers breathtaking 360-degree panoramic views ideal for observing celestial events including the Milky Way.

descriptions.name: Ondřejov Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1898 and located 35 kilometers southeast of Prague, the Ondrejov Observatory is the principal facility of the Czech Academy of Sciences' Astronomical Institute. Its 2-metre telescope, installed in 1967, was the 7th largest in the world at that time, and the observatory has discovered more than 700 minor planets while maintaining active research in solar physics, stellar physics, and planetary systems.

descriptions.name: Onsala Space Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1949 by professor Olof Rydbeck, Onsala Space Observatory is Sweden's national facility for radio astronomy, located 45 km south of Gothenburg. It operates two main radio telescopes including a 25.6m decimeter-wave telescope built in 1963 and a 20m millimetre-wave telescope, making it a crucial hub for international radio astronomy research and the Nordic ALMA node.

descriptions.name: Orchard Hill Observatory
descriptions.description: Constructed in 1965 at the highest point on the University of Massachusetts Amherst campus, Orchard Hill Observatory houses a 16-inch Cassegrain reflector optical telescope. The facility is used for teaching observational astronomy and is open to the public every Thursday evening from 7:30-9:30 p.m., operated by the Department of Astronomy at UMass Amherst.

descriptions.name: Orgonon
descriptions.description: Orgonon is a 175-acre property in Rangeley, Maine, built in 1948 and now serving as the Wilhelm Reich Museum. The main Orgone Energy Observatory is a fieldstone structure designed by architect James B. Bell where psychiatrist Wilhelm Reich conducted research on atmospheric orgone energy, and the site features three cloudbusters and operates as a public museum honoring Reich's scientific legacy.

descriptions.name: Orioloromano Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 2007 in Oriolo Romano, Viterbo, Italy, the Oriolo Romano Observatory is a fully robotic amateur astronomical facility featuring a Celestron 8-inch Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope and QSI WS40 CCD camera. It serves primarily for astronomical research and educational outreach while functioning as a local weather station, providing data for planning optimal observing conditions.

descriptions.name: Orwell Park observatory
descriptions.description: Located near Ipswich, Suffolk, the Orwell Park Observatory came into use in summer 1874 with engineering by Wilfrid Airy and architecture by John Macvicar Anderson. This prestigious Victorian observatory on the grounds of Orwell Park School features a 10-inch equatorial refractor and a 3-inch transit instrument, and has been recently reopened following restoration with support from the Orwell Astronomical Society.

descriptions.name: Oslo Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1815 at the University of Christiania, the Oslo Observatory was built in 1833 as an Empire-style structure with a central tower.
