Directed first by Christopher Hansteen, it contributed significantly to 19th and early 20th-century astrometry programs for stellar cataloguing and Norway's geodetic mapping, establishing itself as a foundational observatory for scientific observation and national surveying.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio astronomico di Cima Rest
descriptions.description: Located at 1,200 meters altitude on the Cima Rest plateau in the municipality of Magasa in Val Vestino, Italy, this observatory has served the public since 1997. Managed by the Associazione Astrofili di Salo, it features two structures: one with a 37.5cm Newton telescope for public viewing and another with a computerized 5.8cm telescope for research, open to visitors on Saturday evenings May through September.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio Astronomico di Gnosca
descriptions.description: Osservatorio Astronomico di Gnosca is located in Gnosca, Ticino, Switzerland, and serves as a research institution participating in international astronomical projects. The facility contributes observational data to peer-reviewed astronomical studies and operates as part of Switzerland's network of astronomical observatories in the southern Alpine region near the Italian border.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio astronomico di Isnello
descriptions.description: The Parco Astronomico GAL Hassin in Isnello, Sicily, opened in September 2016 as one of Italy's highest observatories featuring a digital planetarium, observation terrace with 12 instruments, a 2.3-meter radio telescope, and an outdoor laboratory. Located on the Madonie mountains identified by the Italian Space Agency in the 1970s for telescope placement, it has attracted nearly 100,000 visitors in a few years.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio astronomico di Loiano
descriptions.description: Built in the early 1900s as a branch of Bologna Observatory and inaugurated in 1936, Osservatorio Astronomico di Loiano sits 37 km from Bologna. It houses two major optical telescopes: a 60cm Zeiss reflector for educational outreach and the 152cm Cassini telescope, the second largest in Italy, dedicated to research and managed by INAF's Astrophysics Observatory.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio astronomico di Luserna San Giovanni
descriptions.description: Founded in 1989 by the Urania Amateur Astronomers Association in the Piedmont Alps of Luserna San Giovanni, this observatory acquired the Piedmont region's first planetarium in 1994. It features an 8-meter radio astronomy antenna the largest at an amateur level and is the only radioscope observatory of its kind in Piedmont, offering a unique facility for space signal detection.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio astronomico di monte Zugna
descriptions.description: Active since 1997 at 1,620 meters elevation on Monte Zugna, 40 minutes from Rovereto, the Osservatorio Astronomico di Monte Zugna is managed by the Civic Museum Foundation of Rovereto. Its 4-meter dome contains 3 telescopes including a solar telescope for observing sunspots and spectrum, with exceptional viewing conditions due to minimal light pollution and high altitude precision.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio astronomico di Remanzacco
descriptions.description: Founded in 1989 by the Friuli Astronomical Association, the Osservatorio astronomico di Remanzacco operates with advanced equipment including a 45cm Newton-Cassegrain telescope and 30cm Baker-Schmidt telescope. Located in Friuli-Venezia Giulia with MPC code 473, it conducts scientific research and organizes seminars, conferences, and observation evenings in collaboration with national and international organizations.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio astronomico Fondation Clément Fillietroz
descriptions.description: Located in Nus, Italy, at over 1,600 meters altitude in the Saint-Barthelemy valley, the Osservatorio astronomico Fondation Clement Fillietroz and accompanying planetarium are managed by the Clement Fillietroz Foundation established in 2003. It is Italy's only regional astronomical observatory with INAF-affiliated researchers, recognized with TripAdvisor Certificate of Excellence and Platinum Dark Sky Ambassador status from the International Astronomical Union.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio Astronomico Sormano
descriptions.description: Completed in 1987 by the Gruppo Astrofili Brianza at 1,000 meters elevation near the Swiss border, the Sormano Astronomical Observatory began observations in January 1989. Known for astrometric observations of minor planets and comets, it has enabled discoveries by prominent amateur astronomers using its 50-centimeter Cavagna Telescope and continues hosting research and educational outreach activities.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio Monte San Lorenzo
descriptions.description: Founded in 2000 and located 536 meters high on Monte San Lorenzo in Monte Grimano Terme, the Osservatorio Monte San Lorenzo Observatory is owned by the Railway Workers' Association of Rimini. It features a 530mm Ritchey-Chretien reflector and actively operates in supernova research, asteroids, astrometry, and spectrography, conducting outreach and dedicated observations for schools and the public.

descriptions.name: Osservatorio Polifunzionale del Chianti
descriptions.description: Inaugurated in 2010 between Florence and Siena in the Chianti Botanical Park, the Osservatorio Polifunzionale del Chianti serves as a multifunctional facility for research, education, and outreach. Its 80cm Marcon telescope and integrated weather and seismic stations make it the first Italian observatory with multisensory pathways for blind visitors, inaugurated in 2016 by Maestro Andrea Bocelli.

descriptions.name: Ostrava planetarium
descriptions.description: Founded in 1980 as part of VSB Technical University of Ostrava, the Planetarium Ostrava is the third largest planetarium in the Czech Republic. Located on the west edge of Ostrava in a forest park setting, it features modern projection technology creating a night sky as dark as few places in the world, with programs for schoolchildren, students, and the general public.

descriptions.name: Ostrowik Observatory
descriptions.description: Located 40 km southeast of Warsaw in Gmina Celestynow, the Ostrowik Observatory began operations in 1952 as part of the Astronomical Observatory of the University of Warsaw. Featuring a 60cm Cassegrain telescope installed in 1973, it conducts follow-up observations of transients discovered by the Gaia space mission and maintains the Polish Fireball Network for meteor and bolide observations spanning twenty years.

descriptions.name: Oukaïmden Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in the Atlas Mountains of Morocco at 2,750 meters altitude, Oukaimeden Observatory was registered with the International Astronomical Union in June 2007. Operated by Cadi Ayyad University in Marrakech, it hosts the TRAPPIST-North telescope which helped identify the TRAPPIST-1 exoplanet system in May 2016 and serves as a crucial hub for astronomical research in Africa.

descriptions.name: Owens Valley Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: Operated by Caltech's Astronomy Department near Big Pine, California, the Owens Valley Radio Observatory is one of the largest university-operated radio observatories in the world. A prototype 32-foot telescope moved to the site in 1958 launched an interferometry program that evolved into the Deep Synoptic Array and the Expanded Owens Valley Solar Array for studying fast radio bursts and solar radiation.

descriptions.name: Palomar Observatory
descriptions.description: Located on Palomar Mountain in San Diego County, California, and operated by Caltech since 1949, Palomar Observatory houses the iconic 200-inch (5.1m) Hale Telescope, which was the world's largest for 26 years. Operating multiple telescopes nightly for international research partners, it remains an active facility supporting the Zwicky Transient Facility and other cutting-edge astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Pan-STARRS
descriptions.description: Operated by the University of Hawaii's Institute for Astronomy, Pan-STARRS consists of two 1.8-meter telescopes on Haleakala, Maui, equipped with the world's largest digital camera with 1.4 billion pixels. As the world's leading Near-Earth Object discovery telescope, it discovers over half of large near-Earth Objects and more than half of new comets each year, with the DR2 data release comprising 1.6 petabytes of images.

descriptions.name: Panská Ves observatory
descriptions.description: Panska Ves observatory, located 60 km north of Prague near Duba, belongs to the Department of Ionosphere and Aeronomy of the Czech Academy of Sciences' Institute of Atmospheric Physics. Famous for its satellite receiving antennas (dishes), it has received signals since 1967 from scientific missions including APEX, INTERBALL, and CLUSTER, and currently hosts German airglow instruments GRIPS and FAIM.

descriptions.name: Paranal Observatory
descriptions.description: Operated by the European Southern Observatory, Paranal Observatory is located in the Atacama Desert of northern Chile at 2,635 meters altitude, 120 km south of Antofagasta. The flagship facility for European ground-based astronomy features the Very Large Telescope with four separate 8.2m telescopes, survey telescopes VISTA and VLT Survey Telescope, and hosts regular public visits on Saturdays.

descriptions.name: Parc Astronòmic Montsec
descriptions.description: Located in the municipality of Ager in la Noguera, Catalonia, the Parc Astronomic del Montsec is considered the most important astronomical facility in Catalonia with optimal observing conditions. It features a 50-centimeter Dall-Kirkham telescope and 20+ portable telescopes, won the 2020 Starlight Prize for Education, and received dual certification as a Starlight Reserve and Tourist Destination in 2013.

descriptions.name: Pardubice observatory
descriptions.description: The Pardubice Observatory is located in Pardubice, Czech Republic, and is classified as an Observatory and Planetarium facility. Ranking among the top attractions in Pardubice, it serves educational purposes and provides public viewing opportunities in the Pardubice Region.

descriptions.name: Paris Observatory, PSL University
descriptions.description: Founded in 1667, the Observatoire de Paris - PSL is a large public institution for research in astronomy, astrophysics, and meteorology with 750 researchers and staff. A founding member of PSL University and comparable to Harvard's Center for Astrophysics, it occupies three locations (Paris, Meudon since 1875, and Nancay radio station since 1953) conducting research across all astronomical disciplines.

descriptions.name: Parkes Observatory
descriptions.description: Located 20 kilometers north of Parkes, New South Wales, Australia, Parkes Observatory hosts Murriyang, a 64-meter radio telescope completed in 1961. Famous for receiving Apollo 11 moon landing television, it remains one of the world's best telescopes and the largest single-dish radio telescope in the southern hemisphere, operating daily to capture signals from distant galaxies, pulsars, and fast radio bursts.

descriptions.name: Paul Robinson Observatory
descriptions.description: Owned and operated by the New Jersey Astronomical Association at Voorhees State Park, the Paul Robinson Observatory features a 26-inch diameter primary mirror refractor telescope converted to Cassegrain configuration. With a massive German Equatorial mount weighing over four tons and towering fifteen feet, the facility hosts public viewing nights and hydrogen-alpha filtered solar viewing sessions for astronomy enthusiasts.

descriptions.name: Paul Wild Observatory
descriptions.description: Named after astronomer John Paul Wild, the Paul Wild Observatory is located 25 km west of Narrabri in NSW on Gomeroi Country and houses the Australia Telescope Compact Array with five movable antennas on a 3km rail track. Funded for Australia's Bicentennial and opened in 1988 by Prime Minister Bob Hawke, it is one of three facilities comprising the internationally renowned Australia Telescope National Facility.

descriptions.name: Peach Mountain Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1955 near Dexter, Michigan, approximately 20 kilometers northwest of Ann Arbor, Peach Mountain Observatory is operated by the University of Michigan for research and instruction. Its 26-meter radio telescope, built in 1958 with Navy funding, has monitored radio emissions from active extragalactic objects since the mid-1960s, while amateur astronomers operate the McMath telescope for dark sky observations.

descriptions.name: Penteli Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1937 with observations beginning in 1936, the Penteli Observatory is operated by the National Observatory of Athens about 18 kilometers from central Athens. Housing the historic 62.5-centimeter Newall refractor telescope relocated from Cambridge in 1959, its 14-meter dome has vertical movement for precise observations, and the facility has been open to the public since 1995 for sky observations and research.

descriptions.name: Perkins Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1923 by Hiram Perkins, Perkins Observatory in Delaware, Ohio, housed the third-largest telescope in the world when its 69-inch Perkins telescope came online in 1931. Operated by Ohio Wesleyan University, it serves as an active research and educational facility offering public programs (day and night) for astronomy enthusiasts located 10 miles north of Columbus on State Route 23.

descriptions.name: Perrott's Folly
descriptions.description: Built in 1758 in Edgbaston, Birmingham, Perrott's Folly is a 29-meter tall Grade II* listed tower later used as a weather station and observatory. In 1884, meteorologist Abraham Follet Osler began using it for observations as the Edgbaston Observatory, contributing to one of the world's first regular weather forecasting services until 1979, and is believed to have inspired Tolkien's Two Towers.

descriptions.name: Perth Observatory
descriptions.description: Western Australia's oldest observatory, founded in 1896 in West Perth and officially opened in 1900 by Premier John Forrest, Perth Observatory moved to Bickley in 1965 due to urban expansion. Now run by a volunteer community partnership, it hosts over 200 annual events drawing 10,000+ visitors, offering star-viewing and day tours while maintaining Australia's oldest continuing operating observatory.

descriptions.name: Peterberg Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1977 in Saarland, Germany, the Sternwarte Peterberg operates on the 584-meter high Peterberg near Braunshausen and was opened in 1997 after five years of construction. With 160 members, it provides public astronomy talks and group sessions under dark rural skies with panoramic views, and participates in the Sankt Wendeler SternenLand project to combat light pollution.

descriptions.name: Pic du Midi Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 2,877 meters atop Pic du Midi de Bigorre in the French Pyrenees, this observatory dates back to 1774 when scientists first climbed to study atmospheric pressure. With construction beginning in 1878, it houses the 2-meter Bernard Lyot Telescope, the largest in France, and was designated as the sixth International Dark Sky Reserve in 2013, the first in Europe, allowing overnight stays for visitors.

descriptions.name: Pico dos Dias Observatory
descriptions.description: Operating since 1980 in Minas Gerais, Brazil, at 1,864 meters altitude, Pico dos Dias Observatory is operated by Brazil's National Astrophysical Laboratory (LNA). Home to the 1.6-meter Perkin-Elmer, the largest optical telescope in Brazilian territory, it received its first CCD detector in 1988 and now includes the Panoramic Electro Optical System for space debris monitoring since 2017.

descriptions.name: Pierre Auger Observatory
descriptions.description: Located on the Pampa Amarilla plain in Malargue, Mendoza, Argentina, the Pierre Auger Cosmic Ray Observatory is the world's largest cosmic ray observatory studying ultra-high-energy cosmic rays. With construction beginning in 2000 and production-grade data collection from 2005, its 1,660 water Cherenkov detectors span 3,000 km2, coupled with 27 fluorescence telescopes for comprehensive particle detection and analysis.

descriptions.name: Pierre Kauffman Radio Observatory
descriptions.description: The Pierre Kauffman Radio Observatory, renamed in 2016 in honor of physicist Pierre Kauffman, is located in Atibaia, Sao Paulo, Brazil. Operating a 13.7-meter dish antenna in a radome (replaced in 1990) and observing across multiple frequency bands from 18 to 50 GHz, it conducts astronomical and solar monitoring with specialized Solar Patrol Equipment for continuous sun observation.

descriptions.name: Pine Mountain Observatory
descriptions.description: Operated by the University of Oregon Department of Physics in the Deschutes National Forest, Pine Mountain Observatory is located 26 miles southeast of Bend at the summit of Pine Mountain. Featuring a 24-inch Cassegrain reflector installed in 1967 and a restored 15-inch Fecker Cassegrain, it provides dark sky conditions and is open two weekends monthly from late May through September with adjacent forest service camping.

descriptions.name: Piombino Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1975 on the promontory of Piombino in southern Tuscany, Italy, the Punta Falcone Astronomical Observatory adapted an old coastal naval defense structure. The association upgraded facilities by installing a new dome in 1986 and discovered an underground military communications station that became its headquarters, continuing to serve astronomy enthusiasts exploring the Etruscan Coast.

descriptions.name: Pises Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 1,300 meters altitude in Aumessas in the Parc National des Cevennes, France, Pises Observatory began operations in 1985 with optical telescope and CCD equipment for asteroid surveys. It has discovered 41 minor planets including 18623 Pises and 20488 Pic-du-Midi, and maintains research partnerships with regional societies while conducting educational programs for asteroid threat assessment.

descriptions.name: Pistoia Mountains Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1991 in San Marcello Piteglio, Tuscany, at 900-950 meters altitude, the Pistoia Mountains Astronomical Observatory features two 5-meter rotating domes with 40 and 60-centimeter telescopes for educational and scientific work. Home to the GAMP amateur astronomers group, it received the 2019 International Shoemaker Neo Grant award for asteroid search merits and hosts conferences and seminars for public engagement.

descriptions.name: Piszkéstető Station
descriptions.description: Located in the Matra Mountains 80 kilometers northeast of Budapest, Hungary, Piszkesteto Station has operated since 1958 as a facility of Konkoly Observatory. Its 102-centimeter Ritchey-Chretien-Coude telescope remains Hungary's largest, and the station is renowned for discovering impactor asteroids before impact: 2022 EB5, 2023 CX1, and 2024 BX1, with 19 total minor planet discoveries credited to the facility.

descriptions.name: Planetarium Bad Salzungen
descriptions.description: Planetarium Bad Salzungen is an educational astronomical facility in Thuringia, Germany, established in 1984 and located on the scenic Burgsee lake. The planetarium features a projector from 1951 constructed by Carl Zeiss Jena and operates under a 8-meter dome with seating for up to 50 guests.

descriptions.name: Planetarium Halle-Kanena
descriptions.description: The Astronomische Station Johannes Kepler Kanena in Halle, Germany was constructed in 1961-1963 as the first school planetarium in the German Democratic Republic. This historic facility features approximately 60 seats under an 8-meter dome and continues to offer regular astronomical discussion sessions and night sky observations.

descriptions.name: Planetarium Negara
descriptions.description: Planetarium Negara is Malaysia's national planetarium in Kuala Lumpur, featuring a distinctive blue dome situated on top of a hill in Lake Gardens. The facility includes a 14-inch telescope, exhibits on Malaysia's space program including the first national satellite, and an ancient observatory park with a replica of Stonehenge.

descriptions.name: Planetarium České Budějovice
descriptions.description: The Observatory and Planetarium Ceske Budejovice was founded in 1937 as the second oldest public observatory in Bohemia. The facility expanded in 1971 with the addition of a planetarium and cinema theater, and operates a branch observatory at Klet for monitoring comets and asteroids.

descriptions.name: planetary astronomical observatory of Anzi
descriptions.description: The Planetary Astronomical Observatory of Anzi is located in Basilicata, Italy at high altitude in the village of Anzi. The facility doubles as both a planetarium and astronomical observatory, utilizing the location's elevation and low light pollution to provide clear celestial observations.

descriptions.name: Planetology and Astrophysics Institute of Grenoble
descriptions.description: The Institute for Planetary Sciences and Astrophysics of Grenoble (IPAG) was established in 2011 from the merger of two laboratories and employs approximately 170 researchers. The institute conducts research on solar system formation, exoplanets, and planetary physics from its campus location in the French Alps.

descriptions.name: Planetron
descriptions.description: Planetron is a planetarium and astronomical observatory located in Dwingeloo, Netherlands, featuring a 15-meter dome. The facility provides visitors with opportunities to explore the sky through specialized telescopes and projection systems.

descriptions.name: Port-Bizet
descriptions.description: Port-Bizet is a seismographic station located on Ile Longue in the Kerguelen Islands. Established in the 1950s as part of early scientific missions, the facility served as lodging for a shepherd between 1955 and 2012 and remains an isolated site accessible only by sea.

descriptions.name: Poznań Observatory
descriptions.description: Poznan Observatory was founded in 1919 by the Jesuit College's astronomical equipment dating back to the 18th century. The observatory is now operated by Adam Mickiewicz University's physics department and specializes in satellite dynamics and near-Earth asteroid research through facilities in Borowiec and Arizona.

descriptions.name: Prenzlau observatory
descriptions.description: The Prenzlau observatory in Brandenburg, Germany is housed in the Steintorturm, a tower first mentioned in 1306 that was originally part of the city's gate complex. Local astronomers operate the facility as a public observatory serving both astronomical observation and cultural purposes.

descriptions.name: Prescott Observatory
descriptions.description: Prescott Observatory in Arizona features a 16-inch computerized Meade telescope and is ranked among the top observatories in the United States. The facility also includes the Jim and Linda Lee Planetarium with 360-degree 4K resolution capability and is affiliated with Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University.

descriptions.name: Prince Edward Point National Wildlife Area
descriptions.description: Prince Edward Point National Wildlife Area in Ontario, Canada was established in 1978 and encompasses 546 hectares of diverse habitats. The Prince Edward Point Bird Observatory, established in 1995, bands migratory songbirds and records over 300 bird species.

descriptions.name: Principia Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Principia Astronomical Observatory is located on the Principia College campus in Elsah, Illinois and was installed in 1998. The facility features a 16-inch Ritchey-Chretien telescope and has been used for research on minor planets submitted to the International Astronomical Union.

descriptions.name: Prishtina Observatory
descriptions.description: Prishtina Observatory in Kosovo was established in 1977 and reopened in 2022 after 35 years. A new facility located in Shtime, 32 km from Pristina, opened in 2024 with a 50-seat planetarium under a 9-meter dome and a 6-meter dome housing a 14-inch telescope.

descriptions.name: Private Sternwarte (Zeppelinstraße 7)
descriptions.description: A private observatory located in Germany, representing the tradition of amateur astronomical facilities that contribute to citizen science and astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Provencal Baronnies Observatory
descriptions.description: The Provencal Baronnies Observatory is located in Moydans, France at 800 meters elevation on the lavender roads of Pays du Buech. The facility features a 0.8-meter telescope, five guest rooms named after celestial bodies, and conducts nighttime astronomical observations and stargazing training.

descriptions.name: Public Observatory Mainz
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte (Public Observatory) Mainz in Germany is located in a 35-meter high tower of the Anne-Frank-Schule and offers regular public viewing of the night sky. The facility provides opportunities to observe and learn about astronomical phenomena.

descriptions.name: Public Observatory Mercury
descriptions.description: Public Observatory Mercury refers to public observatories offering Mercury viewing opportunities, including the Phoebe Waterman Haas Public Observatory at the National Air and Space Museum. These observatories provide safe viewing of Mercury transits and observations during favorable conditions.

descriptions.name: Public Observatory Regensburg
descriptions.description: Public Observatory Regensburg, located in Bavaria, Germany, dates back to 1774 when Saint Emmeram's Abbey dedicated towers to astronomical observations. The facility moved to the Placidustower in the city wall in 1812 and is now operated by a volunteer club that offers free admission on Friday evenings.

descriptions.name: Puckett Observatory
descriptions.description: Puckett Observatory is a private facility located in Georgia, USA owned by Tim Puckett. The observatory specializes in comet study and supernova discovery, housing a 24-inch Ritchey-Chretien telescope and operating the world-renowned Puckett Observatory World Supernova Search.

descriptions.name: Pujalt Observatory
descriptions.description: Pujalt Observatory in Catalonia, Spain is both a meteorological and astronomical observatory located at 750 meters elevation. Opened in 2004, the facility conducts climate research and offers telescope observations, astronomy workshops, and a 360-degree planetarium experience.

descriptions.name: Pula Observatory
descriptions.description: Pula Observatory in Croatia was established in 1869 as the oldest observatory in the country and served the Imperial and Royal Hydrographic Institute of the Navy. The facility discovered 28 planetoids and provided critical services including timekeeping, meteorology, and geomagnetic measurements.

descriptions.name: Pulkovo Observatory
descriptions.description: Pulkovo Observatory was founded in 1839 near Saint Petersburg by order of Emperor Nicholas I and was equipped with state-of-the-art telescopes for the time. The facility established the Pulkovo Meridian, which served as the reference for all Russian geographical maps, and was reconstructed after World War II destruction.

descriptions.name: Purgathofer-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Purgathofer-Sternwarte in Klosterneuburg, Austria is the second-largest private observatory in Europe, built between 1982 and 1989. The facility houses a 1-meter reflecting telescope and conducts research on supernovae, variable stars, and performs astrometry on comets and minor planets.

descriptions.name: Purple Mountain Observatory
descriptions.description: Purple Mountain Observatory in Nanjing, China was established in 1934 as the nation's first modern astronomical observatory. Known as the 'Cradle of Modern Astronomy in China,' the facility discovered several periodic comets and asteroids and conducts both open science and space domain awareness activities.

descriptions.name: Putrajaya International Convention Centre
descriptions.description: Putrajaya International Convention Centre is a major convention facility in Putrajaya, Malaysia completed in 2003. The building, designed to resemble a royal belt buckle, sits on Putrajaya's highest peak and provides state-of-the-art facilities for conferences and events.

descriptions.name: Pyramid International Laboratory-Observatory
descriptions.description: The International Pyramid Laboratory-Observatory is located at 4,980 meters on Mount Everest's southern slope in Nepal and was inaugurated in 1990. The unique pyramidal structure is self-sufficient with hybrid energy systems and has hosted over 500 scientific missions in fields including meteorology, geology, and biology.

descriptions.name: Qingdao Observatory
descriptions.description: Qingdao Observatory was originally built by Germany in 1898 and transferred to Chinese control in 1924. The facility was one of three major observatories in the far east and played a crucial role in establishing China's first time service system in 1924.

descriptions.name: Qism Helwan
descriptions.description: Qism Helwan, also known as the Helwan Khedivial Observatory in Egypt, was established in 1903-1904 about 30 kilometers south of Cairo. The facility houses a 30-inch telescope that was the first to record Halley's comet in 1909 and 1911.

descriptions.name: Quito Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Quito Astronomical Observatory was founded in 1873 as one of South America's oldest observatories and is based at the National Polytechnic School. The facility was completely renovated in 2009 and features the 24-centimeter Merz Equatorial Telescope manufactured in 1875 in Munich.

descriptions.name: Radcliffe Observatory
descriptions.description: Radcliffe Observatory in Oxford, England was commissioned in 1675 and completed in 1794, featuring a distinctive octagonal tower based on Athens' Tower of the Winds. The observatory holds the UK's longest unbroken daily weather record and is now part of Green Templeton College.

descriptions.name: Radiosternwarte Kiel
descriptions.description: Radiosternwarte Kiel was a radio observatory facility of Christian-Albrechts-Universitat operating from approximately 1950 to 1976. The facility housed two radiotelescopes and was used to map galactic and extragalactic radio radiation during its operational period.

descriptions.name: Real Instituto y Observatorio de la Armada
descriptions.description: Real Instituto y Observatorio de la Armada in San Fernando, Spain was founded in 1753 making it the oldest observatory in Spain. The facility established the Cadiz meridian which governed Spanish cartography until 1884 and continues to provide time service and conduct space debris monitoring.

descriptions.name: Regiomontanus-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Regiomontanus-Sternwarte in Nuremberg, Germany is a public observatory staffed entirely by volunteers offering regular Friday and Saturday evening lectures and observations. The facility features a 60-centimeter main telescope installed during a 2004 renovation and hosts workshops and guided tours.

descriptions.name: Remplin Observatory
descriptions.description: Remplin Observatory in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany is the oldest preserved observatory building in the region, built in 1793 by Count Frederick II von Hahn. At the time, it was the third-largest observatory outside of Great Britain and continues to provide public solar and night sky observations.

descriptions.name: Reutlingen Observatory and Planetarium
descriptions.description: Reutlingen Observatory and Planetarium in Baden-Wurttemberg, Germany was founded in 1956 with a planetarium added in 1966. The facility underwent major renovation in 2010 and features a 50-centimeter mirror telescope, digital planetarium, and multiple portable telescopes operated by 15 volunteers.

descriptions.name: Rihlaperä Observatory
descriptions.description: Rihlapera Observatory in Jyvaskyla, Finland was built in the early 1960s and officially opened in 1963. The facility is operated by a local organization called Sirius and hosts public observing events during autumn and winter months.

descriptions.name: RIT Observatory
descriptions.description: RIT Observatory at Rochester Institute of Technology in New York features two computer-controlled telescopes including a 14-inch Celestron and 12-inch Meade. The facility promotes undergraduate teaching and research in astrophysical sciences and holds quarterly public open houses.

descriptions.name: Ritter Observatory
descriptions.description: Ritter Observatory at the University of Toledo in Ohio features a 1.06-meter Ritchey-Chretien telescope built in 1967 and installed in 1968. The facility conducts long-term spectroscopic monitoring of stars and resumed public telescope viewing in 2024.

descriptions.name: Robert-Mayer-Volks- und Schulsternwarte Heilbronn
descriptions.description: Robert-Mayer-Volks- und Schulsternwarte Heilbronn in Germany is a public observatory founded over 100 years ago and operated by an association dedicated to astronomical education. The facility attracts over 4,000 annual visitors and features a historic two-meter diameter hollow globe with 170 marked stars.

descriptions.name: Rome Observatory
descriptions.description: Rome Observatory was founded in 1938 at Villa Mellini in Rome and expanded to three sites including Monte Porzio Catone. The facility operates interactive astronomy labs and hosts 5,000 to 10,000 student visitors annually through its educational programs.

descriptions.name: Roque de los Muchachos Observatory
descriptions.description: Roque de los Muchachos Observatory is located on La Palma in the Canary Islands at 2,396 meters elevation within a UNESCO Starlight Reserve. The facility hosts one of the world's largest telescope arrays including the 10.4-meter Gran Telescopio Canarias and was established in 1985.

descriptions.name: Royal Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded by King Charles II in 1675 to improve navigation, this is Britain's oldest scientific institution and the original home of the Prime Meridian (0° longitude) and Greenwich Mean Time. Designed by Sir Christopher Wren with John Flamsteed as its first Astronomer Royal, the observatory moved to Sussex in 1947 due to light pollution and now operates primarily as a museum within Royal Museums Greenwich.

descriptions.name: Royal Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1822 when George IV granted royal status, the observatory moved to its current Blackford Hill location in 1896 thanks to the Earl of Crawford's donation of instruments and library. Today it houses the UK Astronomy Technology Centre (leading work on instruments like JWST's MIRI), the University of Edinburgh's Institute for Astronomy, and a visitor centre with the historic Crawford Collection of rare astronomical books.

descriptions.name: Royal Observatory of Belgium
descriptions.description: Royal Observatory of Belgium has been situated in the Uccle municipality of Brussels since 1890 and was originally founded in 1826. The facility operates the Brussels Planetarium integrated since 1979 and conducts research in astronomy, seismology, and space weather.

descriptions.name: Royal Observatory of Madrid
descriptions.description: Royal Observatory of Madrid was founded in 1790 and designed by Juan de Villanueva as a highlight of Spanish neoclassical architecture. The facility suffered damage during the Peninsular War but underwent refoundation in the mid-19th century and serves as the seat of the Spanish National Observatory.

descriptions.name: Royal Observatory, Cape of Good Hope
descriptions.description: Royal Observatory, Cape of Good Hope was founded in 1820 as the first permanent observatory in the southern hemisphere. The facility served astrometric purposes for maritime navigation and was amalgamated with the Republic Observatory Johannesburg in 1972 to form the South African Astronomical Observatory.

descriptions.name: Rozhen Observatory
descriptions.description: Rozhen Observatory in Bulgaria was officially opened in 1981 and is one of the largest observatories in Southeastern Europe with approximately 50 active astronomers. Located at 1,759 meters in the Rhodope Mountains, the facility houses a 2-meter Ritchey-Chretien telescope and discovered the minor planet 6267 Rozhen.

descriptions.name: Rožňava observatory
descriptions.description: Roznava observatory is an astronomical observatory located in the town of Roznava in eastern Slovakia. The facility serves as a notable landmark in this historic mining town and provides astronomical observation opportunities.

descriptions.name: Rutherfurd Observatory
descriptions.description: Rutherfurd Observatory is the astronomical facility maintained by Columbia University and named after Lewis Morris Rutherfurd, an early astrophotographer. Located atop Pupin Hall since 1927, the observatory houses an 11-inch Celestron Schmidt-Cassegrain and 14-inch Meade Schmidt-Cassegrain and offers public lectures and stargazing events.

descriptions.name: Sadabell Astronomical Society
descriptions.description: The Sadabell Astronomical Society operates a recognized astronomical observatory in Catalonia, Spain. As one of the oldest amateur astronomical organizations, it carries the MPC code 619 and continues to contribute to amateur astronomical research and education in the region.

descriptions.name: Saji Observatory
descriptions.description: Saji Observatory, established in July 1994 in Tottori, Japan, is one of Japan's leading open-air astronomical facilities. Featuring a 103-cm reflecting telescope and known for having some of the clearest starry skies in Japan, it operates Saji Astro Park for public astronomy education.

descriptions.name: Saltsjöbaden Observatory
descriptions.description: The Saltsjobaden Observatory, inaugurated in 1931 near Stockholm, Sweden, housed world-class instruments including a 40-inch Grubb reflector and 24/20-inch Grubb double refractor. Though the astronomy department relocated in 2001, the historic facility remains preserved with amateur astronomers maintaining the telescopes.

descriptions.name: San José Observatory
descriptions.description: Lick Observatory, located on Mount Hamilton near San Jose, California, became the world's first permanently occupied mountaintop observatory when it opened in 1888. Its 36-inch refractor telescope was the largest of its kind and enabled notable discoveries including Jupiter's fifth moon Amalthea in 1892.

descriptions.name: San Vittore Observatory
descriptions.description: San Vittore Observatory was a private astronomical observatory near Bologna, Italy, operating between 1969 and 2004. Located at 280 meters altitude near the historic Sant Vittore oratory, it conducted astronomical research and held MPC code 552.

descriptions.name: Santa Lucia Stroncone Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1975 by entrepreneur Antonio Vagnozzi in Umbria, Italy, the Santa Lucia Stroncone Astronomical Observatory is accredited with discovering 53 asteroids and two supernovae. Equipped with a 500mm Ritchey-Chretien telescope and three smaller instruments, it remains an active research facility.

descriptions.name: Sapporo Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Sapporo City Astronomical Observatory, completed in 1958 and located in Nakajima Park, is Japan's smallest public observatory. Equipped with a 20-cm refracting telescope, it offers free public stargazing on designated nights throughout the year.

descriptions.name: Sapporo Science Center
descriptions.description: Sapporo Science Center, reopened in 2016 after renovation, features Hokkaido's largest planetarium with an 18-meter dome. Its state-of-the-art projector system can display approximately 100 million stars and shows programs in Japanese for children and astronomy enthusiasts.

descriptions.name: SARA-CT
descriptions.description: The 0.6-meter SARA Cerro Tololo Telescope at Cerro Tololo Inter-American Observatory in Chile is operated by the Southeastern Association for Research in Astronomy (SARA) consortium. Upgraded from the original 1968 Lowell 24-inch telescope, it provides remote internet access for educational observations.

descriptions.name: SARA-KP
descriptions.description: SARA-KP is the 0.9-meter Cassegrain reflector telescope operated by the Southeastern Association for Research in Astronomy at Kitt Peak in Arizona. Located at 6,800 feet elevation, it offers remote observing capabilities allowing universities to conduct observations from their labs on assigned nights.

descriptions.name: Satellite Communications Center, Medvezh'i Ozyora
descriptions.description: The Satellite Communications Center at Medvezh'i Ozyora near Moscow, established in 1967, is one of Russia's largest teleports. In 1995, it became a major branch of the Russian Satellite Communications Company (RSCC), providing comprehensive broadcast and communication services.

descriptions.name: Sayan Solar Observatory
descriptions.description: The Sayan Solar Observatory, established in 1966 in Buryatia, Russia at 2,000 meters elevation, operates the world's largest Lyot coronagraph and advanced infrared telescopes. In 2023, construction began on Eurasia's largest solar telescope at the same location, expected to complete by 2030.

descriptions.name: Schulsternwarte „Johannes Franz“
descriptions.description: The Schulsternwarte 'Johannes Franz' in Bautzen, Germany, refounded in 1922, is one of the oldest and largest school observatories in Germany. From 1958-1982, it participated in international satellite optical tracking for the Soviet Academy of Sciences.

descriptions.name: Scottish Dark Sky Observatory
descriptions.description: The Scottish Dark Sky Observatory near Loch Doon in East Ayrshire was constructed in 2012 and expanded with a planetarium in 2017. After being destroyed by fire, a new facility is planned for Clatteringshaws Loch within the Galloway Forest Park, Scotland's only Gold Tier Dark Sky Park.

descriptions.name: Sears Tower – Harvard Observatory
descriptions.description: The Sears Tower-Harvard Observatory, a historic astronomical facility in Cambridge, Massachusetts, was designed by Isaiah Rogers and built in 1843. Its dome originally housed a 15-inch telescope, making it state-of-the-art for its era and a significant part of Harvard Observatory's complex.

descriptions.name: Seeberg Observatory
descriptions.description: Seeberg Observatory near Gotha, Germany, was founded in 1787 by Duke Ernest II with Franz Xaver von Zach as its first astronomer. It became a center of European astronomy and hosted the first European congress of astronomers in 1798, though it closed in 1934.

descriptions.name: Sendai Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Sendai Astronomical Observatory, opened in 1955 in Miyagi, Japan, features a 1.3-meter Hitomi telescope and extensive exhibition halls. The first planetarium in Tohoku opened here in 1968, and the observatory has discovered two asteroids and a minor planet over 50 years of operation.

descriptions.name: Sendai Space Museum
descriptions.description: Sendai Space Museum houses a planetarium that projects powerful images of the starry sky with various programs for different audiences. Located in Sendai, Miyagi Prefecture, it continues Sendai's centuries-old astronomical tradition that began with advisors to the powerful Date samurai clan.

descriptions.name: Shamakhy Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: Shamakhy Astrophysical Observatory, established in 1959 in the Caucasus Mountains of Azerbaijan, is named after Nasreddin Tusi. Located at 1,500 meters with 190-200 clear nights annually, it features a 2-meter Carl Zeiss telescope and conducts active research in stellar astronomy and astrophysics.

descriptions.name: Shanghai Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Shanghai Astronomical Observatory, officially established in 1962, merged the historic Xujiahui Observatory (founded 1872) and Sheshan Observatory (founded 1900). It operates major VLBI stations and maintains research stations across China for astro-geodynamics, cosmology, and planetary science.

descriptions.name: Shattuck Observatory
descriptions.description: Shattuck Observatory, built in 1854 at Dartmouth College in Hanover, New Hampshire, was designed by Boston architect G.J.F. Bryant. Notable for its director Edwin Brant Frost who later led Yerkes Observatory, it remains open for public observation on Friday evenings.

descriptions.name: Sheshan Observatory
descriptions.description: Sheshan Observatory, built by French Jesuits around 1899 on Sheshan Hill in Shanghai, housed the 'First Lens in the Far East' a 40-centimeter refracting telescope that captured nearly 7,000 astronomical photographs. Now part of Shanghai Astronomical Observatory, it reopened as a museum in 2023.

descriptions.name: Shosanbetsu observatory
descriptions.description: Shosanbetsu Observatory, located in a fishing village in northern Hokkaido, Japan, features a 65-centimeter reflecting telescope in a 360-degree rotating dome. The 'My Stars System' allows visitors to register star names, and Asteroid 6158 Shosanbetsu was named for the village.

descriptions.name: Siding Spring Observatory
descriptions.description: Siding Spring Observatory, located at 1,165 meters on Mount Woorut near Coonabarabran, NSW, Australia, is the nation's largest optical observatory. Home to the 3.9-meter Anglo Australian Telescope and multiple international research facilities, it sits within the heritage-listed Warrumbungle National Park.

descriptions.name: Sierra Nevada Observatory
descriptions.description: Sierra Nevada Observatory, established in 1981 at 2,896 meters altitude in Granada, Spain, is operated by the Instituto de Astrofisica de Andalucia. Equipped with 1.5m and 0.9m Nasmyth telescopes, it participates in the SMART project for detecting meteors and fireballs.

descriptions.name: Silesian Planetarium
descriptions.description: The Silesian Planetarium, founded December 4, 1955 in Chorzow, Poland, is the largest and oldest planetarium in Poland. Featuring a 23-meter high dome with a Carl Zeiss projector displaying over 8,000 stars, it also houses Poland's largest refractor telescope with a 30-centimeter diameter.

descriptions.name: Siligo astronomical observatory
descriptions.description: The Siligo astronomical observatory in Sardinia, Italy, operated by the Societa Astronomica Turritana since 1999, features a 45-centimeter diameter Ritchey-Chretien telescope. The association maintains multiple other instrument configurations and regularly organizes public stargazing events throughout Sardinia.

descriptions.name: Simeiz Observatory
descriptions.description: Simeiz Observatory, located on Mount Koshka in Crimea at 360 meters altitude, was established in 1908 and became an astrophysical department of Pulkovo Observatory in 1912. After World War II restoration, it contributed to stellar catalogues including the famous Simeis catalog of galactic emission nebulae.

descriptions.name: Skalnate Pleso observatory
descriptions.description: Skalnate pleso Observatory, founded in 1943 by Antonin Becvar at 1,786 meters in Slovakia's Tatra Mountains, is renowned for visual comet hunting and astrometric observations of minor planets. The asteroid 2619 Skalnate Pleso was named in the observatory's honor.

descriptions.name: Skinakas Observatory
descriptions.description: Skinakas Observatory, inaugurated April 12, 1986 on Psiloritis mountain in Crete, Greece at 1,750 meters altitude, is equipped with 1.3m and 1m Ritchey-Chretien telescopes. By 2024, its observations contributed to 293 refereed publications, making it Greece's most productive observatory.

descriptions.name: Sky's the Limit Observatory and Nature Center
descriptions.description: Sky's The Limit Observatory & Nature Center in Twentynine Palms, California is a non-profit facility featuring a 14-inch Cassegrain telescope and a 20-billion-to-1 scale solar system model. Located adjacent to Joshua Tree National Park's International Dark Sky Park, it offers stargazing programs on Saturday nights.

descriptions.name: SkyMapper
descriptions.description: SkyMapper is a fully automated 1.35-meter wide-angle telescope at Siding Spring Observatory in New South Wales, Australia, operated by the Australian National University. Its 268-million pixel camera with six filters conducts a deep multi-epoch survey of the southern sky, releasing data to enable discoveries about dark energy and galactic structure.

descriptions.name: Slovak Central Observatory Hurbanovo
descriptions.description: The Slovak Central Observatory in Hurbanovo, founded in 1871, is one of Europe's first astrophysical observatories and now serves as the national methodological center for Slovak observatories and planetariums. It conducts research in solar physics, stellar astronomy, and interplanetary matter.

descriptions.name: Smeetoren
descriptions.description: The Smeetoren, built between 1122-1145 as a rampart tower in Utrecht, Netherlands, was converted into the second university observatory in the world. Though insufficient for advanced research, its platform served until 1854 when the observatory relocated to Sonnenborgh.

descriptions.name: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory (SAO), established in 1890 in Washington D.C., relocated to Cambridge, Massachusetts in 1955 and now operates as the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian. It conducts research on exoplanets, solar activity, asteroids, and extreme cosmic phenomena.

descriptions.name: Sohland/Spree observatory
descriptions.description: The Bruno Burgel Observatory in Sohland an der Spree, Germany, inaugurated in 1963, features wheelchair-accessible grounds and a 4.2-kilometer planetary path. It offers educational programs for local schools and regular evening observation sessions for public stargazing.

descriptions.name: Solar Observatory - Tower 4 - Appearance
descriptions.description: The Solar Observatory Tower at Meudon, a 36.47-meter reinforced concrete structure built 1963-1969, houses a vertical coude telescope with a 60-centimeter mirror. Its 14-meter spectrograph enables high-resolution solar physics research and continues to serve both scientific and educational purposes.

descriptions.name: Solar Observatory Tower Meudon
descriptions.description: The Solar Observatory Tower Meudon in France features a vertical coude telescope with a 60cm mirror and a coelostat system that reflects sunlight through the building. Commissioned in 1969, it remains an outstanding instrument for teaching solar physics methods with spectacular resolution capabilities.

descriptions.name: Sommers–Bausch Observatory
descriptions.description: Sommers-Bausch Observatory at the University of Colorado, Boulder was completed in 1953 and named after donors Elmer E. Sommers and Carl L. Bausch. Equipped with modern 20-inch and 24-inch telescopes, it provides hands-on observational experience for undergraduate students and hosts free public open houses on Friday nights.

descriptions.name: Sonneberg Observatory
descriptions.description: Sonneberg Observatory, established in 1925 in Thuringia, Germany, conducts long-term studies of variable stars and maintains one of the largest archives of astronomical plates. Its Sky Patrol program, running since 1926, continues to the present, contributing significantly to variable star research.

descriptions.name: Sonnenobservatorium - Altbau mit Turm 1- äußere Erscheinung
descriptions.description: The Sonneberg Observatory in Germany, founded in 1925, features one of the world's largest collections of astronomical plates documenting variable stars. Its continuous monitoring programs, including the Sonneberg Sky Patrol since 1926, provide invaluable data for stellar research and astronomy education.

descriptions.name: Sonoma State Observatory
descriptions.description: Sonoma State Observatory, located in Rohnert Park, California, reopened in 2017 after many years of closure with significant upgrades including a slide-off pitched roof. Approximately 1,000 students use the facility annually for astronomy courses, and free public viewing nights are held each semester.

descriptions.name: South African Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The South African Astronomical Observatory (SAAO), established in 1972, is South Africa's national optical and infrared astronomy center with primary facilities in Sutherland. Its headquarters in Cape Town occupies the grounds of the historic Royal Observatory established in 1820.

descriptions.name: South cupola of Brno Observatory and Planetarium
descriptions.description: The South African Astronomical Observatory operates from historic facilities in Cape Town, including the original Royal Observatory campus established in 1820. Headquartered here, it coordinates national astronomical research while maintaining historic telescopes and a museum.

descriptions.name: Southern African Large Telescope
descriptions.description: The Southern African Large Telescope (SALT), inaugurated November 10, 2005 near Sutherland, South Africa, is the largest optical telescope in the Southern Hemisphere. With a 9.2-meter aperture consisting of 91 hexagonal segments, it enables spectroscopic observations of objects a billion times fainter than unaided eye visibility.

descriptions.name: Spanish National Observatory
descriptions.description: The Spanish National Observatory at Calar Alto, Spain's largest astronomical facility, opened in July 1975 at 2,168 meters altitude in the Sierra de los Filabres. With 3.5m, 2.2m, and 1.23m telescopes, it conducts research including the CARMENES exoplanet survey and CALIFA galaxy observations.

descriptions.name: Special Astrophysical Observatory of the Russian Academy of Science
descriptions.description: The Special Astrophysical Observatory of the Russian Academy of Science, established in 1966 in Zelenchukskaya, is Russia's largest ground-based astronomical center. Operating the 6-meter BTA optical telescope and the 600-meter RATAN-600 radio telescope, it employs over 430 people including 100+ researchers.

descriptions.name: SPECULOOS-South Observatory
descriptions.description: SPECULOOS-South Observatory at ESO's Paranal Observatory in Chile comprises four 1-meter robotic Ritchey-Chretien telescopes named after Jupiter's moons (Io, Europa, Ganymede, Callisto). Dedicated to detecting terrestrial exoplanets around ultracool stars, it discovered super-Earths in the habitable zone by 2022.

descriptions.name: Sphinx Observatory
descriptions.description: Sphinx Observatory at 3,571 meters on Jungfraujoch in Switzerland is one of the world's highest observatories, completed in 1937. Equipped with a 76-centimeter Cassegrain/Coude telescope, it contributed the first precise evidence for the K-meson's existence in 1949 and remains crucial for solar and atmospheric research.

descriptions.name: Sproul Observatory
descriptions.description: Sproul Observatory at Swarthmore College in Pennsylvania, built in 1906 to house a 24-inch telescope, dominated as the largest on the East Coast when the telescope arrived in 1913. Though superseded by the 2009 Peter van de Kamp Observatory, the original facility is undergoing renovation into a cultural center.

descriptions.name: St. Andrews observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1940 at the University of St Andrews in Scotland, the observatory marked the return of astronomical research to the university after a 270-year gap since James Gregory's 17th-century attempts. The facility, including the renowned James Gregory Telescope constructed in 1962, has been pivotal in advancing observational astronomy.

descriptions.name: St. Margarethen observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Binningen near Basel, Switzerland, the St. Margarethen Observatory was established in 1928 as the successor to the Bernoullianum observatory and was operated by the University of Basel. After the university's Astronomical Institute dissolved in 2007, it has been operated by the Basel Astronomical Association.

descriptions.name: Star Square Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Star Square Astronomical Observatory is an amateur astronomical observation facility dedicated to public outreach and star viewing. The observatory continues to serve its community with regular viewing sessions and astronomy programs.

descriptions.name: Stara Lesna observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Vysoke Tatry in Slovakia, Stara Lesna Observatory is part of the Astronomical Institute of the Slovak Academy of Sciences and operates at high elevation in the High Tatras mountains. The facility maintains two 60cm Cassegrain telescopes housed in 5-meter domes used for stellar photometry, spectroscopy, and exoplanet detection.

descriptions.name: Stardome Observatory
descriptions.description: Located at 670 Manukau Road in Auckland's One Tree Hill Domain, Stardome Observatory has been sharing knowledge of space and astronomy since 1967. The modern facility features a 75-seat planetarium (largest in New Zealand), two telescope domes, and exhibition galleries.

descriptions.name: Starkenburg Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1970 near Heppenheim in the Bergstrasse region of Hesse, Germany, the Starkenburg Observatory is situated 280 meters east of Starkenburg castle. Operating as a working research observatory with approximately 150 members, it has become notable for asteroid discoveries.

descriptions.name: Stará hvězdárna
descriptions.description: The Stara hvezdarna (Old Observatory) in Prague, also known as Stefanik Observatory, was founded in 1928 on Petrin hill and named after Slovak astronomer Milan Rastislav Stefanik. The three-domed facility houses a historic double-refractor astrograph made by Zeiss in 1905.

descriptions.name: Stellafane Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1920 by Russell W. Porter on Breezy Hill near Springfield, Vermont, Stellafane is the home of the Springfield Telescope Makers and birthplace of the amateur telescope-making movement. The Pink Clubhouse built in 1923 and the observatory became a National Historic Landmark in 1989, hosting the longest-running astronomical convention in the United States since 1926.

descriptions.name: Sterngarten
descriptions.description: The Sterngarten is a free open-air planetarium and observatory facility in Vienna-Mauer initiated by Hermann Mucke and built between 1997 and 2000 on the edge of the Maurerwald forest. Spanning one hectare with three 17-meter-high masts, it provides precise tracking of celestial movements and seasonal sun paths.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Sternwarte refers to a constellation of small observatories across German-speaking regions, often operated by local astronomical associations as public facilities. These observatories typically feature modest equipment and serve important educational and community outreach functions.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Aachen
descriptions.description: Operating since 1935 at Hangeweiher in Aachen, Germany, the Volkssternwarte survived World War II damage while retaining its original buildings and equipment. Its main telescope is a 20cm lens refractor made by Carl Zeiss with a 3-meter focal length.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Aalen
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Aalen is a public observatory and planetarium on Schillerhohe in Aalen, Baden-Wurttemberg, Germany, operated by the Aalen Astronomical Association. The facility provides regular free public observation sessions on Friday evenings and Sunday afternoons.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Bülach
descriptions.description: Located in Bulach, Switzerland, Sternwarte Bulach is a public observatory featuring unique twin telescopes with mirror diameters of 85cm and 50cm, making it distinctive in Switzerland for its dual Cassegrain/Newton configuration design.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Davidschlag
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Davidschlag is a small public observatory in Austria dedicated to amateur astronomy and public education. The facility offers regular viewing sessions and serves the local community.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Diedorf
descriptions.description: Located in Diedorf, Germany, Sternwarte Diedorf is a public observatory operated by local astronomy enthusiasts. The facility provides community members with access to telescopes for observing the night sky.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Dresden-Plauen Hermann Risse
descriptions.description: The Sternwarte Dresden-Plauen Hermann Risse Observatory was established in 1960-1961 in the Hohen Stein district of Dresden-Plauen as a joint effort by teacher Hermann Risse, parents, and students. After Risse's death in 2015, the observatory was renamed Hermann-Risse-Sternwarte in 2017.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Gönnsdorf
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Gonnsdorf is a public astronomical observatory in Germany serving amateur astronomers and the general public. The facility offers regular viewing sessions and educational programs.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Heringsdorf
descriptions.description: Located in Heringsdorf, Germany, Sternwarte Heringsdorf is a community-focused observatory providing public access to astronomical observation. The facility supports local astronomy clubs and educational initiatives.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Herne
descriptions.description: Founded in 1981 in Dorneburger Park in Herne, Germany, Sternwarte Herne is operated by the Astronomical Working Group Wanne-Eickel/Herne. The facility features a 5-inch refractor and 20cm Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope, a 4-meter planetarium, and a radio telescope.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Hof
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Hof is a public observatory in Hof, Germany, dedicated to bringing astronomy to the local community. The facility offers regular viewing sessions and educational programs.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Kirchheim
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Kirchheim is a public observatory located in Amt Wachsenburg in Thuringia, Germany, operated as Volkssternwarte Kirchheim e.V. Recognized by the Minor Planet Center with observatory code A33, it contributes to asteroid research.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Melle
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Melle is a public observatory in Melle, Germany, serving the local community with astronomy education and observation opportunities.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Mirasteilas
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Mirasteilas is an astronomical observatory in Switzerland dedicated to public observation and amateur astronomy.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Neanderhöhe Hochdahl
descriptions.description: Located in Hochdahl, Germany, Sternwarte Neanderhöhe is a public observatory serving the local community with regular viewing sessions and educational programs.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Oberwittstadt
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Oberwittstadt is a public observatory in Oberwittstadt, Germany, dedicated to amateur astronomy and community outreach.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Rümlang
descriptions.description: Located in Rumlang, Switzerland, Sternwarte Rumlang is a public observatory providing astronomical observation opportunities for the community.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Simplon-Adler
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Simplon-Adler is an alpine observatory in Switzerland located in the region of the Simplon Pass. The facility takes advantage of its high-altitude location and clear mountain skies for astronomical observation.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Tübingen
descriptions.description: Built from 1955 to 1957 for the University of Tubingen's Astronomical Institute, Sternwarte Tubingen houses a 30cm Zeiss refractor with a 5-meter focal length originally built in 1924 for Nobel laureate Carl Bosch. Since 1973, the Astronomical Association has used this historic telescope for public stargazing tours.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte und Planetarium „Sigmund Jähn“ Rodewisch
descriptions.description: Located in Rodewisch, Germany, the Sternwarte und Planetarium 'Sigmund Jahn' is a school observatory and planetarium facility named after German cosmonaut Sigmund Jahn, the first German to reach space in 1978. The facility features a large Cassegrain reflecting telescope and a 60-seat planetarium.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Weikersheim
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Weikersheim is a public observatory in Weikersheim, Germany, dedicated to amateur astronomy and public education.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Weisbach
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Weisbach is a public observatory in Weisbach, Germany, serving amateur astronomers and the general public.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Welzheim
descriptions.description: Located in Welzheim, Germany, Sternwarte Welzheim is a community observatory offering amateur astronomy and public observation.

descriptions.name: Sternwarte Zollern-Alb
descriptions.description: Sternwarte Zollern-Alb is an observatory located in the Zollern-Alb region of Germany serving as a community resource for amateur astronomers.

descriptions.name: Sterrenwacht Limburg
descriptions.description: Sterrenwacht Limburg, located in Heerlen in the Dutch province of Limburg, opened in December 1986 and is the only public observatory in Dutch Limburg. Situated at the edge of the Brunssummerheide forest, the facility features antique telescopes for viewing celestial objects.

descriptions.name: Stjerneborg
descriptions.description: Built circa 1581 by Tycho Brahe on the island of Ven between Denmark and Sweden, Stjerneborg ('Star Castle') was an underground observatory designed to protect delicate instruments from wind and anchor them on solid stone for measurement accuracy. Excavated and covered by a dome in 1950-1951, it now houses multimedia presentations and exhibitions.

descriptions.name: Stockholm Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1753, Stockholm Observatory was established to map celestial movements and chart stars for accurate timekeeping, with its meridian line serving as Sweden's prime meridian until 1884. Featuring continuous weather observations since 1754, it holds records for the world's longest continuous temperature and precipitation measurements.

descriptions.name: Stonehenge Aotearoa
descriptions.description: Opened on February 12, 2005, by Nobel Laureate Professor Alan MacDiarmid, Stonehenge Aotearoa is a 30-meter diameter, 4-meter high open-sky observatory in Wairarapa, New Zealand. Built with 24 concrete pillars resembling hewn stone, it incorporates multiple astronomical traditions including Egyptian, Babylonian, Celtic, Polynesian, and Maori astronomy.

descriptions.name: Stony Ridge Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1957 by amateur astronomers, Stony Ridge Observatory sits on a ridge in Angeles National Forest, Los Angeles County, California, at 1,730 meters elevation. Its 30-inch Newtonian-Cassegrain reflector was among California's largest telescopes when installed.

descriptions.name: Stonyhurst Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1866 at Stonyhurst College in Lancashire, England, Stonyhurst Observatory replaced an earlier 1838 observatory and was one of seven key UK meteorological stations by 1854. With temperature records dating to 1846 among the world's oldest continuous daily records, it expanded under Jesuit management to include astronomy, geomagnetometry, and seismology research.

descriptions.name: Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy
descriptions.description: SOFIA (Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy) was an 80/20 NASA-German Aerospace Center joint project based on a Boeing 747SP aircraft modified with an aft fuselage door for a 2.5-meter infrared telescope. Operated at 41,000 feet altitude to access 85% of infrared wavelengths blocked by Earth's atmosphere, SOFIA made historic observations including detecting water on the Moon's sunlit surface in 2020.

descriptions.name: Stuttgart Observatory
descriptions.description: Operating since 1922 on the Uhlandshohe in Stuttgart, Germany, Stuttgart Observatory is one of the oldest continuously operating observatories in the country. Managed by the volunteer Schwabische Sternwarte e.V., it houses six telescopes including a historic 7-inch Zeiss refractor from 1911.

descriptions.name: Sudbury Neutrino Observatory
descriptions.description: Located 2,100 meters underground in Vale's Creighton Mine in Sudbury, Ontario, Canada, the Sudbury Neutrino Observatory (SNO) operated from May 1999 to November 2006 as a heavy-water Cherenkov detector studying solar neutrinos. Director Art McDonald was co-awarded the 2015 Nobel Prize in Physics for discovering neutrino oscillations.

descriptions.name: Sunriver Observatory
descriptions.description: The Oregon Observatory at Sunriver in central Oregon is the nation's largest publicly accessible observatory with the largest collection of telescopes in the country. Housing telescopes ranging from 4 to 20 inches and operating as an International Dark Sky Place, it offers daytime solar viewing and evening star programs.

descriptions.name: Super-Kamiokande
descriptions.description: Located 1,000 meters underground in the Mozumi Mine in Hida, Gifu Prefecture, Japan, Super-Kamiokande is a massive neutrino observatory consisting of a tank filled with 50,000 tons of ultrapure water monitored by 13,000 photomultiplier tubes. Beginning operation in 1996, it provided the first experimental evidence of neutrino oscillation in 1998.

descriptions.name: Sura Ionospheric Heating Facility
descriptions.description: The Sura Ionospheric Heating Facility, located near Vasilsursk 100km east of Nizhny Novgorod, Russia, was commissioned in 1981 to study the ionosphere's behavior. Operated by the Radiophysical Research Institute (NIRFI), it radiates up to 260 megawatts at 9.5 MHz, enabling detailed analysis of ionospheric physics.

descriptions.name: Sydney Observatory
descriptions.description: Built from 1857 to 1859, Sydney Observatory sits atop a 40-meter high natural point in Sydney Harbour on land selected by Governor William Denison in 1856. The Italianate sandstone building features two telescope domes on octagonal bases and a four-storey time-ball tower. Today it operates as part of the Powerhouse Museum.

descriptions.name: Table Mountain Observatory
descriptions.description: The Table Mountain Observatory in California is operated by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory for research in optical astronomy and atmospheric science. Located in the San Gabriel Mountains, it provides excellent conditions for astronomical observation and monitoring.

descriptions.name: Talcott house
descriptions.description: Talcott Mountain Science Center is located atop Talcott Mountain in Avon, Connecticut, commanding views of 5,000 square miles across state borders. The facility features a new astronomical observatory with computer-driven telescopes including a 16-inch Meade, 12-inch Tinsley, and 17-inch Dobsonian.

descriptions.name: Tallinn Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1954, Tallinn Observatory in Tallinn, Estonia, is part of Tallinn University of Technology since 1993. Known as the Tallinn Observatory Tower, it houses the largest telescope in northern Estonia.

descriptions.name: Tamke-Allan Observatory
descriptions.description: Tamke-Allan Observatory (TAO) is an astronomical facility owned and operated by Roane State Community College near Rockwood in Roane County, Tennessee. Named after the Tamke and Allan families who supported its development, TAO's mission focuses on astronomy education, research projects, and cooperation with similar institutions.

descriptions.name: Tartu Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1802 and completed in 1810 on Toome Hill, Tartu Observatory was a leading astronomical center under director Friedrich Georg Wilhelm von Struve. The observatory hosted one of the largest telescopes of the 19th century (a 9-inch Fraunhofer refractor), and its location in Estonia served as the first reference point for the historic Struve Geodetic Arc. In 1963, a new observatory was built in Tõravere with modern facilities, and the original building now operates as a museum.

descriptions.name: Taurus Hill observatory
descriptions.description: Constructed in 2002-2004 near Varkaus, Finland, Taurus Hill Observatory is one of the largest amateur astronomical observatories in Northern Europe with a Minor Planet Center designation. The facility specializes in exoplanet transit measurements with precision below 10 millimagnitude and has discovered supernovae. Its modern equipment and active research program have made it a significant contributor to professional astronomy through amateur observations.

descriptions.name: Taurus-1 Observatory
descriptions.description: Taurus-1 Observatory in Finland refers to the Taurus Hill Observatory complex, which was established as one of the premier amateur research facilities in the Nordic region. The observatory operates advanced photometric equipment for studying exoplanet transits and variable stars, publishing numerous scientific papers in peer-reviewed journals. Its elevated location in central Finland provides favorable atmospheric conditions for long-term astronomical monitoring.

descriptions.name: Tavolaia astronomical observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1999 and inaugurated on September 5, Tavolaia Astronomical Observatory is located in Santa Maria a Monte, Tuscany, and serves both as a research facility and public education center. Managed by the Astronomical Association Isaac Newton, it participates in observational campaigns including stellar occultation studies of trans-Neptunian objects. The observatory is regularly open to the public for guided observations, lectures, and special astronomical events.

descriptions.name: Tbilisi Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1837 as a magnetic-meteorological observatory and later evolving into a research facility for geophysics, Tbilisi Observatory became a major scientific center in the Caucasus region. The facility, located in the historic Kukia district, participated in the first International Polar Year (1882-1883) and conducted observations across multiple disciplines including seismic and gravitational measurements. Today, its heritage buildings house the Museum of Geophysical Sciences.

descriptions.name: Teide Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1964 and operated by the Instituto de Astrofísica de Canarias, Teide Observatory atop Mount Teide at 2,390 meters hosts solar and nocturnal telescopes from over 60 institutions across 19 countries. The world's largest solar observatory on the island, it features Europe's best solar telescopes including the 1.5-meter GREGOR instrument. The exceptional atmospheric conditions at this altitude make it a premier site for high-resolution solar physics research.

descriptions.name: Temisas Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Temisas Astronomical Observatory opened in 2008 on Gran Canaria at 850 meters elevation and combines research with educational outreach. Operated by the Fundación Canaria Observatorio de Temisas, it features a 14-inch Meade Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope and regularly offers family-friendly 2-hour public tours. The facility's accessible location makes it a popular destination for both amateur astronomers and school groups in the Canary Islands.

descriptions.name: Teylers astronomical observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1784 atop the Oval Room of the Teylers Museum in Haarlem, Netherlands, the Teylers Astronomical Observatory was constructed by Jacobus Barnaart as an innovative observation platform. Though its wooden roof caused vibration issues preventing precise measurements, the observatory served for manual observations and housed a camera obscura until 1817. Today, the historic tower remains a landmark structure visible for miles along the river Spaarne.

descriptions.name: Thai National Observatory
descriptions.description: Completed in 2012 atop Doi Inthanon, Thailand's highest mountain, the Thai National Observatory houses the 2.4-meter Thai National Telescope, the largest and most modern telescope in Southeast Asia. The facility at 2,450 meters elevation provides over 200 clear observing nights annually with excellent sky visibility. Operated by the National Astronomical Research Institute of Thailand, it attracts international researchers and offers public outreach programs.

descriptions.name: The astrodome of the Lyceum in Eger
descriptions.description: Constructed between 1765-1778 under the direction of Jesuit astronomer Maximilian Hell, the astrodome of the Lyceum in Eger represents a masterpiece of 18th-century astronomical architecture. The facility features a preserved camera obscura from 1776 known as the 'eye of Eger' and an astronomical museum with original 18th-century instruments. Today it serves the Károly Eszterházy University and includes a planetarium and interactive science experience center.

descriptions.name: The Equatorial Observatory, Penllergare
descriptions.description: Built in 1851 by John Dillwyn Llewelyn as a gift for his daughter on her 16th birthday, the Equatorial Observatory at Penllergare is the second-oldest astronomical observatory in Wales. In 1855, it was used by Llewelyn and his daughter to take one of the earliest photographs of the moon, a pioneering achievement in astronomical photography. This Grade II* listed structure is undergoing restoration with plans for a planetarium installation.

descriptions.name: The Heights Observatory
descriptions.description: The Heights Observatory in California is a historic amateur observation facility that has contributed to public education and astronomical research. Located in a region with favorable viewing conditions, it has served as a gathering place for amateur astronomers and educational institutions. The facility continues to support stargazing programs and community engagement with astronomy.

descriptions.name: The Octagon at Amherst College
descriptions.description: The Octagon at Amherst College, built in 1847-1848 as the first natural history museum and observatory on campus, is an architectural landmark housing an elegant dome and the first equatorially-mounted telescope built entirely by Alvan Clark and Sons. Constructed on the insistence of college president Edward Hitchcock, it served astronomy education until the new Observatory opened in 1905. The building was subsequently used for music and cultural programs.

descriptions.name: The Space Observatory (Observatoire de l'Espace)
descriptions.description: Established in 2000 as a cultural laboratory by CNES (the French Space Agency), the Observatoire de l'Espace (Space Observatory) in Paris promotes artistic engagement with outer space rather than traditional astronomical research. It fosters space-related artistic creation through residencies and the annual Sidération festival, introducing artists and the public to space science through innovative cultural perspectives. The organization includes immersive experiences like weightlessness flights aboard the Airbus Zero-G.
