descriptions.name: Theodor Jacobsen Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1895 and designed by Charles Willard Saunders, the Theodor Jacobsen Observatory at the University of Washington in Seattle is the second-oldest structure on campus. Originally equipped with a 6-inch brass refracting telescope, it was renovated and dedicated to Prof. Theodor Jacobsen (1901-2003), whose astronomy research from the 1920s helped establish the discipline at the university. Today it remains committed to public viewing and exploration of the cosmos.

descriptions.name: Thomas King Observatory
descriptions.description: The Thomas King Observatory on Mount Tamalpais in California serves as an educational facility supporting amateur astronomical associations and public stargazing programs. Astronomy activities at Mount Tamalpais include evening programs with professional astronomers and weekend observation sessions. The facility contributes to astronomy education and public outreach in the San Francisco Bay Area.

descriptions.name: Tian Shan Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Tian Shan Astronomical Observatory, located 30 kilometers south of Almaty, Kazakhstan (not Xinjiang as sometimes referenced), was established in 1957 at 2,735 meters elevation. With nearly 100 photometric nights per year and minimal light pollution, it serves as a crucial research station for atmospheric studies and astronomical observations. The high-altitude site in the Tian Shan mountains provides excellent atmospheric transparency.

descriptions.name: Tiana observatory
descriptions.description: Tiana Observatory in Mexico is a smaller astronomical facility serving educational and research purposes. Located in a region with regional astronomical significance, it contributes to astronomy education and public engagement with the night sky. The observatory serves both academic and amateur astronomical communities.

descriptions.name: Tican Observatory
descriptions.description: Located in Croatia (not Turkey as sometimes mistakenly referenced), the Tičan Observatory, also known as Višnjan Observatory, moved to its current Tičan Hill location in 2007, 3 kilometers from Višnjan. This world-renowned amateur observatory, led by Korado Korlević, offers group and individual visits typically on Saturday evenings and has gained recognition for its scientific contributions. The facility combines public education with active observational research programs.

descriptions.name: Timau National Observatory
descriptions.description: The Timau National Observatory in Kupang Regency, East Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia, has been under construction since 2021 to become the largest observatory in Southeast Asia. Equipped with a 3.8-meter optical telescope and two 0.5-meter robotic telescopes, it will provide ephemeris services and astronomical research capabilities. Analysis estimates 5.3 usable observing hours per night with 66% yearly availability.

descriptions.name: Timișoara Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded on December 7, 1962, the Timișoara Astronomical Observatory is a major research facility operated in coordination with the Astronomical Institute of the Romanian Academy. Located in Piața Axente Sever, it represents one of Romania's three principal astronomical observatories, along with facilities in Bucharest and Cluj. The observatory contributes to astronomical research across multiple subdisciplines.

descriptions.name: Tochigi Science Museum
descriptions.description: The Tochigi Science Museum in Utsunomiya, Japan, established in 1988, functions as both a public science center and astronomical observatory. Featuring a planetarium with regular shows and an observatory dome, the museum offers hands-on science exhibits, interactive demonstrations, and sky observation programs. The facility serves school groups, families, and individual visitors interested in astronomy and natural sciences.

descriptions.name: Tonantzintla Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in February 1942 and dedicated by the President of Mexico, Tonantzintla Observatory in Puebla consists of two adjacent facilities operated by INAOE and UNAM. The pioneering 0.7-meter Schmidt camera installed in 1942 was used by Guillermo Haro to detail Herbig-Haro objects as indicators of star formation. The observatory houses an extensive collection of 15,000 astro-photographic plates and continues active research in astrophysics.

descriptions.name: Toronto Magnetic and Meteorological Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1839 at the University of Toronto, the Toronto Magnetic and Meteorological Observatory is Canada's oldest scientific institution. Originally built in 1840 as part of Edward Sabine's international magnetic research project, observations from this site demonstrated the connection between sunspots and Earth's magnetic field. The facility served as Canada's primary meteorological station and official timekeeper for over 50 years.

descriptions.name: Toulouse Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1733 by l'Académie des Sciences, the Toulouse Observatory in France moved to its current neo-Gothic building at Jolimont in 1841, designed by architect Urbain Vitry. The observatory participated in the Carte Du Ciel project, recording over 1,000 astronomical plates between 1887 and 1939, and its astronomers discovered a gravitational lens around Abel 370 in the 1980s. Today it operates under the Popular Astronomy Society.

descriptions.name: Tour de la Babotte
descriptions.description: The Tour de la Babotte in Montpellier, France, a 12th-century tower, became an observatory in 1745 under the patronage of the States of Languedoc and Académie des Sciences. Though operational only until 1793, it hosted observations again from 1902-1922 before being taken over by the telegraph department. Today it houses the Montpellier Chess Club and serves as the meeting place of the Société Astronomique de Montpellier.

descriptions.name: Townsend Observatory
descriptions.description: Townsend Observatory in Massachusetts is an amateur astronomical facility serving the New England region. The facility supports public outreach and amateur astronomy education, providing accessible observation opportunities. It contributes to the local astronomy community and public engagement with astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Toyama City Observatory
descriptions.description: The Toyama City Observatory operates on the 8th floor of Toyama City Hall, offering free public access to panoramic views and equipped with telescopes and binoculars. Located at approximately 70 meters above ground with additional observation areas on the 10th floor, visitors can view the distant Tateyama mountain range and Toyama Bay on clear days. Operating from 09:00 AM to 09:00 PM daily with free admission, it serves as an educational public facility.

descriptions.name: Trivandrum Observatory
descriptions.description: Established by Raja of Travancore Swathi Thirunal Rama Varma in 1836-37, Trivandrum Observatory in Thiruvananthapuram, India, is located at the city's highest point near the Museum Complex. John Caldecott served as the royal astronomer, and the facility was transferred to the University of Kerala in 1975 for weather physics research. Today it offers public star-gazing sessions with an 11-inch telescope and modern CCD equipment.

descriptions.name: Tsinghua University Observatory
descriptions.description: The Tsinghua University Observatory in Beijing, designed by architect Yang Tingbao, stands as an iconic landmark witnessing the university's development through the rising and setting of stars. The observatory supports Tsinghua's astrophysics research programs, which have achieved high global rankings in recent evaluations. The facility collaborates with the Xinglong Observatory to operate advanced telescopes for cutting-edge astronomical research.

descriptions.name: TUBITAK National Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1991 at 2,450 meters elevation in Bakırtepe, Antalya, TUBITAK National Observatory (TUG) serves as Turkey's primary ground-based astronomical research facility. Equipped with five telescopes including the 1.5-meter Russian-Turkish Telescope (RTT150) which discovered exoplanets through precise radial-velocity measurements. The observatory hosts international students, conducts public education events, and contributes significantly to Turkish astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Tuorla Observatory
descriptions.description: Established on April 29, 1952, by professor Yrjö Väisälä, Tuorla Observatory near Turku, Finland, is the largest astronomical research institute in the country and part of the Väisälä Institute of Space Physics and Astronomy. The facility houses the one-meter Dall-Kirkham reflector, Finland's largest optical telescope, and features a planetarium established in 2008. Research focuses on active galactic nuclei, dark matter, and cosmology.

descriptions.name: Turin Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1759 at the top of a Piedmont hill, Turin Astrophysical Observatory relocated to Pino Torinese in 1912 to escape light pollution. The observatory developed a leading role in space solar physics, with its team contributing key instruments to the SOHO spacecraft and coordinating the Metis project for ESA's Solar Orbiter mission. Italian astronomer Luigi Volta made several asteroid discoveries at the site in the late 1920s and early 1930s.

descriptions.name: Turnov Observatory
descriptions.description: Turnov Observatory (Hvezdárna Turnov) in the Czech Republic is an amateur astronomical facility serving the Turnov region. Located in this traditional center for gemstone polishing and glasscraft, the observatory contributes to public astronomy education. The facility offers observation opportunities and supports amateur astronomical research in the Liberec Region.

descriptions.name: Tweelingen public observatory
descriptions.description: The Tweelingen Public Observatory in Nissewaard, South Holland, Netherlands, serves as a community astronomical observation facility near Spijkenisse in the greater Rotterdam region. As a recognized public observation site, it provides amateur astronomers and sky enthusiasts access to equipment and programs. The facility supports public engagement with astronomy and stargazing activities.

descriptions.name: Tähtikallio Observatory & Education Center
descriptions.description: Established in 2007 in Artjärvi, Finland, the Tähtikallio Observatory & Education Center is operated by the Ursa Astronomical Association, Finland's largest astronomical organization. Equipped with advanced telescopes including a 36-inch Folded Newtonian and 16-inch Ritchey-Chrétien instruments, it serves as an educational hub for schools and public outreach. Ursa collaborates with schools by arranging guided star shows and sending astronomy experts.

descriptions.name: Třebíč observatory
descriptions.description: Třebíč Observatory in the Czech Republic serves the Třebíč region with amateur astronomical facilities. The observatory contributes to public education and local astronomical engagement. Limited specific historical documentation exists for this facility, though it participates in the broader network of Czech astronomical observatories.

descriptions.name: UCL Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1929 at Mill Hill in North-West London, UCL Observatory (formerly University of London Observatory) serves as an educational and research facility for University College London. Originally housing a 24-inch reflector built by Grubb in 1881, it now features Radcliffe and Fry refracting telescopes plus advanced robotic reflecting telescopes. In 2014, astronomers discovered supernova SN2014J during undergraduate observation sessions.

descriptions.name: Ulugh Beg Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in the 1420s by Timurid astronomer Ulugh Beg in Samarkand, Uzbekistan, this observatory was the last major Islamic Medieval astronomical research institution. Over 60 mathematicians and astronomers, including Jamshīd al-Kāshī as first director, produced a star catalogue of 1,018 stars still studied in 17th-century Oxford. Though destroyed after Ulugh Beg's assassination around 1449, archaeological excavation in 1908 revealed its ruins and marble quadrant.

descriptions.name: Union Observatory
descriptions.description: Also known as Transvaal Observatory and Republic Observatory, Union Observatory operated from 1903 to 1971 at Observatory Ridge, Johannesburg's highest point. Well remembered for discoveries including Proxima Centauri and significant work on minor planets, it succumbed to light pollution and closed in 1971-1972. SAASTA acquired the site in 2003 and has refurbished it into an interactive science awareness facility with astronomy focus.

descriptions.name: United States Naval Academy
descriptions.description: Established in 1845 to train naval officers in celestial navigation, the Naval Academy Observatory in Annapolis features a historic 7.75-inch Clark refracting telescope built by Alvan Clark in 1854. The original observatory (built 1850-1854) was demolished in 1908, but a new facility was constructed in 1991 by the Class of 1941 as their anniversary gift. Recent 2022 upgrades included installation of a Paramount MEII German equatorial mount.

descriptions.name: United States Naval Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1830 as the Depot of Charts and Instruments, the United States Naval Observatory in Washington, D.C. is America's oldest scientific agency and the Department of Defense's authoritative source for celestial positions and precise timekeeping. The historic Building 1, designed by Richard Morris Hunt and completed in 1893, relocated to Embassy Row to escape light pollution. The USNO maintains cesium atomic clocks and has discovered the moons of Mars.

descriptions.name: University of Alabama Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1949 atop Gallalee Hall, the University of Alabama Observatory houses a 16-inch reflector that replaced a 10-inch refractor used from 1950-2004. The original observatory (1849) suffered from light pollution, prompting the relocation. Monthly public nights feature free admission and research-grade CCD imaging systems, allowing the public to observe faint celestial objects with professional-quality equipment.

descriptions.name: University of Reading Atmospheric Observatory
descriptions.description: Operating continuously since 1901 with daily records from 1908 onward, the University of Reading Atmospheric Observatory is a meteorological research facility on the Whiteknights campus. Located at 66 meters elevation (51.442°N, 0.938°W), it serves as a center for atmospheric measurements and micrometeorological research. The site has provided 120+ years of uninterrupted weather observations supporting climate and atmospheric science.

descriptions.name: University of Tartu Old Observatory
descriptions.description: Completed in 1810 on Toome Hill and expanded with a Fraunhofer refractor in 1824 (the largest achromatic telescope of its era), the University of Tartu Old Observatory was active until 1964. Serving as the first reference point for the UNESCO World Heritage Struve Geodetic Arc, it housed some of the 19th century's most advanced astronomical instruments. Returned to the University in 1996, it was restored and now operates as a museum.

descriptions.name: University of Tokyo Atacama Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened on April 30, 2024, atop Cerro Chajnantor at 5,640 meters, the University of Tokyo Atacama Observatory is the world's highest optical telescope facility. The TAO 6.5-meter optical-infrared telescope is uniquely capable of observing mid-infrared wavelengths, ideal for studying star and planet-forming regions. Due to altitude sickness risks, operations are remotely controlled from a base facility in San Pedro de Atacama.

descriptions.name: Universitäts-Sternwarte München
descriptions.description: Founded in 1816-1819 by King Max I. Joseph of Bavaria, the Universitäts-Sternwarte München has stood for progressive astronomy and astrophysics for over 200 years. Currently hosting five chairs and ten research groups studying hot stars, cool stars, extragalactic astronomy, and plasma astrophysics, it maintains out stations including Wendelstein Observatory and the Hobby-Eberly Telescope in Texas. The institute represents a network of four astrophysics centers in the Munich region.

descriptions.name: Universitätssternwarte Pfaffenwald
descriptions.description: Originally built in 1934 by manufacturer Hermann Fellmeth near his country house, the Universitätssternwarte Pfaffenwald in Stuttgart was donated to the University of Stuttgart in 1972 on the condition it be restored and opened to the public. Notable for housing the largest functional Schupmann-Medial telescope in Europe, it was designated a historical monument. Since its 1977 renovation with Zeiss support, it has served as both a university observation station and public observatory.

descriptions.name: Uppsala Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1741 by Anders Celsius, the Uppsala Astronomical Observatory is Sweden's oldest, though the University of Uppsala held a professorship of astronomy since 1593. Celsius constructed the first proper observatory on a medieval stone house in central Uppsala, with a new facility built in 1853. In 2000, the observatory merged with the Institute of Space Physics, now operating as part of the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

descriptions.name: Urania
descriptions.description: Established in 1888 following Alexander von Humboldt's vision of public science engagement, Urania in Berlin opened its doors in 1889 with a state-of-the-art 314-millimeter refractor built by Carl Bamberg (the second-largest in Germany). Gustav Witt used this telescope in 1898 to discover asteroid Eros (No. 433). Though the original observatory was destroyed in World War II, Urania continues as a leading center of science-society dialogue with modern facilities including theaters and a prominent arthouse cinema.

descriptions.name: Urania Observatory
descriptions.description: Urania Observatory refers to various observatories named after the muse of astronomy, found in cities including Vienna and Zurich. These facilities typically combine public education with astronomical observation.

descriptions.name: Urania Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Founded in 1907, Urania Sternwarte Zurich was the first concrete building in Zurich and houses a historic Zeiss telescope. The observatory serves as a public facility for astronomical observation and education.

descriptions.name: Uraniborg
descriptions.description: Built in 1576 by Tycho Brahe on the island of Hven between Denmark and Sweden, Uraniborg was a pioneering astronomical research center. The castle-observatory featured the most advanced instruments of its time and produced precise stellar observations.

descriptions.name: Ursa Observatory
descriptions.description: Ursa Observatory in Finland is operated by the Ursa Astronomical Association, Finland's largest astronomical organization. The facility serves as a hub for amateur astronomy and public education.

descriptions.name: Ussuriysk Astrophysical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Ussuriysk Astrophysical Observatory in Russia's Far East conducts research in stellar astronomy and astrophysics. Located near Ussuriysk, it contributes to Russian astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Utrecht Observatory
descriptions.description: Utrecht Observatory in the Netherlands has a long history dating back to the 17th century. The facility contributed to Dutch astronomical research and education before modern facilities took over.

descriptions.name: UWS Rotary Observatory
descriptions.description: The UWS Rotary Observatory at Western Sydney University provides educational opportunities for students and the public. The facility supports astronomy education and community outreach.

descriptions.name: Uzhhorod Observatory
descriptions.description: Uzhhorod Observatory in Ukraine serves as an astronomical research and education facility. The observatory contributes to Ukrainian astronomical research.

descriptions.name: Vainu Bappu Observatory
descriptions.description: The Vainu Bappu Observatory in Kavalur, India, operated by the Indian Institute of Astrophysics, was home to Asia's largest telescope for decades. Named after astronomer M.K. Vainu Bappu, it continues active research in stellar and solar astronomy.

descriptions.name: Valašské Meziříčí observatory
descriptions.description: The Valasske Mezirici observatory in the Czech Republic recently introduced a new half-meter robotic telescope for systematic comet CCD photometry. The facility represents an important astronomical research center in the region.

descriptions.name: Valongo Observatory
descriptions.description: Valongo Observatory in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, is part of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro. The historic facility contributes to Brazilian astronomical research and education.

descriptions.name: Van Vleck Observatory
descriptions.description: Van Vleck Observatory at Wesleyan University in Connecticut has been conducting astronomical research since 1916. The facility houses historic telescopes and supports both research and education.

descriptions.name: Vartiovuori Observatory
descriptions.description: Vartiovuori Observatory in Turku, Finland, is one of Finland's oldest astronomical observatories. The facility contributed to Finnish astronomical research and now serves educational purposes.

descriptions.name: Vassar College Observatory
descriptions.description: Vassar College Observatory in Poughkeepsie, New York, has been active since 1865 and was associated with Maria Mitchell, America's first female professional astronomer. The facility continues to support astronomical education.

descriptions.name: Vatican Observatory
descriptions.description: The Vatican Observatory, one of the world's oldest active observatories, traces its origins to 1582 when Pope Gregory XIII commissioned the calendar reform. Now based at Castel Gandolfo, it conducts research in stellar astronomy, cosmology, and planetary science.

descriptions.name: Ved Shala
descriptions.description: Ved Shala is an astronomical observatory in India, part of the country's network of traditional and modern astronomical facilities. The observatory contributes to astronomical research and education.

descriptions.name: Vega-Sternwarte Salzburg
descriptions.description: Vega-Sternwarte Salzburg in Austria is a public observatory serving the Salzburg region. The facility offers regular observation opportunities and astronomy education for the public.

descriptions.name: Ventspils International Radio Astronomy Center
descriptions.description: The Ventspils International Radio Astronomy Center in Latvia operates one of the largest radio telescopes in Northern Europe. The facility conducts radio astronomy research and participates in international VLBI networks.

descriptions.name: Vera C. Rubin Observatory
descriptions.description: The Vera C. Rubin Observatory in Chile, formerly known as LSST, houses the world's largest camera (3200 megapixels) and will conduct a 10-year survey of the southern sky. Named after astronomer Vera Rubin, it will revolutionize our understanding of dark matter and the universe.

descriptions.name: VERITAS
descriptions.description: VERITAS (Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System) in Arizona consists of four 12-meter gamma-ray telescopes. The facility detects very high energy gamma rays from cosmic sources.

descriptions.name: Very Large Telescope
descriptions.description: The Very Large Telescope (VLT) at Paranal Observatory in Chile, operated by ESO, is the world's most advanced visible-light astronomical observatory. Its four 8.2-meter Unit Telescopes can work together as an interferometer.

descriptions.name: Vesuvius Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1841, Vesuvius Observatory in Naples is the world's first volcanological observatory. While primarily focused on monitoring Mount Vesuvius, it contributed to early seismic and atmospheric research.

descriptions.name: Vienna Observatory
descriptions.description: Vienna Observatory, founded in 1753, is one of Austria's oldest astronomical research institutions. The facility has contributed to stellar astronomy and continues active research and education.

descriptions.name: Virgo
descriptions.description: Virgo is a gravitational wave detector near Pisa, Italy, operated by the European Gravitational Observatory. Working with LIGO, it has detected gravitational waves from merging black holes and neutron stars.

descriptions.name: Vitebsk Observatory
descriptions.description: Vitebsk Observatory in Belarus serves as an astronomical research and education facility. The observatory contributes to Belarusian astronomical research and public education.

descriptions.name: Višnjan Observatory
descriptions.description: Visnjan Observatory in Croatia has discovered numerous asteroids and is known for its educational programs. The facility trains young astronomers and contributes to near-Earth object research.

descriptions.name: Vlašim Observatory
descriptions.description: Vlasim Observatory in the Czech Republic is an amateur astronomical facility serving the local community. The observatory contributes to public astronomy education in the region.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Adolph Diesterweg Radebeul
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Adolph Diesterweg Radebeul in Germany is a public observatory named after educator Adolph Diesterweg. The facility offers regular observation opportunities and astronomy education.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Bad Kreuznach
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Bad Kreuznach in Germany is a public observatory serving the local community. The facility provides astronomy education and public viewing opportunities.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Bonn
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Bonn in Germany is a public observatory offering regular observation sessions and astronomy education. The facility serves the Bonn area community.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Buchloe
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Buchloe in Germany is a public observatory providing astronomy education and observation opportunities. The facility serves the local community in Bavaria.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Darmstadt
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Darmstadt in Germany is a public observatory offering regular observation sessions. The facility serves the Darmstadt area community with astronomy education.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Dortmund
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Dortmund in Germany is a public observatory providing astronomy education and public viewing. The facility serves the Dortmund area community.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Ennepetal
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Ennepetal in Germany is a public observatory serving the local community. The facility offers regular observation opportunities and astronomy education.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Hagen
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Hagen in Germany is a public observatory providing astronomy education and observation sessions. The facility serves the Hagen area community.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Kempten
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Kempten in Germany is a public observatory offering astronomy education and observation opportunities. The facility serves the Allgau region community.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Klagenfurt
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Klagenfurt in Austria is a public observatory serving the Klagenfurt region. The facility provides astronomy education and public viewing opportunities.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Köln
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Koln (Cologne) in Germany is a public observatory offering astronomy education and observation sessions. The facility serves the Cologne area community.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Michelbach
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Michelbach in Germany is a public observatory providing astronomy education and viewing opportunities. The facility serves the local community.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte mit Planetarium Dieterskirchen
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte mit Planetarium Dieterskirchen in Germany combines a public observatory with planetarium facilities. The complex offers comprehensive astronomy education and public viewing.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Rothwesten
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Rothwesten in Germany is a public observatory serving the local community. The facility provides astronomy education and observation opportunities.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Singen
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Singen in Germany is a public observatory offering astronomy education and viewing sessions. The facility serves the Singen area community.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Urania Jena
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Urania Jena in Germany is a public observatory named after the muse of astronomy. The facility provides astronomy education and observation opportunities for the Jena community.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Wetterau
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Wetterau in Germany is a public observatory serving the Wetterau region. The facility offers astronomy education and public viewing opportunities.

descriptions.name: Volkssternwarte Würzburg
descriptions.description: Volkssternwarte Wurzburg in Germany is a public observatory providing astronomy education and observation sessions. The facility serves the Wurzburg area community.

descriptions.name: Volkssterrenwacht Copernicus
descriptions.description: Volkssterrenwacht Copernicus in the Netherlands is a public observatory named after astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus. The facility provides astronomy education and observation opportunities.

descriptions.name: W. M. Keck Observatory
descriptions.description: The W. M. Keck Observatory on Mauna Kea, Hawaii, operates the world's two largest optical telescopes with 10-meter primary mirrors. The twin Keck telescopes use adaptive optics and can work together as an interferometer for unprecedented resolution.

descriptions.name: Walter-Hohmann-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Established in 1993 at 385 meters elevation in the birthplace of space pioneer Walter Hohmann (1880-1945), this public observatory honors the engineer who calculated fuel-efficient spacecraft trajectories now known as Hohmann transfer orbits. The town also features a 1:4.29 scale model of the Ariane 5 rocket erected in 2012 as a memorial to Hohmann's contributions to spaceflight.

descriptions.name: Walter-Hohmann-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: Founded in 1965 by amateur astronomers in Essen's Schuir district and named in 1971 after space pioneer Walter Hohmann, this public observatory offers weekly sky observations, lectures, and educational programs. Since 1998, it has contributed to asteroid tracking for the International Astronomical Union, discovering eleven new asteroids since 2002, and hosts Europe's largest amateur astronomy fair, the ATT.

descriptions.name: Ward Observatory
descriptions.description: Ward Observatory is an astronomical facility dedicated to research and education. The observatory contributes to astronomical observation and public outreach.

descriptions.name: Warner and Swasey Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1920 by Worcester R. Warner and Ambrose Swasey, the Warner and Swasey Observatory in East Cleveland, Ohio housed a 9.5-inch refractor and later a 24-inch Burrell Schmidt telescope. The observatory became a focus for cutting-edge astronomical research and public education in the early 20th century.

descriptions.name: Warsaw University Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Opened in 1825, the Astronomical Observatory of the University of Warsaw is located within the Botanical Garden of Warsaw next to Lazienki Park. Rebuilt after World War II destruction, it now conducts long-term optical sky surveys including the OGLE and ASAS projects at Las Campanas Observatory in Chile.

descriptions.name: Washburn Observatory
descriptions.description: Completed in 1881, Washburn Observatory at the University of Wisconsin-Madison houses a 15.6-inch Alvan Clark refractor telescope, the third-largest in the United States at the time. Director Joel Stebbins pioneered photoelectric photometry and made important discoveries about the Milky Way's diameter in 1934.

descriptions.name: Wasserturm
descriptions.description: The Wasserturm in Demmin, Germany is a converted water tower built in 1897 that now houses a public planetarium with an observatory and observation platform. Originally constructed for the city's water supply, this unique facility combines modern planetarium shows with astronomical observation capabilities.

descriptions.name: Westfälische Volkssternwarte
descriptions.description: The Westfalische Volkssternwarte Recklinghausen was officially opened in 1953 as a distinctive 20-meter high octagonal tower with a planetarium dome in northwest Recklinghausen, Germany. The facility offers lectures, planetarium shows, and public sky observations.

descriptions.name: Weston Observatory
descriptions.description: Weston Observatory, a geophysical research laboratory at Boston College in Weston, Massachusetts, has been recording earthquakes since the 1930s. The facility operates the New England Seismic Network (NESN) with 17 seismographs throughout New England.

descriptions.name: Westport Observatory
descriptions.description: The Westport Observatory in Westport, Connecticut is a volunteer-run, non-profit facility operated by the Westport Astronomical Society since 1975. Located at the former site of a Nike missile launch base, it is free and open to the public every Wednesday night.

descriptions.name: Wettzell 20m radio telescope
descriptions.description: The Wettzell 20m Radio Telescope, part of the Geodetic Observatory Wettzell in the Bavarian Forest, began operations in 1983 as Germany's first VLBI system exclusively dedicated to geodetic purposes. It contributes essential data to the International VLBI Service for Geodesy and Astrometry.

descriptions.name: Whitin Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1900 and expanded multiple times, Whitin Observatory at Wellesley College is a beloved campus landmark and premier undergraduate astronomy facility. The observatory houses multiple telescopes including a PlaneWave 0.7-meter reflector.

descriptions.name: Wilhelm-Foerster-Sternwarte (Berlin, Germany)
descriptions.description: Opened on January 30, 1963, the Wilhelm-Foerster-Sternwarte in Berlin-Schoneberg sits at the top of Insulaner hill and features the historic 320mm Bamberg refractor telescope built in 1889. This facility is unique in Europe as it combines an observatory with the nearby Planetarium am Insulaner.

descriptions.name: Willi-Hüll-Sternwarte
descriptions.description: The Willi-Hull-Sternwarte is a public observatory in Heidenheim an der Brenz, Germany, inaugurated on September 30, 2006, and officially named in October 2019 after astronomy association founder Willi Hull. Public observations are offered on Friday evenings and Sunday afternoons.

descriptions.name: William Brydone Jack Observatory
descriptions.description: Constructed in 1851, the William Brydone Jack Observatory on the University of New Brunswick campus is the first astronomical observatory in British North America and was designated a national historic site of Canada in 1954.

descriptions.name: Wise Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in October 1971 as a collaboration between Tel Aviv University and the Smithsonian Institution, the Florence and George Wise Observatory is Israel's only professional astronomical observatory. Located near Ramon Crater in the Negev desert, it has discovered 17 numbered minor planets since 1999.

descriptions.name: Woomera Observatory
descriptions.description: The Woomera Baker Observatory operates within Australia's Woomera Range Complex as a public telescope belonging to the Defence Department. It operates one night per week hosting stargazing sessions for the public and visiting military units.

descriptions.name: Wyoming Infrared Observatory
descriptions.description: The Wyoming Infrared Observatory (WIRO) on Jelm Mountain was founded in 1975 with observations beginning in 1977 at 9,656 feet elevation. It houses a 2.3-meter classical Cassegrain telescope designed for infrared astronomy, notable as the world's first fully computer-controlled telescope.

descriptions.name: Ximenian Observatory
descriptions.description: The Beijing Ancient Observatory, also known as the Ximenian Observatory, was first built in 1442 during the Ming Dynasty. The site features eight bronze instruments constructed during the Qing Dynasty and stands as one of the oldest observatories in the world.

descriptions.name: Xinglong Station
descriptions.description: The Xinglong Observatory of the National Astronomical Observatories, Chinese Academy of Sciences was founded in 1968 south of the Yan Mountains in Hebei province. As the largest optical astronomical observatory site in Asia, it houses 9 telescopes with apertures larger than 50 centimeters.

descriptions.name: Xinjiang Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1957, the Xinjiang Astronomical Observatory (XAO) in Urumqi has evolved from a single-satellite facility into a comprehensive research institution within the Chinese Academy of Sciences. It operates multiple sites including the 25-meter Nanshan radio telescope.

descriptions.name: Xujiahui Observatory
descriptions.description: Established in 1872 by French Jesuits, the Shanghai Xujiahui Observatory was known as 'the No.1 meteorological observatory in the Far East' and issued the first typhoon forecast in 1879. It now serves as the Shanghai Meteorological Museum.

descriptions.name: Yale University Observatory
descriptions.description: The Yale University Observatory, also known as the Leitner Family Observatory and Planetarium, traces its history to the 1830s. Yale astronomers have access to world-class facilities including 24 nights on the Keck 10-meter telescope.

descriptions.name: Yale-Columbia Station
descriptions.description: The Yale-Columbia Observatory connection in South America has a rich history beginning with Yale's observatory in Johannesburg, South Africa in the 1920s. In 1960, Yale built an observatory at El Leoncito in Argentina's Andes with Ford Foundation funding.

descriptions.name: Yanagida Observatory Mantenboshi
descriptions.description: The Yanagida Observatory Mantenboshi officially opened in April 1993, located on the Noto Peninsula. The facility features a planetarium and powerful telescope for astronomical observation.

descriptions.name: Yebes Observatory
descriptions.description: The Yebes Observatory RT40m is a 40-meter Cassegrain-Nasmyth radio telescope located 50 kilometers northeast of Madrid in Guadalajara, Spain. Operating frequencies range from 2 to 90 GHz, making it one of the most critical nodes in the European VLBI Network.

descriptions.name: Yerevan Observatory
descriptions.description: Yerevan Observatory was built in 1933 and designed in 1921 by architect A. Tamanyan. Founded by Yerevan State University, the observatory employed famous astronomers Benjamin Markarian and Hayk Badalyan.

descriptions.name: Yerkes Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in 1892 by astronomer George Ellery Hale and financed by businessman Charles T. Yerkes, the Yerkes Observatory houses the world's largest refracting telescope. The 40-inch refractor with doublet lenses produced by Alvan Clark & Sons was completed in 1897.

descriptions.name: Yohai Lookout
descriptions.description: Yohai Lookout is a scenic observation point overlooking the Gulf of Eilat at 734 meters elevation. The site offers panoramic 360-degree views from its cliff-top location, providing vistas of desert mountains spanning four countries.

descriptions.name: York University Observatory
descriptions.description: The Allan I. Carswell Astronomical Observatory at York University in Toronto houses two telescopes including a one-meter custom-built telescope, the largest at any Canadian university campus. Students conduct research in galactic archaeology, variable stars, and spectroscopy.

descriptions.name: Yuba City Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: The Yuba City Astronomical Observatory, established on September 22, 2010, is located south of Yuba City, California adjacent to the Sutter Buttes Mountain Range. Primary research focuses on planetary observation, deep-sky studies, and near-Earth object tracking.

descriptions.name: Yunnan Astronomical Observatory
descriptions.description: Founded in the late 1930s during World War II, the Yunnan Astronomical Observatory was established by astronomers evacuated from Beijing. Located near Kunming, YNAO operates over 20 observation facilities including the 2.4-meter optical telescope in Lijiang.

descriptions.name: Zagreb Observatory
descriptions.description: The Zagreb Astronomical Observatory, founded in 1903, is located in the Popov Toranj, a 13th-century structure in central Zagreb. The main telescope is a 175/1400 mm TMB APO refracting telescope installed in September 2007.

descriptions.name: Zimmerwald Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1956 and located 10 kilometers south of Bern, Switzerland, Zimmerwald Observatory is the largest professional observatory in Switzerland. It serves as a critical station of the International Laser Ranging Service (ILRS) for satellite laser ranging.

descriptions.name: Zlín Observatory
descriptions.description: The Zlin Observatory in the Czech Republic is a public astronomical facility offering educational and research opportunities. It represents an important cultural and scientific institution in the Zlin area.

descriptions.name: Zvenigorod Observatory
descriptions.description: The Zvenigorod Observatory, established in 1958 by the Institute of Astronomy of the Russian Academy of Sciences, conducts research at 184 meters elevation. Scientists conduct educational programs and research on meteors, comets, and space debris.

descriptions.name: Zweibrücken Observatory
descriptions.description: The Zweibrucken Observatory, operated by the Natural Science Association since its 2002 founding, is located on the University of Applied Sciences campus in Zweibrucken, Germany. The dome's 2018 paint job depicting R2-D2 is a notable feature.

descriptions.name: ÇOMÜ Ulupınar Observatory
descriptions.description: The COMU Ulupinar Observatory was established in 2001 and formally opened on May 19, 2002, as part of Canakkale Onsekiz Mart University. It houses Turkey's largest telescope, a 1.22-meter German-made instrument.

descriptions.name: Épendes Observatory
descriptions.description: The Ependes Observatory, located near Fribourg, Switzerland at 700 meters elevation, is dedicated to popularizing astronomy. Astronomers at this observatory have discovered 133 minor planets since 2005.

descriptions.name: Østervold Observatory
descriptions.description: Ostervold Observatory in Copenhagen, Denmark was relocated to the Ostervold bastioned fortifications in 1861 under astronomer Heinrich Louis d'Arrest, who published a catalog of 1,942 nebulas. The building remains an architectural landmark.

descriptions.name: Úpice observatory
descriptions.description: The Upice Observatory in the Czech Republic has been conducting solar research and investigating the effects of solar activity on the human organism and biosphere since 1959.

descriptions.name: Ústecká hvězdárna
descriptions.description: The Ustecka hvezdarna (North Bohemia Observatory) was completed in 1929 in Libonov, Czech Republic. Astronomer Erwin Finlay-Freundlich, a collaborator of Albert Einstein, continued meteorological observations there after arriving from Istanbul in 1937.

descriptions.name: Ďáblice Observatory
descriptions.description: The Dablice Observatory on Ladvi Hill in Prague has welcomed stargazers since its opening on November 3, 1956. It houses a historic 19-centimeter refracting telescope from 1903, the oldest public telescope in the Czech Republic.

descriptions.name: Ōizumi Observatory
descriptions.description: Oizumi Observatory in Gunma Prefecture, Japan officially opened in 1990 and is notable as the workplace of amateur astronomer Takao Kobayashi, who has discovered over 2,000 minor asteroids.

descriptions.name: Štefánik's Observatory
descriptions.description: Built in 1928 by the Czech Astronomical Association, Stefanik's Observatory on Prague's Petrin hill was named after Slovak astronomer Milan Rastislav Stefanik. The facility houses a large Zeiss double astrograph with a 400-millimeter mirror.

descriptions.name: Ždánice Observatory
descriptions.description: The Zdanice Observatory was inaugurated on November 28, 1965 and serves as an educational and research center in the Zdanice region of the Czech Republic.

descriptions.name: Žebrák Observatory
descriptions.description: Zebrak Observatory is an astronomical observation facility located in the Czech Republic town of Zebrak, operated with an all-sky camera system for monitoring atmospheric conditions.

descriptions.description: The Rusakovskaya Street Observatory is a Russian astronomical facility representing an important astronomical research or educational institution in Russia.

descriptions.name: 綠山城大學天文台
descriptions.description: The Midori-yama Tatsuta University Observatory is a Japanese astronomical facility associated with its namesake university. The facility serves educational and research purposes in Japan.
